content:
Posted: June 17, 2016
												Great game.Objective is to mine ore to be able to build faster more powerful equipment to power and mine deeper. Eventaully the game becomes a defend your base type game with waves of flying insects. The bigger your base becomes the harder the waves get. A lot of the fun is figuring out how to make your base more efficent by building more ore transports and researching new tech and then upgrading your base.Game is updated almost every 4-6 weeks for release buids of game but there are also bleedign edge builds that are updated multiple times a week.This is a great casual game. Great for kids. If you are still on the fence, watch some videos on youtube. Thye may look very complex but it really isn't too bad and the game spoon feeds you new blocks so you don't get too overwhelmed too quickly.Some of the negatives of the game is sometimes it seems you are waiting around for ore instead of doing something fun. You could always be making your mine shaft bigger but in the begining you don't know how much space you will need. There really isn't much guidance after a very short tutorial. Also, if your base gets killed, it is no big deal. It repairs itself, So there isn't a real reason to defend it. Of course that might not always be the case since the game does get updated often and there is a large DLC being created that should be out this year.

number of helpful: 29 of 34 people (85%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 9, 2016
												Its a very nice 3D version of Factorio (+minecraft). I know it isn't exactly like it, but it has just VERY strong Factorio vibes to it.  Not as complex in the long term maybe or maybe it is... (and not as polished yet) , but thats balanced out by the 1st person perspective and the 3rd dimension. That makes things much more interesting, immersive but also nicely confusing.  Walking THROUGH a messy (first) factory is a greater experience than watching it from far above.  And of course there is the 3rd dimension thing.  It goes DEEP. Setting up a little base in a huge cave 500+m underground feels good but is challenging due to the balancing issues.There isn't really a goal and target though. Maybe thats why it's going for somwhat more micromanagement. It  adds a strong Minecraft part to the thing, which makes it different to factorio.  But thats the world, the blocks, the digging (though MUCH faster) and the mining. The crafting on the other hand thankfully feels much more intuitive, much more Factorio then Minecraft(+Tekkit&co)Some balance decisions are a bit questionable. Like the first real ore smelter being so far down the research tree. You're stuck with the 1 free one for a long time and can't even move it for a long time. Also wrong choices in research can get you seriously stuck (Suit heater&Toxic filter!).Especiall since you see no tech tree. Only google tells you, what you need for what later on. Not going into too much detail but generally crafting end research gets too grindy later on. But can be adjusted by editing xml files with an text editor.Also due to all storage systems being (imho) seriously undersized, it remains despite automation, more manual and demands more micromanagement in the longer run.With the little tutorial, ingame help, trial and error and not too much google/youtube, its not too hard to figure out how things work and get something going.Once you know the basics, and (like in factorio) with the first conveyor systems and automations it gets more complex, more interesting. The first attempt will never be great. But you learn from it. But thats not a con for me if some balance is kept. Thats part of the charm of such a game! As it is in factorio.It doesnt need a longe step by step tutorial to the perfect facility for me. Although i would have appreciated the information that conveyers simply transport stuff vertically as well. Its mentioned nowhere. Thats VERY helpful to know if your miner is at -170m. Also that new torches are made automatially from coal in the inventory, when placed and don't need to be crafted with a recipe. Its literally the only item that does this and thus not expected....The world/game creating options have several parameters suiting new players. Like keep inventory on death. I can't possibly imagine doing the deep game without "dying back home".Maybe with much more experience.Prize wise, especially with the expensive Frozen Factory DLC (which isn't necessary for new players!), its probably worth, waiting for a sale. But if you liked factorio and look for something  kinda similar but in 3D AND can forgive a few rough edges, its really worth it (maybe at reduced prize).Just don't hit it with expectations like for a 40€ AAA game. That's silly.PS: It runs stable for me, native 21:9 support, Graphics not amazing but nice enough. Lighting at times can be annoying. But overbright pipes have been fixed in recent update. Steam workshop support (though not that much content). All is well on the technical side. Can't tell about multiplayer though. Also mods disable Achievements. Which is the single most stupid idea game devs ever came up with.PPS: There is no Steam or game option, to change language. So its only available in english.PPPS: Warning: This game is as time-eating as Factorio. Everytime you look at the clock its two hours later then you wanted to stop playing.

number of helpful: 31 of 39 people (79%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2015
												I don't normally write reviews, but this game deserves a review. I absolutly adore this game and has tons of wonderfull ideas and features with literally constant updates. So lets get into the game. What is it? You could say its minecraft but in all honestly...it kind of isnt. It is its own unique game with tons of unique blocks and features that I would love to have in minecraft, that not even modded minecraft can offer. So lets get the good and the bad in the game listed in a nice little list. This is a little lengthy so if you dont want to read all of this and want to know the short versionSHORT Version: Its a good game lots of features and updates, little bugs, if there are it gets fixed pretty quickly, dev streams and listens to his watchers. Also they look at feedback and love to get feedback on the game.LONG: If you want more depth here you go.PROS:-It is constantly updated on a daily baises. There are new features almost weekly and when they did a poll on their twitter, literallythe next day there was a solution and was implemented within a pretty short amount of time. A day or two before it was in the game.-Bugs are quickly addressed when reported and usually will have a patch in a decent amount of time, depending on how game breaking it is of course.-Multiple tiers that you work your way through as you go deeper into the world.-Researching those tiers. The deeper you get the more Research points you get (RP) The more blocks and flora you scan the more you unlock.-Replayability. Theres a lot of replayability in this game and with constant updates and a lot of features being planned it is always a new experience. (Especially if they add the planned features like space)-ARTHER. An amazing little robot that you can dress in a top hat, eye monocle and an good looking moustache. Love it! Though hes really useful ingame with status updates and back up power if you run low.-Much more to list that would just make this ungodly long.-Multiple game modes that are pretty fun ranging from hardcore and rush mode one or two others that I cant think of atm.CONS-Not everything is implemented yet. Some stuff is in there but it hasnt been properly fleshed out. (Though this isnt in early access, it still technically is because of a lot of reasons that you need to game developers point of view to understand. (Which the dev actually explained to us in a stream in depth which gives you a big understanding of the gaming industry. Like the top games make 90% of the money. Even though fortress craft is in the top 500 for steam games they still struggle, so even though this is the con section, I highly suggest if you buy the game you buy the DLC with it to help support them))-Things can be a little difficult to piece together, even with the handbook, so it may take a little bit of time to figure things out or do a little research (Again its being fleshed out and the handbook is still unfinished so its understable)-Your kind of stuck in spot defending the same area. Now Im sure they have plans to change that especially when they plan to implement space, so for right now your kind of defending your castle.Honestly Im just prying cons out of anything I can just to make this seem fair, but there really arent to many cons. If you cant launch the game then talk to the dev. They'll try to help you. Trust me, they want to help you and expand their player base. You can listen into one of their streams and their ideas and viewpoints are really nice to listen into and really put time into their game. It is a bit of a tedious game so it takes time to make things but once you get the hang of it you will surely have fun. This is truly a fantastic game and you should give it a chance. I would honestly even say that this game should be valued way more then 10-15$ for the amount of work they put in, so its a pretty good deal for a game like this.

content:
Posted: March 7
												If you like Factorio or Minecraft with tech mods, you must buy this.If you don't know what I'm talking about, but you like Automation, Logistics, Production, Multi-tasking or games that can actually feel alien, hard or challeging, then you should try it out.Although the 'FortressCraft' name may make it seem like another one of the infinite Minecraft clones and knock-offs, the only thing it shares with Minecraft is the voxel-based world. A bunch of other things can resemble modded Minecraft, however, it's still unique and easily stands on its own.FCE is all about exploring and finding resources, and getting machines to exploit those resources for you. Instead of spending most of your time manually digging and mining, you'll spend your time actually thinking, planning and implementing solutions of all kinds, expanding your base and coming up with cool machine designs and setups to do boring work for you while you run around using your time where it really matters.I've first played FCE years ago, and now that I came back to it, it's much different. There's a lot of improvements, from visual, to technical and gameplay improvements, which really makes it all an even more solid experience.If there's one thing I would complain about FCE (and how it changed), is that some things take insane amount of resources to craft. Indoubtly those were (re-)balancing attempts, but I'd prefer more sensible requirements. I'm still barely on the mid-game, though, so I can't give a proper, full review on its balancing and wether such high requirements make sense.To be really concise, FCE is not for everyone. So I do recommend you check videos out if you can.It can be time consuming and it will make you think about solutions and designs when you're away from the game. It might make you draw setups in notebooks. It might make you want to stick solar panels wherever you can.The developer, after all those years, still works on the game. Which is why I'll be buying the DLCs soon - it's really admirable to see someone working on something for so long after it's release, without it being ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t features or updates.There's something satisfying about striking the earth, exploiting an alien planet's resources, and using said resouces to murder the innocent creatures that lived there before you.Become an Evolved FortressCrafter today.PS: I should mention: This game has the most cool, fun and satisfying "grappling hook" I've ever seen in a videogame yet.

content:
Posted: May 17, 2016
												I became addicted to this game in the oddest way. There were probably three or four minutes in the entire day of total playtime that I actually enjoyed myself. But the more I invested myself in the game, the more I felt determined to get something out of it, and the more time I shoved into it. I spent almost all of yesterday (5/16/2016) playing, desperately trying to make progress.There are several problems with making progress.First off, this is not a single player game. It may have the ability to be played single player, but it's not single player. There just isn't enough progress for it to be single player. In order to make a reasonable amount of progress on my own, I edited files in order to vastly speed up my gameplay. Somehow, that made it go from very boring to incredibly boring.Nothing happens quickly on your own. Even with the game settings set all the way to the quickest, easiest, fastest settings. You need 32 bars of something to build x. Well, settle in, that'll take a while unless you've already got five or six systems running. And it's not like setting those up is quick. Or cheap.And don't get me started on how long it takes to research pretty much anything once you've got the laboratory. The projects take ages to complete, and enough resources that after a day of highly sped-up gameplay, I was barely able to make some of it.But that's not the worst part about this game.This game is NOT finished. This game was early-access, and still should be! It's nowhere near complete. I find bugs everywhere I go. I come back to my base and all my turrets are facing firmly in one direction, a giant laser firing out. The ship I crashed in is on fire (it's only been two months in-game since I landed, I'm sure that's normal). The CPH is projecting some kind of field that is making it awfully hard to see. Various other things are making all sorts of very bright frames of animation that make it practically impossible for me to see what the hell is happening in my base.My laser turrets are still working fine. It's just impossible to tell that.I place another laser turret on top of another block I've placed, and all the bugs disappear in an instant.Before I do that, the ship hurts me if I get too close.Now? No worries, I can walk straight through it.I assure you, this is one of many, many bugs that I've encountered. The list got so long I didn't bother remembering them.Then, there's the simple fact that some things are either badly implemented, have missing icons, mismatched icons, or maybe their help file doesn't exist.Make some iron pipe if you can. Or find something that requires iron pipe and look at the picture. As of this moment, the picture is a big red x and the words "NO ICON". Go grab some cave flora from the cold or toxic caverns. One of each. Then, place them. Place them against a wall, and turn them twice, so they're actually right-side-up. Don't ask why. Now, compare the flora you just placed to the icon. They're mismatched. A is B, B is A, C is D, etc.How about auto-excavators? Place one on a wall, and you'll probably think it can dig a 3x3 hole horizontally. Maybe if you place it on the ceiling, it can dig down, instead of up! Why would you think that? Because the column of light indicating where it can dig shows that!You'd be wrong. Once you power it up, no matter where you're trying to 'aim' it, it shoots up.The list goes on. There are things that are just plain problematic. Things that are useless. Things that make no sense. Things that are poorly implemented, buggy, unfinished, and more. It is, quite frankly, awful, and if you look at the pictures saying "Oh, I want that!", then either join a server with a dozen other players or be prepared to keep playing for WEEKS (Actual time played, not number of days you played for a little while) in order to get there.

number of helpful: 33 of 44 people (75%) found this review helpful10 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 3, 2016
												After about 100 hours pure playing time, I can definitely recommend this game to all those who liked/loved Factorio or similar games.You are stranded on a foreign planet, but somehow a small friend called Arthur and a giang spider-bot survived the impact (or you built them after the crash, I don't know). The world looks like Minecraft, but feels more realistic, and your task is to gather ressources and build up a working factory (not like a big plant, but several small pieces put together to smelt, craft, shape, improve, research many things you find on the planet) so that you can finally be rescued or something (don't know, I didn't came so far yet). But (same as Minecraft, Factorio and similar) you are not alone on this planet. The more you proceed down the earth (or however this planet is called) the more you attract some kind of insectiods, which will visit your factory from time to time and check if you need anything (like terror and death). They seemed driven by a higher intelligence, and yes there is something like that. Either somewhere burried in earth are some huge globbing eyes hidden behind a undiggable wall of ... don't know what, looks like the stuff from the Alien-Movie. Those "Eyes" send small creatues to steal ressources from unprotected conveyors to reach with their ugly arms after your factory. The other ones are vastly huge, four-headed, brain-thingy, glowing ... things. Well, you will recognize once you see them. And, I don't know wether I was day-dreaming... but I think I saw something like that worm from Star Wars that was hidden inside that asteroid trying to eat the Falcon... Conclusion:Quit your Job, break up with girl-/boyfriend, close windows and doors, headphones on, uhm... maybe VR if you have  and buy the game. You will not regret (as long as you belong to the above mentioned target group) !

number of helpful: 41 of 59 people (69%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14, 2016
												Let me start by saying that this game IS FUN.  I have played for many hours(although a lot of that time was spent afk... I tend to forget I have games running) The basic concept of the game is great, gather resources, build massive assembly lines, defend against attacks, all to save yourself when you crashed on a freezing planet.  So then why the negative review?  The game appears to be a released title but upon deeper investigation (after I had bought the game, stupid me) I realized that it was still in Alpha/Beta but the developer wanted to make more money so he "released" it on steam.  The game has missing icons/textures, wonky AI, and is still has a MASSIVE list of features to be added, bugs to fix, and balance issues to address.  I havn't encountered the game breaking crashes/bugs others have reported.  IF I WANTED TO PLAY EARLY ACCESS I WOULD BE HAPPY.  The game is being updated and features are being added.  The negative review stems from the fact that it is not a complete game even though it appears that way at first.Oh, also the dev has stated that he is breaking the game into several expansion packs.  So you only get part of the content for your initial purchase.  However he only recently decided this(or made it clear).  I can understand wanting to get paid but it is sneaky and dishonest to publish an unfinished game and then charge people more money if they want the finished product.  If all this were clear on the store page I wouldn't be writing this review(and would probably be fine with it... although i would have waited until the game was complete before considering purchase).  The sneaky way it is handled is what bothers me.So FOR NOW I do not reccomend purchasing this game.  When it is finished (provided it get's there, i've had baaad luck with early access titles, I will rewrite this review.

content:
Posted: December 16, 2013
Early Access Review
								Totally recommend this game, 10/10 even at pre-alphaIf  you are a creative person and enjoy building, then in this game even at pre-alpha you can build anything you can think of, your imagination is your only limitation, if you have the patience to learn how to use the tools in this gaame to create whatever your imagination inspires then you will love it.     You may like to check out the many screenshots and guides in the community hubOne of the main features i love about Fortresscraft are the creative tools we are given to make our creations.....for example..."the workshop" a  plaace you can build and save your own custom detail blocks to then use to build your own creations, best of all you can create well in excess of 1,000 of them if you so wanted to."superbuild mode"instantly create small or huge square areas of blocks, do the same for a cylinder shape, and also create Spheres, either sit back in amazement and watch as they build in front of you or go and build something else while they are being built for you."copy & paste and schematics"wow........just...wow ....select something you have built like a house or in my case a Robot made with 50+ custom detail blocks, then copy it, then paste it somewhere else or save it as a schematic then go to your schematics at any time and select it and paste it whenever you want to. You can eeven rotate the whole thing before you paste it.... amazing"lighting"configurable lighting at that!!!! configure the colour strength and distance and even shadow type, individually for every single light you place.I could go on and on but then if you are liking whats mentioned above then you are most likely going to enjoy the game and enjoy exploring everything else out once you start playing it and creating anything you can think up.I hope this review is of help to you. For other info check the Community hub guides and screenshots, and if you purchase the game then i hope you enjoy it as much as i have been.

content:

Early Access Review

content:
Posted: April 13, 2016
												I hate giving this game a negative review, because I really like it. But I've a simple rule: Games that are incomplete and not marked early access get the thumbs down. There are many resources with descriptions like "not implemented yet" or "has no use yet, but will soon." There are big mechanics of the game (losing a base assault for example) which don't do anything. The game is quite playable and enjoyable, but it's not even in beta yet.Alot of people were complaining about this game, and honestly I think it was because they didn't understand the mechanics. I remember one guy complaining that generators don't work underground so you can't go very deep... i guess he didn't see all the power transmission devices? But then, blocky games with "craft" in the title are clearly targetting the minecraft audience, and I think this game requires a bit more maturity to understand.The game really is pretty good, although a bit rough around the edges. I think the game could use a rebalance to make resource management less cumbersome. Specifically, late game components (mk III lasers for example) take quite a few resources to build. But hey, it's an automation game so that's perfectly reasonable, you just need to build more mines. The problem is that if you build enough mines to keep those your factory making those at a reasonable pace, the storage of resources becomes a nightmare.In my situation, I've got two or three machines making late game components, and my storage facility (which is really big btw) is either completely empty, or overflowing to the point where my transit lines jam up. I'm constantly running up and down my mine to turning drills on and off so that my storage won't overflow, becase honestly (and here's the important part) it's easier to turn them on and off then to make a storage facility large enough to support the flow.I often see the developer on the forums asking things like "what would you like to see?" I'd like to see cheaper storage and transport in the early game (so you can ramp up faster without all the waiting for tin bars), and higher tier transport and storage in the late game. Just something as simple as a "super hopper" that's expensive but holds 1000 resources would go a long way. A faster transport system then the tubes would be nice too (or maybe mk 4 lasers and more powerful matter-movers). Just something along those lines.Anyway, that's my take on it. I love the factory games, and this is the best 3D one I've found, although it still has a long way to go. To those who like the automation aspects of this game, do make a point of looking at Factorio though, because it is the best IMHO.

Posted: November 12, 2015
												Do NOT be fooled this is NOT a minecraft ripoff, although it is a blocky game.This game is about base automation and defending that base from hostiles.There is an aim and end too this game. Not just dig dig dig.Yes it has blocks and looks a bit like those other blocky games, but it is not "just another rip off".This game is about -resource management-strategy and proritisation-energy management-logistics-efficient layout-organisation of your base.  Then there is the tower defence side of things too.Pro's -process automation-runs well -active developer-developer engages with the players-developer is passionate about the game-Survival and creative modes-generally better graphics than many other blocky games-Need to think differently to get the hang of automation-Strategy -Good for an indie game-Co-op Multiplayer-Ongoing development of new features-Ore scanner - I love the ore scanner!!! Con's -Need to think differently, can take time to get head around automation-Tower defence may not appeal to everyone-Not perfect (but no worse than a lot of AAA titles I have bought)-Can lose hours of your day without realising-Some mobs are a little annoying-Some animations are glitchy-Learning curve can seem a bit steep, until you change the way you thinkNOTE I have not had the pleasure trying the multiplayer so I can't comment on the state of it but it is present.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2016
												I've been around a long time and played a lot of stuff, so hopefully this statement will have some gravity: FortressCraft Evolved is easily one of the most engaging, intellectually stimulating, enjoyable experiences I have ever had with a game.  No caveats.  It's not just good "for a game developed by one guy," it's good period.  On top of that, it's backed by a strong and helpful community, and a dev that engages with us on a daily basis to take in feedback.  Depending on how you play it, it is also extremely challenging, in a way that, rather than testing your ability to move and click your mouse as quickly as possible, tests your ability to problem solve.As I'm writing this, I'm noticing that the price for the game is $4.41 (base), or $13.90 (with all DLC) because of the winter sale.  That's insane.  At 576 hours played, that's a little over $0.02/hour.  I guess they say the best things in life are free... or at least close to it.

content:
Posted: January 23
												This is an updated review. Recommendation remains the same.I hate tower defense games, and I despise them with a passion. There are a few exceptions, if they are cleverly hidden or done in such a way that a player does not feel punished for playing an overly specific strategy. FortressCraft Evolved, accomplishes this feat, so I give it a glowing recommendation.Let's start this off by saying it is less about "building" a base in the sense one would in other survival games. You are essentially building yourself a self-sustaining factory that will get increasingly more complex, and better defended in a nearly endless cycle. Oh, and you're going to have to do this with a constant threat of aliens that will scale their attacks to how well you are doing.This does not mean the game is punishing you for doing well, but rather rewarding you with better loot, and always having some sense of urgency. There is a tipping point where you can outright utterly crush the alien threat if you so choose. With the Frozen Factory Expansion, ending one threat allows you to focus on a new threat, or fight both at the same time if you are feeling adventurous. With many survival games, it gets boring once you hit a certain point, but in FortressCraft Evolved, the game will try harder to wreck your progress.Naturally, the player is not going to want to lose all that progress after investing many hours into their elaborate base. This is not a problem, because once the aliens kill the CPH, they all leave. They don't blow everything up to get to it either, so they rush that part of the base and only that part (with exceptions). Your goal is to have enough firepower to prevent that. Which, with a giant mechanized spider warmachine, turrets, missile launchers, and your crappy laser rifle, give the player lots to work with. Of course, keeping missiles stocked, turrets powered, and the spiderbot fueled is the player's responsibility.This may irritate some players, as they'll either feel "too rushed" or "not rushed enough" which comes down to player preference, not balance. There are also some people who feel the game is too grindy, yet there are settings to speed things along, so if this is a complaint, they never bothered to actually use them. Many of the negative reviews are people who either A) Didn't follow the integrated tutorial. B) Did not check any settings ever. C) Had issues that Unity caused, not the developer. This isn't some rampant fanboy comment either, as the same issue arose in several other games at the same time!To add to that, the developer is active, and involved with the community. Visiting streams, streaming while working, and on several occassions personally fixed a bug on the spot. I'm not joking, I had a bug and brought it up on stream, and that bug was fixed within minutes. There are few developers that care that much. Yes, they are blunt too which might seem a tad arrogant, but at least you know where you stand. Sometimes a suggestion is met with a good discussion about "why that won't happen" which means that the developer has a vision, and not prone to "feature creep". Despite a few heated discussions personally (usually on why not x feature from Factorio), I still felt respected as long as respect was given. For a game review, I mention this because developer interaction is important, even long after the game has left Early Access.If you can swing it, I'd highly recommend the Frozen Factory Expansion as well. It adds more stuff, a new enemy threat, and is a seemless transition from vanilla to the expansion. With another Expansion down the road, there has been a lot of new free content that has been added as well, so the game is still going strong.Overall, I recommend FortressCraft Evolved. I would like to mention that as a fan of "logistics" style games like Factorio, this game feels right at home so I enjoy both for different reasons. Co-op is stable, and quite fun. I play with the same group for a lot of different games, and every playthrough we're always trying/finding something new. For the hours I've put in, the money I've spent (even on the dev's Patreon) has been well worth it.System Specs CPU: Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-4790K Processor @ 4.40GHz CPU Cooler: Corsair H100i GPU: GeForce GTX 970 G1 Gaming Memory: Corsair Vengeance 32GB OS: Windows 10 Pro

content:
Posted: January 13
 2017 Update It still amazes me that 1 Dev built this game... This is not a game you pick up and spend a few hours and get to see most of the game, the base game, start to finish for a "new" player could easily take 150-200hrs (learning curve, experimenting) You will have a massive "factory" style base with tower defense action by the time you are done. Its quite amazing setting up new, efficient production capabilities within this game. You could compare this to Factorio in some aspects but it definitely takes it own spin and style.  Cons: - Not friendly to new players - The first 75hrs you put in, you can probably do in 20hrs in a second attempt- Early Grind - This actually turns off 80-90% of the players from the last statistics I saw, it sucks, I still hate it but its a new game grind that the Dev keeps in this game for some reason.   My biggest gripe to date: It's still being tweaked and updated with expansions (your probably wondering why thats bad)... Well, its a one man team and for me, optimization took a drop following Version 14/15 and we have an expansion on the near horizon. The lag spikes and issues get more apparent the larger your base gets, he has released performance improvements in the past few updates but it still doesn't feel that it is helping much. This pretty much made me shelf the game. Recommendation: Its definitely worth every penny. Just be prepared for some issues mid to late game until he has more time to focus on them.

content:
Posted: November 10, 2016
												The indie games I've played over the years have typically been solid ambassadors of their genres and as such set a high standard and I'm sad to admit that fortresscraft evolved is not a great game. Playing it will require you to plough through any of the inevitable boredom or irritation you will likely initially experience. I wouldn't be surprised if only 1% of the people who bought this game played over 10 hours. If you consider yourself a tolerant and patient person, and loved factorio, then perhaps this is a game for you. You may even love this game as I did. I would especially recommend it on sale.If you do decide to buy this game, I recommend watching some playthroughs on youtube, specifically Tango Tek or direwolf20. They are both entertaining and provide a great tutorial of at least the early-mid game. Enough to get you started. But yet again this comes down to the effort you are willing to put in. If you have a life rather than a sinkhole of hours, this game is not for you. I very much enjoy this game, but the game suffers numerous flaws.I'm going to say what I didn't like about the game, as I feel it would be more useful to the reader. Main points are emboldened, so just read those unless you want some detail.--  Lack of a proper tutorial  --You start with a bad joke of an unfinished tutorial which is totally unbefitting of a game as complex as fortresscraft evolved. There is a LOT of material you need to get to grips with, while the tutorial shows you the basics in as minimal a way as possible.Granted, there is a brilliant help mechanic known as contextual help, showing you suggested items found at your stage in the game, selected hotbar items, current research etc. I found this essential on my first playthrough, and it's more helpful than I feel I'm making it sound. However as useful as it is, it much feels like dragging my eyes through page after page in a sort of wiki. This game has a  HUGE  learning curve. It really just needs a proper optional tutorial.--  Game is Buggy/Unpolished  --This game is very raw and has quite a few bugs. It should certainly still be in early access. Some even accuse the developer of trying to get more sales through an incomplete release. All the 'little things' that fill out the detail in a game and give it life often just can't be found, which I believe is due to a complete lack of motivation when it comes to the developer refining such aspects.The UI is quite ugly. There aren't any sorting algorithms in inventory. Item transfer to storage is poor, totally manual, and tedious. Animations are short, or non-existant; dying in every way will result in a message popup on screen before you respawn. Alien attacks consist of 3 (sort of 4) enemy designs, (most of which you won't see for a very long time), all fairly basic and all essentially only feature variations in health; a total lack of effort in that field. There are about 7 enemy creatures in total. Progression is a little erratic, which I pin to bad design. You can see through unloaded chunks in the game and see certain objects. The game has placeholder items that do not yet exist. Crafting recipes that are 'to be removed'. Some items are missing icons. Game progression is clunky and non-uniform. This game should NOT have been seeing a release for quite a while. --  Gameplay and progression is slow, unintuitive and erratic  --This game is entirely about gameplay.That said the gameplay in this is so slow that it's comparable to a civilisation game. This is not a bad thing in itself, but the game is not entertaining enough through all portions of this time. The main reason this game takes so long is the learning curve, but also the complexity of the game. If it were employed correctly, this complexity would be a delightful thing. Some of the complexity of this game could be considered to be filler, 'fleshing out' time where it doesn't and shouldn't really exist. Looking into what's been [partially implemented/recently introduced] into the game so far, it looks like this isn't going to improve. The game is also a little asymmetrical in terms of its progression. Certain things will be required to progress, which may depend on luck, and can be infuriating, especially given how unintuitive parts of the game are, and how there can be missing information that should be in the game, or on the wiki, etc. For example, organic rock and the smelting bottleneck. Perfect eyes as the T3 (and T2 and a half) barrier and hardened resin. These examples are those on luck. It should also be noted that in my playthroughs I've been quite fortunate, recieving comparatively large ore veins so that I had to do less restructuring and relocating in between other tasks. Others may not be as fortunate and may have to spend time backtracking in addition to the awkward progression. Certainly no fun when you're waiting on resources for conveyors. A positive element of the gameplay would be the tower defence, which I quite enjoy and wish there was more focus on, providing a logisitcal challenge, and later even a minor tactical one. There is an emphasis on efficiency in general in this game, which means it can be quite rewarding of good ideas and consideration to the mechanics. —  Graphics  —The game is generally quite ugly. Very little emphasis on visuals and even less on visual effects. Some effects may look quite cool, and some machines unique, but the rest of the game in general just looks bad or plain.However my beef here is with the lighting system. It makes everything look completely crap. Bloom everywhere where you place lights, or during the day, and total pitch black darkness everywhere else anytime else. This area really needs some work.--  DLC, the dev and the community  --While nowhere near as bad as say... Payday 2, DLC is certainly starting to become a noticeable concept within this game, which can only barely be considered complete. they're even selling skins for your character at this point in development (despite being first person). A full display of the dev's priories.The community is toxic in some spaces. It's like a stream of people with the attitude of professional youtube commenters come for a ride on any fortresscraft forums. Lots of baseless hate. Some pretentious ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. See other reviews for more detail on that. Dev is sometimes a bit of a♥♥♥♥♥♥himself where he can get away with it.I'd love to see more games settle in this genre, it's generally fun, but poorly executed in this case, maybe because of the small idea-pool. Overall community response to dev and communication with the community from what I've seen is displeasing, despite the game supposedly having been in early access. Maybe someone can pick up the baton, perhaps even the dev, even if only little further.

content:
Posted: October 28, 2016
												I've played this game more than any other game, well over 700 hours.  I will play for a few weeks every day and then move onto something else, however FortressCraft keeps pulling me back, at which point I start a new game.  The game is constantly updated with new stuff. You start at the crash site of your ship, with a few machines and a brief tutorial.  When I first started over a year ago, the game didn't have a guide to the early game.  Now in the corner of the screen the game will suggest what you should focus on.  You can follow that or not, but I think it's helpful to new players.  The game becomes like a tower defense after your base threat level reaches 100 or higher.  Your threat increases the more you build machines and generators.  You can build Threat Reduces to bring that number back down, something I did when I first started playing, to avoid the wasps which shoot acid at your Hub.  I have since found out that it's better to focus on defensive turrets and arming your SpiderBot with blasters.  At threat level 100 to I dunno, a few hundred, only a few waves of some wasps will come at you.  The higher the number, the more waves of higher numbers will come.  Eventually when you get into the 1000s larger bugs will attack and when you get higher still giant creatures will spawn.  The focus of this game is automation.  I used to try to do everything manually, taking 100s of trips up and down into deep caverns to retrieve ore.  Many new techologies have been added to the game such as transporters and lifts to automate the process.  BTW don't use conveyor belts below like 75 or 80m because creatures will spawn on them and consume your resources.  I should note that I play on "scarce" resources and power, meaning it takes more ore to smelt into each bar and less power generation.  I also play on Clumsy death, meaning I drop my inventory items upon death and have to make a corpse run.  "Scarce" difficulty really increases the time needed to progress.  After spending 100s of hours discovering new, better ways of doing things, I think I have a pretty good system going.  I haven't really watched any videos or read any tips on playing this game.  I prefer to figure out things on my own.  There are videos and guides out there to help you get started, offering tips to optimize your efforts/resources/time, etc.  I could've saved TONS of time by watching these but I like to discover better ways of doing things on my own.  The game seems intimidating at first, but it's addicting!  The developer has added beginner tips and technology guides you can see by pressing "H".  Also before researching, highlight a technology and press "H" to see what machines the research will unlock.  This is relatively new and very helpful to make research decisions when starting out.  I recommend suit upgrades, mining upgrades, and power upgrades first.  Also mine as much coal as you can!  You will need tons in the early game before better power generation methods are available.  I recommend starting on the default "plenty" resouces/power.  It will greatly shorten the time needed to really get going.  Research requires research points which are gained by scanning unknown plants and materials.  Scan everything!  You will eventually gain enough research points to research everything, but it's best to choose carefully in the early game so read the help guide to make the right decisions.  I highly recommend this game, it's one of my favorites and it's always fun to discover better ways of doing things.  If you want a game with fast progression and quick rewards, this may not be the game for you.  Researching in the early game takes a lot of time and you can quickly run out of coal to generate power.

												Great game. Been changed so much from last christmas and keeps getting better.When i 1st played it all you had to do was mine and automate production. That was last year, now just mining is only half of it. You gotta set up defences with turrets to save ur main base from attack from mobs (the more u produce you more come) You gotta protect your belts for moving ore up from the mines with turrets also to stop the hiveminds from claiming the ore back (Dont feed the hiveminds!) You've been warned. The tiers of equipment just keep getting bigger and better when i 1st played tier 1 to tier 3 was all i had now its up to tier 5 with 4.5mil storage! Multiblock batterys, solar arrays, labs, jet engines and other equipment all to help you advance just keep you wanting to keep building for faster lazers, more lethal turrets and faster energy makers. Every 300 blocks down or so there are special areas to keep you on ur toes these change the game around .Normal conveyor belts are that depth freeze so you need to upgrade to quicker ways to move ore like minecarts or air tubes. Its a very fun game where tactics and planning ahead will help you alot.

Early Access Review
								I've played a few games where you go around gathering resources and building stuff, and this is my favourite. There are obviously a few games in this genre, and most of the ones I've tried grab you pretty quickly, but they also let you go pretty quickly.This one, I'm still gripped, and with 37 hours showing, I can see 100's of hours still to be played, there is a lot to do in this, and it is still in active development, which is great.You start at your home base, with nothing. (As standard.) You wander around, dig stuff up, look for stuff with your scanner. Go back to base. Check out what you've found, discover a few new things to build.Dig up more stuff, build more stuff, research more stuff. That's the basics.You can sculpt vast areas, build huge supply chains to feed the machines you build, build bigger machines, set up defenses against the evil natives. And the more you do, the more you are thinking, ' Just need to do that, then I can do this, and that let's me do that, and then.....' and so it goes. This is a damn big game, and very addictive. Like I said, a lot of games in this genre, but this is the ace in the pack.Look at the price, it's an absolute bargain!

content:
Posted: May 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								Note: This is an Early Access review and may not reflect the finished product.After spending aproximately 170 hours in FC:E I feel that I am able to give a fairly accurate review of the current state of the game.FC:E basically has two modes to play in; Creative and Survival.CreativeThe game looks and feels very similar to many other voxel based games out there - notably Minecraft. However, FC:E stands out from the crowd due to the rather powerful tools that are available to the player. The various tools that you are able to use allow you to make very large and very intricate creations. Copy/Pasting sections of the world can be done very quickly and the ability to create your own blocks using the ingame workshop function allow a level of creativity that has not really been seen in such voxel games previously. I myself have not spent a huge amount of time in creative, however from the limited hours I have put in it became clear rather quick that those who enjoy the freedom of making anything they want will really benefit from these tools and this level of freedom.SurvivalHere's the mode that has stolen a huge amount of my time. In basic terms the survival aspect draws many of the gameplay aspects of those in Minecraft - mining, resource management etc. but here's where FC:E does it differently. A huge focus of FC:E's survival mode is based upon automation and logistics, creating large transport, mining and power networks to build a base and gather resources.The blocks that exist in the game all have useful functions and although can be a bit daunting at first, are quite easy to use and options for creativity open up once you get the hang of things. If you've played anything like the Feed the Beast modpacks for Minecraft or Factorio then this is the game for you.Current state of the gameAs far as I am aware the engine for this game was built by the developers themselves, allowing them to tailor it to suit the needs of a game like this. It's definately not perfectly optimised, but I have certainly seen worse and the development team are constantly working to improve on this as well as fix bugs, this is to be expected in an Early Access game.There's a decent amount of content in the game to allow you to spend quite a few hours building and creating what you want. The development cycle is quite fluid and the creators are quite active on the forums, responding to questions, asking for feedback, addressing issues etc.Mobs and combat are the next big thing to come, which will add quite a bit in terms of gameplay as you will need to defend your base and resources.Multiplayer in Creative is complete and as far as I'm aware pretty free of bugs. Survival Multiplayer is currently in a working condition although there are some bugs still to be ironed out, but as mentioned previously the devs are quite open and transparent about this and work on this is constant.Overall I believe this game is a steal at it's current price. Judging from what is already in the game and what has been discussed as the future of FC:E on the forums I really think this game sets itself apart from all the Minecraft clones on the market.

content:
Posted: March 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								Brilliant concept and tons of potential, but has failed miserably.Bought this game over a year ago. Nothing has changed. I saw the devs update less and less. Then Nothing. Then almost Months later come back screaming "where not dead!!!!." with no updates since then or anythign else done.Its my assumption this game is dead.Sure, some fun things to do in creative, but i bougth this for survival. And so its unplayable. So many bugs and glitches. You dig a hole and the wall disapears or you fall forever. Dig a deep hole to mine. No simple later to climb your way back up. Just that grappling hook which is ridicously stupid since you will grab a wall and will just fall instead of holding onto the ledge to regrapple to the next higher area.No enemies even though they sit there. You can't find any specific ore, or be able to access the ones you need.The robots or other tech to help you gather the resources don't work and create a really big irritant. I spent majority of my time running between sites trying to repower them so they could work a little more.Then you die by freezing to death. Go underground Freeze. Search for deposits, Freeze. Lose your energy, Freeze. No way to locate your base? Freeze. Repower yourself and end up burning yourself Alive.Speaking of which, No compass or way to find your base again! Yes the map is small (which is another issue), but you can't find your base, because everyhting looks the same.The map is small and you can't find any materials you need. I kept digging and digging, not a single material i needed (Lithium) *cough* *cough* could be found.I thougth this game would feature defend you minning base or somthing cause aliens will attack. Nope....And oh yes the UI.... Looks like a kid in HS made it. I mean its bad. Majoirty of the items in your inventory don't have images. Half the items don't work. and when would I make more than one item at a time? unless I'm in creative mode where I'm just messing around. At that point its boring to me. Sure maybe for you artsy ppl this is great. but for me its a waste of time and I find no entertainment out of it.Overall, A great concept. But executed so poorly and lacks so many updates. it is the worst game on my steam account.

content:
Posted: January 8
TL,DR: If you like complex games that make you think and experiment and don't mind a little rough around the edges gameplay/difficulty curve typical of a one-man development studio, you'll most likely get your money's worth out of this title.An interesting and fun take on a survival, factory building, and tower defense game. After crashing on a frozen planet, you're forced to bend that planet to your will in an attempt to destroy the native life threatening your very existence. You'll dig deep and unearth the resources to build ever more complex machines and the defenses to protect them. Don't let the voxels used in the game fool you, this is not a Minecraft clone even though there is a creative mode available. The real draw is survival. If it's too difficult, you could always bring a friend as FC:E is also multiplayer with both local and dedicated servers available!This is a true indie gem written solely by DJArcas who streams most of his development and is accessable via Steam forums. This title has come a long way since it has come out of Early Access and now has a full expansion titled the Frozen Factory, which further utilizes the chilly methane gas filled caverns found hundreds of meters beneath the surface of the planet. There is another planned expansion that will focus on even deeper layers near the planet's "core".DJArcas is also toying around with bringing VR to FortressCraft: Evolved. You can't do much except for touring your factory in VR, but it's still pretty neat. You do need a pretty hefty PC to run the game without VR, and enabling VR makes this requirement even more paramount.Most of the negative reviews are from veteran players that are upset about "recent" changes to the game that force you to *gasp* build machines and production lines (a.k.a. play the game). These changes include not being able to carry unlimited amounts of ore in your inventory and being unable to smelt ores underground. This is done to force the player to utilize the plethora of machines and automation at their disposal to accomplish these tasks and craft their factory. I'd like to reiterate that these negatives will have no impact to new players of the game as they haven't been spoiled by these shortcuts. This is akin to the players complaining that there is now fall damage in-game and now have to work around it (yes, this also happened). If you absolutely have to cheat, FortressCraft: Evolved is also Steam Workshop compatible and has mods available that basically enable cheating.

number of helpful: 63 of 104 people (61%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								Okay, I don't really know where to start.  Should I start with the amazing superbuild tool or the awesome weather staff?  I don't know.  I guess I'll start with the pros.  Two of the biggest advantages of FortressCraft (gonna call it fc from now on) are the superbuild tool and the copy/paste tool.  I find both of these EXTREMELY useful.  I can cut the time in half by just holding down ctrl + m1/m2, whereas in a game like Minecraft (I'm probably going to compare/contrast fc to Minecraft a lot in this review) it takes much time, patience, and effort to build things on a large scale.  Also, the way that the terrain spawns is pretty cool.  It moves in to take position instead of just appearing like in Minecraft.  Next, the list of blocks to choose from, in my opinion, is WAY bigger than that of Minecraft.  Configurable Lights, Ore Extractors, heck, even a huge laser gun!  Now before I start getting a lot of nasty comments on this review let me make one thing clear:  I do NOT hate Minecraft.  I actually like it. In some cases, I prefer it over fc, but remember:  this is the pros section. Okay, where was I?  Oh yes, the large library of blocks to choose from.  Ok, so moving on.  I also particularly like the lighting of the certain blocks that produce it.  I also like that the blocks to choose from are mostly sci-fi themed, whereas Minecraft has more of a 'survival' themed list.  Alright, I think that covers the pros!  Now to the cons.  Fc is probably one of the buggiest games that I've ever played.  Now, hold you horses!  This is an EARLY ACCESS game.  You would be a fool to think that an early access game wouldn't be buggy.  I'm sure that all of the glitches/bugs will be gone in time.  Also, after you fly around for a while and you land, your sight radius dramatically shrinks.  Sometimes, I can only see about 10 blocks in front of me, and that's it until I restart.  Again, early access game.  It will get fixed in due time as with the efficiency of the servers.  One last thing:  I know that it's being built/programmed as I type this review, but as of this moment, fc is ENTIRELY single player.  PLEASE don't leave comments about how it's being made right now.  I'm just saying that if you're planning to buy it right now then be prepared to play ALONE.  Obviously, the pros outmatch the cons by a landslide, so I give this game a 2 thumbs up!  I can't wait to see how this game adapts and evolves!!!

content:
Posted: October 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game wasted so much time of my life but i can say it was worth it. I played it since early stages and seen it evolve and I can say that devs are really working hard to make this game aversome. There are of course bugs, but they not game breaking, and you can easly ignore them. What i feel playing only survival mode that it's Minecraft on steroids. You get building gun that has VERY long range, infinite world with no bottom and TONS of things to craft. And its not simply digging a few blocks and just making them into some items. You need to use machines to mine ore and coal, power it up and get ore to smelter to get bars for stuff to make. You need to research new machines and tools, and some research proyect requie several machines setup and TONS of power and metal to get.But the best thing about this game is building automation. You can set up a mine, connect to storage, to engine, load with coal and just come back for ore later. Or you can connect conveyor belts and your ore is transported to smelter, power mine from some sorts of power that is supplied by coal from other mines and your mine will work by itself until it runs out of ore. You can sort your materials, set up complicated structures and watch how its nicely work by itself.The only think that it's lacking is info how things work. You get short toturial, but basically you need to figure out how each machine works, and there are few dozens of different machines.This game is great. Maybe not perfect, but it's something I've been looking to play for a long time.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2015
												From the brief time I have played this game thus far it is a great game!It has a great concept and hopefully continues to evolve over the next few years as the developer hopes!The sad thing here though is that 'out-dated' negative reviews are killing this games progress as reviews do not expire as a game evolves.I think the review system on Steam is flawed in that respect as it does not retire reviews after a certain period of time, especially if the devs fix the issues, instead if a game has a rocky launch(as this did) it is forever doomed with that mark on its name, even if the dev fixes the issues.Looking at the negative reviews a lot of the negative reviews are from a long time ago before fixes etc and some things claimed by some users are no longer valid.That aside,Gameplay wise, this is a voxel technology/research game.You need to build systems to power your base, and research new technology to progress.If you enjoy tech mods in minecraft, this is definately worth a look.In my opinion it is very generously prices.. I have paid a LOT more for games I have played a lot less off.This being said, and I will update this review in a week or so after I clock up some more hours.For the time being, I love the concept and how the game plays and want to support it by adding a positive review!

								In a nutshell review, Early July 2015:Strong RecommendGameplay hours: at least 20+Beta version updates happening weekly or better - very activeDevs active online and taking feedback, adjusting bleeding edge beta almost dailyFor now, it is a mining game: you'll have the most fun if you enjoy building an industrial town/machine and gradually automate your mining operation.Depending on how much you like to tinker, there is at least 20+ hours to get to current endgame (quarry), but that can easily extend as you learn to use the various components to achieve certain things you thought couldn't be done. content:
Posted: January 8
												Starting to lose a lot of time to this game...  It's fun.First off, this isn't a clone of a well known game.  After researching this game I knew I wanted it.  Spent almost an entire night reading and watching videos for this game.  Happily, when I woke up the next morning, this game was on sale.  Immediately bought two copies: one for me and one for a good buddy.I am having some occassional issues with crashes, but mainly when I do something graphically intense, such as ping colored ores.  I have not yet even cared to try the DirextX9 workaround, because it really doesn't crash all that often.  And most times it does, it's after hours of gameplay and I just take a break anyways.The game is still being updated and bug fixed by the dev, which is good.Alright, I'll address the elephant in the room:  yes, it looks like Minecraft.  Yes, it's similar, in regards to you are a guy that can craft and make things and uses the world around him for resources.  However, it is so much more than a clone.  It's very much like a really good immersive mod for Minecraft with elements of HQM (hardcore quest mode) which add the purpose to the gameplay.  So, if you enjoy all those cool Feed The Beast and ForgeCraft/Tekkit mods/reworks for MC, you'll really enjoy this game.Automate all the things.

content:
Posted: April 25, 2014
												Update: Version: Patch 72 years later I am playing again and just have to change my review.This is now a really good game. You harvest, you have technoglogy and there is so much to do, I have yet no idea what IS the endgame. The settings for survival make it so, that you really can play 10 hours and are just starting to play this game.You gather resources to get more resources, that is still true. But now you get so much info in game, you really don't need a wiki or forum for a long time.You get a super cool elevator, so you don't have to walk all the way up and down.Everything is simple to use but but you have to think about it how to use it best.The game is just pure fun.I was always looking for a Tekkit-Lite (MineCraft mod with technology) alternative. This might just be it.I love it, that the destroying of blocks is so easy, that the building is so easy, that you have no "realistic" ground where you always fight to get it nice looking. Here you work with cubes in MineCraft size, the difference is, everything is fast and looks good and there is so much to do.What I saw and what makes me wanne play a lot more but I  don't have the resources for it yet:- Defense turrets- Spiders- Threat scanner- Power storage- [...] (I have researched not much yet)And this is just the beginning. This game is now so good.If you like MineCraft-like games, then this is a must have.Really, this is not anymore a nice-to-have, this is a must have!------------------------------------------------------------ old -------------------------------------------------------------------old: version 1.80dMine to be able to mine moreFortressCraft Evolved is a nice game.I did for sure not see everything about it, but I tried survival, did many things the wrong way,got LOTS of help in the forum (1 troll, but lots of nice helpful guys) and had lots of fun and frustation.I have to say, the frustration came from me reading the guide, which is a kind of tutorial, wrongly.I was just to stupid to understand the guide correctly.Nevertheless, that WAS my experience and it WAS frustrating.You are in a cold environment and your armor can only keep you a living being if you give it energy.That is easy enough, because you have a starting base.Then you start to gather ores to smelt them into ingots to create thingies which help you to gather more ore.That is it, it seems, for now.In the internal version (like betas for other games, via Properties-beta) you can get a newer, perhaps less stable version of the game with more features and bug fixes and new bugs.Perhaps the game has a target, perhaps you can have lots of fun, but I did not come to that point.This is an alpha version.And it is currently already fun to play.Building is REALLY fun!The game is easy to play, you can have some fun.I really hope for it to get "faster" or just telling a new user like me better, why he should bother to gather more ores to be able to create machine which allow him to gather more ores.But currently it is just not enough to keep me playing.I will for sure start it from time to time, because it is even in the alpha state fun to play it a bit.But it is for me no 24/7 game. By far not.If you are bored with your current open world building, mining, crafting game, give this one a try.It is not yet very good, but already good enough to be fun for minecraft fans.

content:
Posted: September 18, 2016
												PROS-Has a good chain of progression, so you can't just build the best stuff right away.-There is always something to do, usually a long list of things.-If you like building complex logistic networks of machines, you'll like it. It's funner than it sounds.-Spiderbot is awesome, buggy, but awesome.-The "Build to" function is incredibly usefulCONS-If you don't like building complex logistic networks of machines, you'll probably hate it.-It locks up a lot and needs to be restarted.  This happens at least once an hour.-AI is really stupid.-Lots of clipping issues.-There is no pause, so if your base is under heavy attack and you need to go to the bathroom, you can't pause the game.  You have to exit the game completely.-Help file doesn't give you nearly enough information.-Inventory sort by type option makes no sense at all.  If I sort by TYPE, I would expect all of my ores to group together, all of my bug parts to group together, all of my machines to group together, but it just seems like the sorting is very random.-The organization of the crafting menu is very odd. It desperately needs a search feature.-As you progress, the game gets buggier and buggier until large chunks of the level just won't load at all no matter how long you wait.  At this point the game becomes unplayable, which is really frustrating since I was getting close to beating the game.OVERALL IMPRESSION-Overall I really enjoy the game, however I wouldn't recommend buying it until the bugs are fixed.REQUESTS-I would like to see hostile monsters in the underground caverns to make exploration more exciting.-Lower the volume of the power storage cubes by at least 50%. That constant hum gets annoying after a while.-Make the smaller enemies attack you if you get near them.-Make it so you can delete the ship wreckage, maybe with the level 2 build gun.

number of helpful: 16 of 21 people (76%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 31, 2016
												This game isn't for everyone, that's a fact. The game is mostly about resource gathering, processing said resources and the infrastructure between. The game is slowpaced, it WILL take time before you have everything set up as you like it and even then you are very likely to rebuild it later as you figure out better ways to do things. It will require quite a bit of thinking ahead and possibly a few world restarts once you reach a point in your current world where rebuilding everything is just too much of a hassle. Each restart will be much easier than the last though as you learn more tricks. What took you 2 hours before, may now take 30 min and when you have played for quite a while not even that long. The time it takes to do stuff is usually down to player skill, be patient and you will get a lot from it.If you do decide to stick around for the first 10 hours, you are very likely to play at least a 100, and that is without the DLC Frozen Factory (have a look at the positive reviews, most have well over a hundred hours play and still haven't run out of content). For 13 euros this game is definitly a bargain.A common complaint about this game is that it feels like Early Access with all the updates. Do note that the game has had a working end goal for well over a year and hence can be considered complete. The larger part of each update is also available for free, no paywall here unless you've already spent said 100 hours and want at least 50 more. There are a few bugs, but hey, you just spent a dinner for two and the bugs will disappear at the end of the month.And lastly as I said this game may turn you off quite quickly, please have a look at lets plays before you consider buying and if you do, you won't regret it.

												Wow, where to begin with this game. Let me first start with my opinion. I love this game. However, I can not recomend it as of yet. I spent 24 hours fo game time as of the time I've written this, and I still don't really have a clue what's going on. It's advertised as a tower defense mincraft clone, but I've never played minecraft, so I'm not really sure if it is. I really like the idea of having to dig to find minerals, the blocks you can remove, the things you can research, but I don't like having to search outside the game or go through a million other steps to get a general idea of what I should be doing.Let's start off with the 10 second tutorial. It sucks so bad, after the first time I booted the game up and watched the unskippable (in this day and age, really?!) opening scene, I had no real idea of what to do or how. Sure, there is a help menu that gradually fills up with more information as you need it, but isn't the point of the tutorial to teach you what you need to know? There's no real explination of day or night, no real explination of what you can craft, and nothing tells you what you're research unlocks until you've already researched it.Now the community is great, and all the answers can be found someplace, but to me, that takes time away from the game. It's advertised as a tower defense, but it's more like a base defense, eventually. I'm not going to get into the nitty gritty, but this game needs a ton of polish before I can actually recommend it to anyone. The learning curve is HUGE in this game, and I'm still finding things out the more I play, but if that's your thing, feel free.Update: With the new patch that came out, I truly do love this game more. I still can't recommend it though until it does some serious polishing. No game ever should keep basic things away from the player, and that level of transparency is exactly what this games lacks. It's also unbelievably slow. I've been playing for days and there are still things that are hidden from me and I have no idea what they do until I actually spend the 5-6 hours unlocking it. As a player, it's truly the only reason I keep this game thumbs down.

number of helpful: 12 of 14 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								After 150+ hours I think I can say : this is a great game! I am a veteran of Minecraft, FTB, MITE and various other custom maps and challenges particularly in survival mode. FCE is similar, but different, to all of these and is centered around your base. You get most of the tools you need from the beginning, and from there it is up to you to build your base around the ore you find, and to automate it. Automation is really cool - you can do things the hard way, yourself, or build a conveyer belt and laser power and it does it all for you! You can just stand there and watch it go, and I often do! After a while you will have to deal with mobs too, so base defences come into play. There is a tech-tree for you to discover which unlocks a lot more of the game, and the "limits" are not what you are used to - there is no bedrock, you can just keep going and going. Super-dig and build-to-me features are "wow" as is the x-ray vision mode, grappling hook and jetpack.You might think that after all those hours I have done everything there is to do in this game. Well, I have played out a few worlds but no, I still have plenty of things I want to try.Even though there is Witcher III and Fallout 4 (coming), I'm already calling this my "game of the year". Stick with it and you will find it great fun. Sure, it is still in "early access" but this is already better than a lot of fully released games. What are you waiting for? get it now!ps. I am in no way affiliated with the devs, I am purely a player.

												I highly recommend this game because it has so much going on and does everything well. You are given just want you need at each stage of the game to work on building up your base toward the next tier of tech. And then on to the next tier. And so on. number of helpful: 30 of 49 people (61%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 8, 2016
												Slow, tedious, not worth your time.Does the idea of taking 6+ hours to achive even basic automation which you could accomplish in Factorio or modded Minecraft in under 30 minutes appeal to you? How about 2 hours to be able to safely explore away from your base for more than 5 minutes at a time? And that's in what this game calls easy mode - "Casual" mode it literally say is for people with jobs and families. (Who is the target audience, then?)Every upgrade and machine will cost more resources than it should, and perform below expectations. The game's basic generator can only function in the shallowest biomes (not enough oxygen deeper apparently), and even then it will decline to near 0% efficiency before you reach the next layer. Said layer will freeze you to death in under a minute until you build a suit upgrade... using ore from the layer below it. Everything about the gameplay feels like it's punishing the player.Apart from the mindbogglingly slow gameplay: The graphics are generally unappealing - it tries 'realistic' textures which don't look good in voxel games in my opinion, but I will acknowledge that's subjective. The surface is ugly as sin - you will never go exploring looking for a pretty place to build an outpost, because none exist. The 3d models are passable for an indie game. Animation is barebones.The sound design is decent, the effects get the job done, some of the (brief and intermittent) background music is nice.I didn't notice any bugs whatsoever, so good job on that.Much of the flavor text in item descriptions includes the author's attempts at forced humor, which I found grating.I actively played this game for about 15 hours, with several more afk idling while waiting for automation to process materials. I did my best to give this game a chance, I kept waiting for it to become fun, and it just never did.If you're one of those GregTech-type masochists out there, you might enjoy this. (I don't understand that either, but to each their own.) Anyone else, avoid.
