content:
Posted: March 3, 2016
												Let's start by saying that this game is still being heavily developed despite being out of early access.   Some of the newer stuff doesn't have icons but besides that the game is basically 100% completable in what constitutes a pretty decent end-game that can take 50-100+ hours to get to, with additional difficulty settings for pretty good replayability.The game does a good job of combining a minecraft style sandbox with tower defense.  It takes some of the slow and annoying parts of minecraft and removes it and gives the player a lot of tools to assist them with common tasks such as building.  building 50 blocks in a straight line in survival mode is very convienent, not to mention no wait on breaking a block and protection mode from breaking multiblocks.  The grappling hook is quite fun to use and makes grappling up a verticle mining tunnel a lot of fun.  On my 4 year old computer the game runs smoothly even with a lot of stuff going on.  Overall when buying this game remember some developers wait until they have everything that they can possibly do to the game done with before exiting early access, this allows them to make excuses for whatever bugs are in the game.  This developer has done a great job at leaving early access and releasing a very stable main build along with a constantly updated bleeding edge build.  The game might not be as complete as some other games that have exited early access, but it is stable, there is a lot of fun things to do, and my biggest complaint about the game is that $12 is just way too cheap.  I would of gladly paid $20-$30 for it possibly $40

number of helpful: 14 of 20 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 20
												FortressCraft is an interesting concept, and I do enjoy solving the logistical puzzles the game creates, even the spelunking and tunneling was enjoyable in its own way, with the grappling hook adding a lot to the experience. I know base building is a niche sort of genre, but it's my niche and I enjoy it.Unfortunately, the negatives of the game heavily outweigh the positives. DEVELOPMENT: FortressCraft is incredibly graphically buggy, to the point that the engine itself seems broken. Lights and phantom outlines of things flash all over the screen, sometimes at random, sometimes continuously throughout the whole gameplay experience, and they do so with such glare and rapidity, that it will eventually give you a headache. DO NOT PLAY THIS GAME IF YOU ARE EPILEPTIC. SERIOUSLY. Whole sections of the map will often fail to load as you travel along it, leaving huge holes in the world that, while you do not fall through them, still impede progress because you cannot see the terrain you are walking on. (Also, if you build a block on top of yourself using a low ceiling, you can see through all of the walls.) Speaking of not loading, the most frustrating load failure comes from the overminds and the sandworms, which both kill you instantly and without warning if you come anywhere near them. I like playing most sandbox games on ironmode so there are consequences to my actions. It adds a sense of danger and suspense to the gameplay. But being randomly and instantly killed by a hazard that cannot be seen or anticipated is not shocking or suspenseful. It just sucks. Finally, if you play above simple graphics, even on a well built gaming rig, the game will gradually slow down over the course of an hour or so to the point where you will have to exit and re-enter to reasonably play it without killing yourself during a lag altered grappler jump. The game invariably freezes and then crashes out when you choose to exit, and triggers a windows forced shutdown box during archiving, every single time. It's a mess.GAME DESIGN: There are some great things here. The alien world, when it isn't bugging out and searing your retinas, feels very much like a dangerous, foreign environment. Random noises will occassionally cause you to twitch spin, but it is just creepy enough to get the blood flowing without crossing over into a darker genre. The sheer number of machine parts you are provided is fantastic. There are many, many different ways to go about building your supply lines and machines, and a decent number of hazards you have to find ways to work around. Also, the smart help menu, is a feature that should exist in literally every game of this genre. That kind of genius deserves a patent.However, the other aspects of the game are not as well fleshed out as the supply line/base building elements.The task of defending your base from attackers and eventually returning fire on the overmind gives a sense of purpose to the hours and hours of logistical puzzle solving and resource grinding, until you realize that the enemy never changes. It's a bunch of wasps that fly in a straight line and only shoot at the generator in your base. That's it. They don't shoot at you, they don't hit your defenses or the supply lines for your defenses. They fly in a straight line to the base, and shoot at the generator. In any setting except for the very highest difficulty, the cost for losing to their attack is roughly 30 seconds without power from that particular generator. Any machine not tied directly to the central generator experiences no consequence whatsoever, so there is basically zero consequence to losing to the attacking swarm and as a result, very little reason to defend against it. If you venture farther into the game, the wasps will eventually become larger wasps with more hp, but they'll still do exactly the same thing the smaller wasps do.Defending the base basically comes down to buying the same cannons, but with varying color and cost, and placing them along the straight line the wasps always travel on the way to your base. The primary tactical challenge to defense is figuring out how to keep the batteries charged on the cannons throughout the zerg wave. So much more could have been done with this aspect of the game in order to reach a much, much wider audience. As it stands, this is mostly a game about building machines that allow you to grind enough materials to build slightly more complex, and exponentially more expensive machines, for hours and hours, until you can build a really big and really expensive machine that ends the game.Unless, of course, you get insta-killed by an invisible pop-up sandworm that ignores your health and shields. Or walk up a hill and suddenly insta-die, because there is an unloaded, invisible overmind sitting on it. Or plummet to yet another insta-death in a mining shaft without any warning, because your grappler gun doesn't work properly at a certain depth underground.I respect and admire the effort that DJ and his team have put into the game, and I'm impressed by his responsiveness to fans of the game online, but the broken graphics and the lack of so many of the most important basic elements of game design (for the love of god, take out the warningless insta-death mechanics!) make it impossible to recommend this game.Sorry guys, it could have been great.

Early Access Review
								I love this game so very very much.I reckon if you are an older or experienced Minecraft/Technic player you will love this too.Right now it is in early access and as such there is a variety of things to be sorted but I have watched and dabbled in this over the years and its always been interesting. The Devs keep well on top of this game as well and there is no doubt they are serious about crafting a work of intricate design. The biggest draw right now, as an early access title, is the machinery. It is one of the focal points of the game and you can craft a variety of machines to do much of the mining, crafting and distribution of materials so you can research, mine and craft even more powerful machinery that takes increasing power to run meaning you will need to upgrade your power network to keep up with the demand of an ever growing base of machines. I like machines.There are still issues with the U.I. and there are gameplay mechanics not yet implimented but the Devs are attentive to their community and listen to suggestions. This is one early access title thats gonna go the distance.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2015
												A highly polished work in progress game that has consumed many enjoyable hours of my free time. Whilst this game may be sort of like minecraft, it has many defineing differences. Namely the ability to build factories to automate you resource gathering. Also turrets to defend your base and factories from varying types of enemies which as time progresses will be added open. As for the game itself can at times have a bit of a learning curve and be slow in progression at times, but once you figure stuff out it can be quite fun. They community is always happy to help to when you have any issues you need help with. There is also a goal to work towards in the end game instead of just hey I found diamonds in minecraft and built the strongest armour. Now what? In the future many more end game goals are planned to be added in and even building of space ships and space station is on the table as one of the possible future additions. The developers are very active too, provideing updates to the game at roughly every to the bleeding edge  branch 1.8 days - 1 week and and activly read their discussions on a day to day bases. All things said I look forward to many fun updates and hours of play from this game.

number of helpful: 10 of 13 people (77%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								TL;DR - If you want a finished, bug-free game don't buy it, if you like Minecraft-style games and don't mind waiting for new content and patches buy it. Frustrating at first, but already the developers have made it much better.I've never played Minecraft but have always wanted to, but when I went to their website and would have had to sign up for an account before I could even see how much the stupid game cost, I became annoyed. I read on another site it was $30 (which I'm not sure is true or not, regardless I became more annoyed). Lo and behold, that same day on the front page of Steam I see FortressCraft for $4. Needless to say I got it.The first hour was an incredibly frustrating experience because I had absolutely no idea what I was doing and the help menu wasn't helpful at all. Thankfully they have made it much more in-depth, so new users shouldn't have nearly as much trouble as I did. I read a guide and got into it, having quite a bit more fun even though finding ore was tough at first (they have also made this easier, using one key and scrolling to find the ping you want, whereas before there was a key combination for each ping type).Now that I'm getting my base set up and things automated, I'm having a lot of fun! It's always cool to see your progress so clearly.There are some bugs which is to be expected since it's an early-access game. Most annoying is that the x64 executable likes to go missing, so I've been playing with x32. There are infrequent crashes, and if you quit when anything is in your smelter the items get lost. Not a bug but slightly annoying when I first started playing: menus that don't completely work. Now that I know the features haven't been implemented it's fine, but before I was clicking and totally confused as to why nothing was happening.The roadmap the developers have is great, and they seem to be very active here on Steam. Nice to know they're listening! Things I would like to see added are some ideas or guides for power plants and things like that, more detailed graphics (though I'm fine playing with the current ones), and maybe trees that regrow themselves. That would be cool. Seeds and stuff would be neat too.Anyways, it's a great game and awesome for the price and all the stuff they have planned.

content:
Posted: September 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								(This is a long description, skip to the pros and cons below if you don't want to spend much time on my review)My initial impression of the game wasn't great, which was largely thanks to the greatest difference between stable and beta branches in a game I've ever seen.   Once I opted into the beta, and selected some easier difficulty options, I found a game that was somewhat similar to some of the tech mods for minecraft, but with far more depth and coherence.   But this game, unlike minecraft, or most other mining games for that matter, requires you to build infrastructure that mines and processes for you, rather than you mining yourself.   The early mining process requires you to locate a sutible ore vein, plop down a ore extracter on it, stick a storage hopper on it, and dump a bunch of power into it, and leave it for about 10 minuites before coming back, recharging it, and taking the ore to refine.However, every step of that process is automatable, from the very start of the game.   Progression gives you faster, more efficient ways to mine, and automate the mining devices, while encouraging you to dig deeper to get access to more valuable ores, to research and build more advanced and effective machines.Pros-Advancing tech keeps you building and modifying structures-Tower defense aspect adds mid and end game goals-Scanning and visual tools lets you quickly plan out the most efficent way to set up and debug structures-All the information needed to progress can be found in game, no immersion breaking forum trips needed-Large difficulty range-Multiplayer (Still buggy, will likely be improving with time)-EXPLOSIVES that you can make as powerful as you have power for (maybe not so great in multiplayer)Cons-Not much in the way of a wiki to look up information for optimizing setups, particularly base defense-Single threaded- hard to run unless your computer has relatively good single thread performance (I have an AMD 3.7 GHz processor, and I have to run it on a lower graphics setting to avoid framerate drops)-Mob difficulty tends to get grouped- if you want things to fight back, you also have to deal with ore eating mobs that spawn on your conveyers.-Falling too fast kills you, makes it somewhat hard to go down mineshafts, you have to spend a fair amount of time building and navigating stairwells or platforms-Some dead spots while waiting for materials to be mined or refined

number of helpful: 11 of 15 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												After finally charging the OET, I feel like I can write a bit about FCE. I nearly gave it a thumbs down, but I think, overall, it deserves a recommendation. Most say it's a combination of Factorio and Minecraft, but it largely reminds me of Power Towers, a TD custom map that involved defending your base with towers that needed to be routed power from power generators. I enjoyed the grand majority of my [thus-far] 150 hours in FCE, despite ignoring the missions most of the time and playing my own [undoubtedly slower] style. Even not on sale, it's easy to get your money's worth out of FCE, with plenty to see and do. If you don't like busywork, there's plenty of tools for automation to build a base limited only by your imagination [and PC specs]. My biggest complaint is lack of polish, including user customization; for example, the music is ofttimes just whistling tones, just begging to be turned down or off [there's no setting in the options to adjust only the music volume, nor a setting to disable music all of the time - it must be switched off every time you play] - just little things like this that drive home that this is an indie game that needs some more love around the edges. Dev seems to listen to the community and continues to add content [even as DLC - which costs more than the base game?!? - it's an excellent value]. In-Game handbook and wiki seem to be incomplete/out of date, but I think there's some focus on improving this coming up [why the official wiki doesn't have info built directly from in-game data beats me]. I only ever played single player, so no comments on MP.+Gameplay+Style+Fun factor+Value-Lack of polish and easy-to-find answers-Occasional community hostilityOverall: 8.5/10tl;dr: If you like base management, defense, mining, and don't mind indie quirkiness, there's no reason to not check out FCE. You could watch for a sale price, but it's well worth the everyday price.

number of helpful: 12 of 17 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								Wow. Just... Wow.Where to start? This is a really well thought out, high quality game that encourages players to take advantage of its in-depth building system to achieve levels of creativity not found in other craft games. Mixing exploration with creativity, the game world modes cater for just about any gamer. Survival mode is possibly the most interesting, feeling fresh and challenging to just about any gamer. Survival mode gives a subtle drive to the creative player, besides creating visually stunning environments.Other modes offer a more relaxed experience, with vareity to suit the player. All modes are customizable in terms of difficulty and resources, in order to create the most suitable game world for the player.Though in terms of fun, multiplayer is where it's at. Co-op mode is a blast and working alongside your buddies to create and delve is great. Visually the game blows most other craft games out of the water. The textures have a hand made, consistent quality not often seen in games today, and compliment the models considerably. The sheer level of effort put into the visuals is very noticable, and the torch light in underground areas is pretty cool, gives a real sense of exploration.The sound effects are great and the music is decent, complimenting gameplay. Listening to the ambient wintery wind howl as you dig and search for resources in survival mode is pretty awesome. Gives a real sense of being in the game.Best thing though? The deep building system. You can do all kinds of cool stuff like powering generators with coal or materials for equipment energy, check out objects to find their hidden secrets with your laser scanner, craft new gear with materials you find along the way. It has to be seen to be believed really.Sadly the game has had some slating in the past owing to early beta releases, though in comparison the game has gone leaps and bounds miles away from what it came from (and I hope past reviewers amend their posts.) and exceeded my expectations.Overall, the game is a great choice for craft game fans and players who want to dip their feet into the world of creative games. Highly recommended. 10/10

number of helpful: 12 of 17 people (71%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 4, 2015
												Disclaimer: A key was given to us by the developers to review the game.Hello everybody, Shaun Meyers (Kyo Akiara) here to bring you a short overview of our review for FortressCraft Evolved. If you'd like to read our full, in-depth review, you can find it here: http://www.universalgamingreviews.com/fortresscraft-evolved-overview-and-review/I've been watching FortressCraft Evolved evolve over the course of its development ever since we first previewed the game quite a long time ago and it's become an incredibly impressive and fun survival based game.I'm normally the type of person to avoid survival based games in truth but out of the many that we've previewed so far FortressCraft remains one of my favorites, with it's incrediblly massive world to explore, tons of craftable equipment and excellent gameplay, it's a joy to play.I will also say that the game requires an immense amount of time and patience to really get anywhere and since I lack the patience to create vast mining cities I found myself a bit bored after a while. This doesn't mean the game is bad however, it's just that I can't play a game for that long haha.Definitely a recommended title though and I enjoyed following its development from a relatively small Early Access title to what it has become now. Still much more to come I imagine, 8.6/10.

content:
Posted: May 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is great!  They give you a little survival guide that helps you figure out how to survive initially.  Without that there's no way I would've made it.  It's like minecraft with reasonable graphics and a fun space theme.  The worlds are huge, it's easy to get lost and fall down to somewhere far below your base, but that's what the grappling hooks for!I don't have too many hours into it yet, but so far I haven't seen many bugs.  Occasionally the blocks go transparent if you're standing too close, and the pause menu doesn't seem to actually pause anything.  If you're going to walk away from it for a while, make sure you quit to desktop.  That'll save your world and you won't come back to the game to find you've died and reloaded to a terrible place you were lost at two hours ago.  Can't wait til it's finished, but for a $5 alpha FC can't be beat!

												Don't play this game if you intend to keep a personal life. It will eat your time and devour your soul. You will start dreaming about conveyors and power distribution grids. Even at the full price, it's a bargain as the time spent/cost ratio is going to skyrocket. It is constantly under development with a major patch coming out each month and a testing branch to test out the newest feature before they're implemented in the main game (experimental so back up your worlds).Active forums with lots of experienced people who will help you out, no matter your problem.So stop wasting your time irl and waste it in this masterpiece of a logistics game.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								FortressCraft Evolved is not about building your house on an infinite voxel terrain but organising the vertical transportation of ores and power to develop your base. Luckily resources are plentiful as you'll need hundreds of thousands of ingots to accomplish your mission.As of version 1.19 FortressCraft Evolved is a fully-fledged logistic nightmare which will fulfill the most demanding OCD sufferer. You will find a mix of sandbox, management, research, tower defence and a little survival.ProjectorGames has been in overdrive for the last months to push the game out of Early Access, and as such you shouldn't take into account comments written before version 1.18. So many things have been added, among which a tiered research, mobs, a tutorial, and an easy mode to accelerate the otherwise challenging and lengthy beginning.If you like building long assembly lines and accumulate resources to build even more assembly lines, do yourself a favour and buy it.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								I bought this game because I loved Minecraft with the Buildcraft/Industrialcraft mods. Research and automation are the core progression of this game. As this game is in early access, it does need some polishing and bug squashing.So far (15hrs), I've found 2 bugs: A minor issue where I had to re-open a UI (such as an inventory screen) to get my cursor to work instead of mouse-look, and an issue in multiplayer where other players could not see my placed blocks. The multiplayer issue was annoying, but the devs are actively working on addessing multiplayer bugs in newer builds.FortressCraft appears to be built on Mono, instead of the resource heavy Java that Minecraft used. This means it runs in 64-bit, can be multiplatform, and runs very, very smoothly.

number of helpful: 9 of 12 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 7
												Basically Minecraft with techmods without all the weirdness that comes from Minecraft with techmods (pickaxe into nuclear reactor, what?).It is very addicting to automate everything, but this is not all. This game has also tower defense elements, as you have to protect your base and certain buildings from regular waves of enemies with turrets and proper logistics, to keep them working.Sadly the game also has some drawbacks. Especially the depth of the map is annoying. Just getting from T1 to T2 ores needs you to dig hundreds of blocks down which also means you then have to create ways to transport energy down, ressources up and a way for yourself to get fast up and down. And this game has actually four tiers. There are ways to make this easier, but those arrive quite late (e. g. a quarry that digs a 3x3 shaft down so you can immediately use a elevator).Also the tech tree is quite weird at times. For example, it takes hours till you are able to use mincarts and when you have them, you simply don't need them anymore.The game has also some technical issues. The UI is ugly as hell (and feels like it is done for a tiny resolution) and the draw distance is quite low. Also items on conveors are invisible regulary.Other than that it is a fine game if you like fiddling around with machines and automation. It is better than Minecraft with mods in that area.

content:
Posted: November 10, 2015
												WARNING...This game is so addictive you won't be able to stop....seriously....For a guy who owns 100+ games on steam with over 10,000 hrs of gameplay I am pleased to announce that this is probably one of the best survival games I have ever played.....This game doesn't allow you to travel to other planets like Empyrion, it doesnt allow you to travel to the nether like minecraft and it doesnt have mobs chasing you the whole time..... This game is an INDUSTRIAL oriented game, being an engineer makes it even more fun as I plan my production plan for a certain resource. You have questions like how many extractors I need?, how many conveyer belts per resource? should I create a line of robot arms to selectively pick my ores or should I seperate the belts? What  will my production be with one smelter....how about two...how about a hundred? What would the energy requirement be? Can I fullfill it or should I tech up?....and the list just goes on....Bottom line this game is huge, with thousands of mega projects that you can endorse that can keep you entertained for hundreds of hours.......(note: I just reset my account and I play offline quite often).This game is a must buy for anyone who loves survival games or even if you want to try one....this game is the way to go.For all the guys who write hateful reviews, just ♥♥♥♥ off you minecraft lovers.......This game is for big boys.11/10 Would repel a 100+ Wasp invasion with Arthur.

number of helpful: 11 of 16 people (69%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								I love this game so much! Sure it has some bugs and glitches but it is barely done! I want to go over the glitches and bugs before I get to the best parts first just in case someone wants to find out what the issues may be in the game. The glitches are quite bad sometimes and can seriously affect the gameplay, the glitches come at random moments, usually when you least expect it. We have the problem with not being in control any more, this happens a lot, it causes your player to just fly up into the sky when you press space bar, this can also make it impossible to float back down and usually I just turn the game off after that. We also have the copy and paste option, sometimes it leaves blue and green lights stuck on your walls, sometimes the wall has holes in it where the copy and paste didn't work properly. You've even got a glitch that makes you walk around when you don't want to and you have to just move to a block and wait until the player stops moving, then slowly tap on the 'W' key to make sure he/she doesn't do it again. There is also even on fastest graphics mode it can have a huge drop in frame rates quite rapidly. Don't let this scare you from buying this game.I think this game is a must have due to its great potential, there aren't a lot of blocks but they are still developing the game and once it is done I am hoping it will have a larger collection of different blocks and materials. It's also a really big world and plenty of worlds for you to make, the copy and paste functions is pure genius and will definantly help to build huge structures! The little robot that follows you is helpful to show what block you currently have and for some reason it looks kind of cute. I'm very serious when I say this game has huge potential! I hope that more people buy this game so they can get more money to develop it better and faster! If you're looking for a game of fun and adventure then this game is for you! If you don't mind the bugs and just get on with it then this is extremely fun, this is my own opinion though so don't take it all to heart. But if anyone wants to join me when they have finished constructing the multiplayer then please feel free to add me. I hope this game gets the recognition it deserves! I remember first playing it on the xbox and it was a really good experience, I felt like I was playing something so different to games like MineCraft and it was a new adventure for me and that is why this game brings back that good feeling of change in the sandbox gaming category.

number of helpful: 46 of 83 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								FortressCraft Evolved as its name implies is the evolution of the original installment FortressCraft that appeared on XBLIG in April 2011.  Taking advantage of the power of a modern PC with several times more RAM and processing power compared to that of the aging console, FC:E offers a more expansive world than ever before.The game builds upon its success from the console version by offering the best creative tools available in any vox game including:Superbuild - An interface to quickly build geometric structures of thousands of blocks to save time for the detail workPaint gun - Paint select blocks using nearly any color you could dreamDetail blocks - the micro blocks of the XBLIG version have returned with even more flexibility.  Choose from 2x2 - 8x8 blocks in your detail block design to add a finer touch to your world.  The PC version allows a nearly inexhaustible collection so you'll have plenty of options to add more detail to your world.Copy and paste - Take a unique design and reproduce it to fill in your world with color or simplify a large project by reducing it to a set of duplicable pieces by copying and pasting elements of your world.Build2me - Excellent for covering roofs, building bridges, or filling in gaps build2me allows you to place an entire line of blocks from your target all the way to your current location.High graphical fidelity  - Incredible texture resolution, whole array of shaders, and a lighting engine that must be seen to be believed makes an incredible project look that much better.All of these provide the player with the tools necessary to build beautiful constructions of a scale that until now has been unimaginable in a vox game.  In this regard it is a huge step forward from the console version.  As of the time of writing this review the primary missing feature from the creative toolbox is animating the detail blocks.  This feature has yet to return but remains on the roadmap so expect it to appear before the full release.  I highly recommend checking out some of the Top rated screenshots to see some of the incredible things players have built already using the engine.One of the most desired elements that I had waited on with the console version was the development of a survival oriented game to make the most of the engine.  That time has finally come as the survival mode has seen its public debut and with only a few weeks of development time it already shows promise for an entertaining experience that will last many, many hours.  The player is dropped into a world where the environment itself is hostile.  The early game has the player battling the cold by sustaining a supply of energy to power his high tech hazard suit to prevent freezing to death by hypothermia.  The suit also appears to be designed for heat, radiation, low oxygen levels, and toxic environments so expect to see a variety of hazards to face from the world itself.  As of the time of writing the cold is the only threat.  Although the suit can be heated up by standing on a torch there is no danger from heat yet.  It will attempt to consume energy to keep you cool however.The gameplay centers around the idea of your suit energy being your life and that venturing far from your main energy network is a great risk.  You'll spend much of your time developing a network of power distribution to your mining network which is driven by machines called extractors which collect ore from resource nodes albeit at a slow pace.  This process is slower than the player's own mining ability however it is more efficient and automated as long as you sustain the machines with energy.  Later on you gain the ability to make batteries to store power and provide it to your machines, lasers which are used to move power between batteries, a generator for burning coal to produce power, hoppers to collect the resources from the extractors, and robots to move items among the hoppers.  The end result is the complete automation of your mining operations and the ability to generate and move energy around your base of operations to keep everything alive and moving including yourself!A few other relevant bits about the mode: torches can be placed as a source of light and heat.  They serve as little beacons of safety in the harsh world.  The player is provided with a grappling hook to quickly climb from the depths as the world goes down many light years.  Surival mode currently only utilizes the first several hundred blocks down but will eventually stretch to several thousand meters underground.  The player has a handy ore/cave sensor which consumes a quarter of your suit energy but provides an indicator of the closest ore/cave from the player.  This removes some of the tedium associated with finding resources and just getting about underground.All of this is only after about a month of development.  There is already a list of planned features to expand upon the mode including suit upgrades such as increased energy storage, greater insulation from the cold, upgrades to the ore sensor to identify specific ore types, and more.  The first mob was added to the game which is a real treat.  The details of which I won't provide here as they are more fun to discover on your own. :)  He isn't much of a threat yet but I'm sure that will change as the tools necessary to combat him are added.  In the current state it takes several hours to proceed through the current tech tree and with additional features promising to fill out the game the survival mode is shaping up to be an incredibly entertaining experience that will be even more fun with friends given the natural scale of the game.It is now I should probably place a reminder here of the normal warnings of early access games.  This is an early access title so it isn't complete yet.  Among the features still missing that is probably most desirable is multiplayer.  It is on the roadmap and even in development right now.  The devs have the game roadmap[www.fortresscraft.com] including multiplayer progress on their website where you can keep track of progress if you don't wish to buy in immediately.  As mentioned above the animations are not available for detail blocks and survival mode is only a month into development.  Other areas that still need work include the menus where many options are still unavailable and do not use a mouse interface yet.  In the end I guess the question that matters most is: Is it worth it?  If you enjoyed the creative experience offered by the XBLIG version or are looking for a more powerful block builder than you can get with other PC titles then FC:E is already a must buy.  If the survival experience is more what you are after then the answer isn't as clear.  Although the game is progressing very quickly it is still far from complete and there are many features required to fill out the experience.  There is also a lot of bug fixing and optimization needed as so much is being thrown into the game so quickly.  If you absolutely must have the end result then it is worth buying now at the introductory rate which is said to be 40% of the final price and will increase with each major milestone.  If you still are unsure then be sure to check out the forums regularly as new patches are released multiple times a week with fixes and new content.  At the rate the game is currently moving it will be making a big name for itself in voxel gaming this year.

number of helpful: 14 of 22 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2015
												UPDATE for this review: Too many things have changed that I no longer play this game.  Not only was it the mobs, but it was also not being able to use generators where we wanted to.  You can have a generator in a game to provide power, but lasers were unfortunately more favored over generators for some reason.  One day, a game will come out, that will be a factory game, no mobs, and no BS, and that is the game I am looking for.  Full automation with no interruptions.In the end, no I do not recommend this game.  I have edited this review to show that I was 50/50 on my review, as a full recommendation for the game.  Now, I am 100% dead set, I DO NOT RECOMMEND THIS GAME.  I have been playing the game with no mob AI and have actually been loving it.  It's a nice change from playing Minecraft all day long.What I enjoy most about the game, is the fact that you need machines to gather resources, mainly your ores, and that you can use conveyor belts to move all your materials around.  I've worked a warehouse job where it was conveyor belt city almost, and one conveyor belt at this job, took 10 minutes to get the product from the machine to me, where I had to sort it with other packages.  So the game in it's current state is pretty wild.  So I recommend it based on how it's different from Minecraft, you can build and destroy blocks from almost any range, and how its got all this factory stuff.  I believe there are mods for Minecraft for factory, but I enjoy playing this game as it offers a much different feeling and gives a different look.Recent changes however will be approaching, and this is where I am undecided on a full recommendation.  Changes will be coming that will give the mobs an AI, meaning they can drain power or screw with your machines functioning unless you plop down turrets.  To begin, alot of items to build are very expensive, and that problem needs addressed.  Another recent change to the game was how generators work.  Before, you could use generators anywhere for power.  Now, generators will only work so far underground, then you are forced to use lasers.  My laser system is getting to be pretty crazy, trying to drag down as much power as I can, and it feels like a never ending battle to even be able to keep power running.  There have been recent game code fixes to the lasers in how they operate.  I personally dislike the lasers altogether, but I'm really trying to give them a chance.The other problem that I have, is that, I would love to just be able to operate a factory, with no interruptions, but that isn't going to be added as a seperate option.  A simple option to start a new game with no mobs, cannot or will not be included.  A few people have asked for this, but all have been given a "no this is not an option" answer.  The way indie games are made today, community input is helpful, and when that input is actually used in the game, that's even better, and I believe that indie developers should always keep an open mind about different things they can and cannot include.  What I'm saying is, if the game Minecraft can have a no mob option, come on, it really shouldn't be that hard for you to include it as well.  But I'm not saying that it needs to be included right away.  I'm just saying, it is an option, and it shouldn't be ruled out so quickly.  Once the game gets more closer to completion, then add in the option to turn off the mobs.  Personally, I'm not looking forward to the mobs in the game, because I was hoping to just run a factory.The more you cater to your players and fans of the game, the more they will see you in a better light.  Then, mix it up a bit and change something that players wouldn't feel is too game breaking, or that on a forum, you have ideas and can go over those ideas with your playerbase.  This happens already, but that transparency is what people want nowadays, and the developers have 100% transparency with their playerbase.It's really just the no mob thing.  Never entirely rule something out if it can be a possible option added in later on.  I play Minecraft so much, that I'm getting tired of mobs.  Which is why I have so much play time with this game.  It's pretty much you building and running a factory, but then here come the mobs.It's a good game, and if you like having to use machines to get things done, then you should get it.It is still in its early stages so it will be going through many changes I'm sure.EDIT:  So I'm not really sure what stage the game is in now, but my final ruling is: NO I DO NOT SUPPORT THIS GAME, AND NO, I DO NOT RECOMMEND THIS GAME.

number of helpful: 28 of 49 people (57%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 2, 2016
												This is hesitant negative review, the game does have a lot of potential and has provided nearly a 100 hours of fun game play despite a lot of short comings. And in that sense it's a good purchase. It has fairly unique feel to it and in the beginning the open world mantra of feel your way around to figure out how things work and what your goals are is a lot of fun.In this phase you can overlook a lot of little things, odd interface for dealing with inventories, an apparent disdain for chests to the point of letting you hold 1000's of bars in your inventory. No RPG like interface to hold upgrades for your character ( which are essentially armor upgrades ) so they just sit in your general inventory. Tons of little visual and animation glitches that don't affect the game play. Some odd sound choices like your power storage ( batteries ) making a lot more noise than your generators, which leads to the odd situation where when you run out of power and your generators power up , it suddenly gets quite. But at some point all of these little things start to get harder to overlook and the game starts to change from fun to a grind that will have you leaving it running in the background while you do other things.The big problem is near the end game, the design philosophy suddenly changes from one that provides fun and rewarding game play while designing your automation systems to one of forcing you into massive grinds. You are no longer automating for the joy of designing virtual machines or because you feel rewarded for doing so, but because the game forces a lot of pain on you if you don't.In the end I don't regret getting the game, I had a lot of fun with it for a good amount of time. I do regret getting the DLC and that's about the only recommendation I can make, make sure you complete the first part of game and are ok with how it plays in the end before committing to the DLC ( although in fairness even with the cost of the DLC it was a good value )

content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												9/10 For gameplay 100/10 for price. Game has infinite replay value and costs less base wise than most games like it by over half.Alright I started playing this game in early acces around patch 4. We are know on patch 10, beginning work on 11 soon. The game is fantastic. I found this game on the featured part of steam one day and thought, "Hey I like modded minecraft, this might be fun." I had never heard of games like factorio, but This game introduced me to that as well. Both of these games are similar and while  Voxel Games tend to be considered a minecraft copyright just due to popularity,  these are not that similar in gameplay. I consider this game to be much more mentally challenging than simple despite using a cube world generation (which actually makes the game much more enjoyable when compared to non-voxel games like Space engineers which does share some similarity to a vague extent with this game). The game starts you off with a nice tutorial introducing basic concepts. An ingame help entry is available for every block, machine, and item you see in the game. The game tests the players' ability to create well balanced logistics systems, mining operations using automated technology, and tower defense skills.I never understood what big meant in a voxel game till playing this one. Minecraft worlds are 256 blocks tall. This game's first cave systems is found at -256. World's currently include content that is fully implemented all the way to -2000 meters down. 10x the depth of minecraft and 100x the content. There are around 11 different resources that need to be automated and all of them come with unique challenges involving their logistical transport. some are so far down that cargo lift elevators are needed to move 1000s of items at a time from deep underground to the surface for smelting. The game takes the logistics fo factorio, the easy to grasp gameplay of minecraft, combines them into a 3d world, adds unique challenges and mobs, throws in a bit of towerdefense early game, and a VERY UNIQUE enemy later with the first DLC that adds literally the same amount of content as the base game alone. These all combine to create what has been one my favorite games of all time. It's still updated almost daily on the beta branches and a new patch adding tons of content comes to the stable mainline every month. The 800 hour reviews that don't recommend the game simply have salt with the developer who I have never had an issue with and I've given him proably 50 ideas that have been shot down with logical reasoning as to why they shouldn't or can't be implented. Love the game, love the devs, and love the cost. I honestly don't see any downsides, and the game comes with over 12 different difficulty combinations that you can use to fine-tune the challenge to your liking. 200 hours seems like a lot for a full playthrough? drop it to Casual mode and you can speed run the thing in around 40. It's not nearly as hard, but it's still extremely fun. And upon completion of the survival mode, alternative game modes are unlocked offering new challenges. There is so much content in this game and even if a few things here and there aren't everyones cup of tea, $13 is not something that anyone can complain about. Call of Duty and other AAA games offer less content for their respecitve genres, less community interaction, and most of all, MUCH less balancing of implemented features based on player feedback. Buy it. Just do it. Thank Me later. And if you honestly don't enjoy the game as much as everyone else does, then refund it and say "I tried something new and didn't give it an awful review on YELP" No harm, no foul.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2015
Building, automation, and explorationThe game just left Early Access, but it's far from being done. I mean that in a good way: The devs are committed to adding features as long as they can afford to.Your job in this game is to build a massive industrial complex to save yourself and escape the hostile planet you've crashed on. If you find yourself doing something tedious, there's probably a machine you can use to do it for you instead.Pros:Zillions of machines to automate your baseFun tower defense aspect can be ignored if you don't like itWorld size is basically unlimited. Dig as deep as you can!Good graphicsMultiplayerCreative mode allows construction of amazing thingsCons:Documentation is mediocre. (Used to be poor, so it's improving.) Best source of info is the Steam forum, which is disorganized because it's a forum.There are some rough spots in scaling your industrial output. There are no machines to gracefully handle thousands of resources. (But they're working on it.)Not much plot or story; if that's what you're looking for, it's not here.

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 8, 2016
												It's fantastic. Plain and simple. It's like someone played MineCraft and thought, "Well, this is pretty fun. What else can it do?" So they dug through mods and found Technic. Then they played that for a bit and thought, "This, too, is pretty fun. But it wasn't really made for this...I bet I could make something like this, but better." And so they did. Starting out can be rough, depending on your world. I tried a couple before I found one I was happy with. It will take time.The game is heavily based around automation, so you can continue to dig deeper and find new things, then automate those new things to get it all back to your base. At first, you will have to babysit things. You simply don't have the resources to get things rolling on their own for the first hour, maybe two. Watch a couple of videos on it. You'll see how others do things, you'll get a good understanding of the basics, and you'll have some ideas as to how to set your own system up. It takes a lot of time to really get a lot going on, but if building up to that isn't your cup of tea, then I might advise a different game type. There are several more mechanics at play here than in MineCraft, and pretty much any other game in this vein. It takes a lot of the concepts explored in Space Engineers, removes space, and instead focuses on mining materials and setting them up to work for you. Never played anything else quite like it. As of this writing, the devs have moved to a new engine and made several quality of life improvements. There are more updates coming, and the community that I've interacted with is outstanding. This is a prime example of an early access game taking full advantage of what gamers can bring to a development cycle.

content:
Posted: August 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game still has its bugs.Despite that, playing it is kind of soothing. I mostly play games like terraria, FTL and minecraft. I make a new review so that I can point out the positive pieces.Energy system, ores, ingots, intermediate building materials such as PCB:s, copper plates...It is a bit difficult to move far away from your home base since the power quickly drains. Besides that, I say it's a challenge. So far, I haven't got to the point where I think this game has "everything". The most bothersome challenge is moving far away from the home base and finding the resources that you need. Canalizing coal into the main hub is one of the most usual things that you will do in the beginning. This is done by hand (taking coal from a mining block into your infinite inventory space, then staying at the base until it has enough power).I imagine that a larger operation would take a lot of time. I sporadically play games with or without liking them, so I would usually not recommend this game because "bitterness". But I got into it a bit more by watching someone making a let's play on it. For example, the tutorial in the beginning was added with the latest patch. Before that, I had to watch the let's play in order to know what to do. Mostly, games like minecraft gain introduction level experience by being simple. As complexity adds to the time that you spend fumbling around, these "cellular automata" games almost require an intro course.I have no idea how to get the complexity that the game promotes by its videos. As usual, the actual gameplay is similar to any minecraft-like game. As usual, there is some difficulty getting to the point where you feel you've achieved something. Things like putting coal in the main hub will predate the point where you've found your first source of copper.Tips:X <--- changes to block breakerM <--- changes to block scanner/pingerL  <--- turns on lights (drains energy)The scanner is necessary to find the first piece of copper deep below ground.Right now, candles are extremely cheap (infinite power!) and craves coal which you get cheap in the beginning (most of the times)C <--- open crafting menu, where you can craft candles on the go

content:
Posted: August 31, 2016
												This game isn't for everyone, but oh man, if it turns out you're one of the people it IS for, then prepare to spend weeks of your life in this game.  Builders, perfectionists, architects & problem solvers - read on, this game is for you.You toil endlessly creating complex systems to do some work for you so you can go back to toiling endlessly, but with a goal to achieve.  Sounds like torture?  Skip it.  Sounds like fun?  Buy it.It's like Factorio got moved into MineCraft.  A 3D block environment where you dig and mine, but not to gather resources.  You dig and mine so that you can place down machines to gather the resources for you.  Then you build a transportation system to move those resources to your base to be turned into more machines.  So you can dig and mine deeper, to place more machines to gather more resources.  Thats the "Craft" piece of the game.The "Fortress" piece is about defending against the waves of attackers.  Fortress isn't really an apt desription, I'd say its more of a camp with a heart that you defend with craploads of guns.  Again, you don't do the defending so much as your machines do the defending for you.  Granted, the waves of attackers are a bit simplistic - very much like the waves in a tower defense game, they mindlessly hover toward the exit (in this case not an exit, but the core machine in your base).  If they reach it, they attack and you 'lose'.The game has several tiers, each reachable only by solving the previous tier; and a little bit of the tier itself that you're trying to reach.  Problematic enough to cause some frustration along with the satisfaction of having overcome that obstacle.  Several times as you try to get to the next tier, you find the machines you have access to come up a bit shy and you need to temporarily resort to doing things by hand again for the earliest parts of of 'leveling up' to the next tier.  How you go about solving it is all part of the fun, and there isn't just one right answer either.This sort of problem solving, improving and perfecting is found throughout the game.  For me, it was an everflowing cycle of frustrating problems and dopamine reward.  Like I said, it's not for everyone, but if it is for you, then easily expect triple digits of playtime next to FortressCraft on your Steam profile.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								If you've ever wondered if the Unity3D engine can do games like Minecraft, then this game answers that question. Its a port of a game that's been on consoles for some time now, and is still a work in progess so things are going to be pretty rough. Despite its shortcomings this game has a lot of potential to be serious competition for Minecraft, which up until now has had no real competition on the PC side.There are things that need to be fixed. You still get the Creative Mode item list in Survival Mode, making it hard to determine which blocks you have available, and you cannot use the mouse in your inventory screen. In fact, you can't use the mouse in any of the interfaces for the game except for the ESC button menu while in-game. This needs to be addressed, especially for this PC port of the game.As I said, this game has massive potential, so while its not quite ready yet if you buy the game now you're helping the developers out so they can finish it that much faster. So, while its very rough as an alpha this is one worth investing in.

content:
Posted: May 7, 2016
												It's like minecraft, but without all the boring♥♥♥♥♥♥Dear lord, this game is fun. It has all of the creative potential of minecraft, but automation removes all the boring negatives like manually mining and smelting and even building block by block. Instead of wasting time on that boring nonsense, FortressCraft Evolved allows you to focus on advancing your tech, building your base, and defeating your enemies! There are tons of awesome aspects of the tech aspect of this game, with my favorite being the ability to build blocks from a specified block to your location using control-click. AFAIK, minecraft doesn't let you do this. At least, it didn't back in the day when I played it. Also, this game has a grappling hook. Let me repeat that for you. THIS GAME HAS A GRAPPLING HOOK. AND YOU DON'T EVEN HAVE TO UNLOCK IT. There are multiple power source types for your machine, and your enemies (bees native to the world you're stranded on) provide you with valuable building materials. There's a lot of variety in every aspect of the game: building, smelting, mining, etc. Also, this game is gorgeous for what it is. I'm running it on an intel g3258 that I haven't gotten around to overclocking yet and an AMD r9 270 and it still runs decently on high-ish settings. And it works on linux! :DThere are a lot of complaints from earlier in the game's development about the creator abandoning the project. He came back, and has been consistently releasing updates since the beginning of the year. He's a bit snarky, but he's really fun to interact with, and he actually listens to player feedback. Basically, this game is everything an indy game should be. Fun, inventive, varied, cheap, and available across all platforms. What are you waiting for?? Buy it!

content:
Posted: August 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								I wish the Steam reviews rating system gave more "score" to reviews written after big updates because this game has developed so much in the latest releases... FE does'nt deserve the Mixed rating, is so much better than that. Sure, it's still rough around the edges and has still many (non game-breaking) little bugs, but the developer is very active and patching and updating the game constantly so that you can solve little problems in as short as a few days span.Now about the game:- Minecraft inspired (blocky world and such)- Story driven: you crash on a planet with your ship and only have some basic stuff to survive and your final goal is to find a way to go back out there where you came from- Creative mode too (with much more stuff than survival mode)- Most of the game is about setting up a mining operation and get the necessary resources/ores to finally build the stuff you need to leave the planet (game end)- Mobs / Tower defence mode has been introduced: so while building/exploring the alien planet you also need to fight and/or setup defences depending on how much you get noticed by the local aliens- There are "Hive Minds"! O_o- If you like crafting and building automated stuff this is the game for you!- This is mainly a single player game IMO but they put in a multiplayer mode too (I don't use it) which is a bit awkward to setup, but they're still improving itSo basically my tip is to go buy it!If you're not convinced by now then just wait for the next sale and grab it, IMO you won't regret it.

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
												Similar to minecraft, in that it is a block based, 1m x 1m x 1m type game. The similarities disappear shortly after that. The build gun is an amazing tool for building or removing blocks at long range and is capable of building large platforms or walls very quickly. Most of the game is based on automation of resources or manufacturing, similar to Factorio. The game play in single player seems to flow through 3 distinct types of gameplay: you start off in a survival game, fighting the elements and trying to just manage; mid-game is filled with automation of all sorts, from power generation and transport, to quarrying, refining materials you obtain, and auto-crafting items; end-game is similar to a tower defense game, fighting hordes of enemies, trying to keep them from destroying your Central Power Hub and resetting the charge on your end-game structure. I thoroughly enjoy it, and can easily say that it's worth the full price.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												First up, I have 183 hours playing this game so far, it's by far my favourite block game there has been so far.If you enjoyed modding Minecraft with things like machines and power, then this is basically that done properly.For anyone thinking or expecting a Minecraft clone however - it's far far from Minecraft's gameplay.The immense fun in this game comes from building bigger and bigger..  More power required, more ore required.. More, more, MORE!  You always want and need more!  But that's a balanced gradual process and before long you have a sprawling power network powering deep mines and a massive turret network on the surface to defend against the planet's creatures' attacks which ramp up and up as you grow.It's constantly being developed (sometimes 3-4 patches a day on the bleeding edge line) and the main dev is fantastic and very active on the steam forum, always listening to and answering comments.If a bad bug is spotted it's usually fixed that day, sometimes within the hour even.  I wish all games had development this great.TL;DR..Buy it now.

content:
Posted: March 16, 2016
												As it is now, I can't reccomend this game. It's hard even on the 'easy' settings to do anything really. With the combonation of heat/cold, energy storage of your suit only one begginer smelter and a whole lot of things early game take way too long! It is a time sink that is in my opinion far worse than other 'builder' games. I will compare to one that most everyone should know: Minecraft.Comparing Minecraft to Fortresscraft*You can easily build multiple smelters right from the start really/ Fortresscraft you may finally unlock a basic smelter after a few hours play.*Ores are generally spawned with more of a pattern/ Fortresscraft is more luck based. Meaning it may take a few hours to even build the basics.*You already know all crafting, you just need the proper tool/ Fortresscraft you need to scan almost everything, and research it. Use the researcher to gain building rights. Making the beginning game so long and tedious.These are just a few issues I have.One could argue: Recode the recipes in the data files. I shouldn't have to. One could say use creative mode. Then I lose out on needing anything and lose on battling enemies. Plus you don't get all the energy stuff or anything. Or none that I could see.I wish there was a kind of hybrid creative/ survival mode. Kind of like how you can switch between the modes in Minecraft with commands. And the creative mode in Fortresscraft had ALL the blocks plus being able to battle enemies should you choose to.So unless you have hours to sit down and figure this game out, don't expect anything to be built quickly. As it is, I can't reccomend it. Maybe it's not for me since I don't have hours and hours to sink into it to find everything and such. Which is why I like Minecraft better. If you want something that does similar to this but qucker, Try Factorio. You can even cheat if you wish, and I don't feel cheating ruined the game for me on that as I still do a lot.It has potential. I love the idea of having a factory with belts/ transporters, and building a defensive base and all that. So I WILL check in on this game from time to time as I do like the ideas. It just needs to be a little more open I guess you could say. Allow us to do what we want, if we wish to speed things up some allow commands to do so or something. I'll keep watching it for updates and such and may update my review at a later date.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2016
												FortressCraft Evolved! scratched all the itches I had playing other sandbox games. I don't care about survival and crafting; that isn't what this game is about. It is about exploring and designing your own systems and gradually opening up more options to make things more efficient. Constant revisioning and redesigning my systems is the best thing about it. The search for efficiency is my motivator throughout. I like playing this game in an information vacuum because I don't care how the other players are doing it; I want to work through it on my own.With the nature of the development there is a fair bit of jank in the game but it is coherent enough to let me forget it after I learned the basics. It is a hard sell to friends that are used to very complete tutorials. This is not a game that holds your hand and it expects you to do some research on your own. I'm fine with that because it is a good game. Any less and it would have sat in my back log.Finally, you can really tell the game is a labor of love and if I were the developer, I would be very, very proud of this achievement.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								First impressions: http://www.cublikefoot.com/fortresscraft-evolved-first-impressions/Note: These are my first impressions based off of my first play sessionFortresscraft was first released in 2011, on the Xbox 360 and went on to become one of the most downloaded Xbox Arcade games ever. Fortresscraft Evolved is a complete remake of the original Fortresscraft in the Unity engine and was released on Steam Dec 10, 2013.A lot of people will go ahead and compare this game to Minecraft and, while it does share some similarities with my all-time favorite game, it is actually quite different, especially in terms of creative building. There is a survival mode in the game, but when I tried to start a new world with it, I was placed in creative mode. No idea why that happened.The creative mechanics in the game are fantastic. There are many features that make building a lot easier than what you'd probably expect from a game like this (try shift+left clicking with a block in hand). I was even able to whip up a quick tree house in about 30 seconds, and this was no ordinary tree house, it was massive. I really love what the devs did to make creative building as painless as possible.The game does have some technical issues however, with the game sound being my major complaint. They seemed to lag behind. Oh, and is there supposed to be game music? I heard some at one point, but, other than that, it appears to be nonexistent.Anyways, the game is fun, if you know what you're doing. The survival mode, however, simply is not as fun as I had expected it to be. Recommended purely for its creative capabilities!

number of helpful: 10 of 16 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 18, 2016
												After a relatively short scene-setting intro and a very quick tutorial, FortressCraft Evolved has handed you the basics and expects you to get on with it, which is a refreshing change from too many games with 20 minute pause-button press-pause tutorials that seem to be the trend recently.That said, the tutorial does give you the basics of how to figure everything else out for yourself with fairly extensive in-game help and tooltips, so with a bit of trial and error along the way, for which the game imposes no penalties on the easy difficulty settings (my personal recommendation until you know what you're doing), you soon get into the swing of it. Automation is a major part of the game, and your strategy of implementing this will heavily determine the pace of the game. Want it to go faster? Simply increase whatever factor is limiting your progress, be it power, materials, or machine throughput. Just as you're getting the hang of all this, you'll come across the Threat Analyser and probably end up building one out of curiosity. This will warn you of incoming attacks and keep you informed as to how much attention your base is drawing from the native life forms. Very useful in determining when you really need to change your focus to building defences against said life forms, but again on the easier settings the only penalty for failure is that it temporarily stops your source of comepletely free power.I've restarted this game several times now, because after developing my base setup a certain way I get further then come up with a better way to do things, which would almost certainly be easier if I did it from the very beginning. The fact that this game can still cause such epiphanies is to me a mark of a very well thought out game indeed.  That said, I could just tear it all apart with no penalty, and rebuild, but I prefer a clean slate.The game is undergoiong continual development on a daily basis. This does not mean that the game is unfinished, having watched the developer's daily live streams of the work being done I can say that it if the game had stayed in Early Access until he ran out of ideas and had implemented all the current thoughts he has for late-game content, it would still be Early Access ten years from now, and the game already far surpasses many titles that I've seen launched from EA.It's true that the developer is planning explansion packs as a way to introduce large chunks of extra content to the game, and a lot of people have slammed this decision, despite the fact that he has clearly said that if he can afford to do so, these will be free expansion packs rather than paid.  Given how many games are released in an almost episodic fashion these days, this is by no means unreasonable, especially given the exceptional value for money the FCE represents. How many games can give hundreds of hours of enjoyment for £10? At this price give it a try, it's a steal and if you enjoy any kind of tower defence, voxel building, crafting, gathering or logistics/assembly line games you should have a blast.Tl/dr: A great game that keeps getting better.

number of helpful: 13 of 22 people (59%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												Sometimes I really wish that there would be more options when reviewing, but I just can't recommend this game. Not because it's a bad one but because of the sheer amount of wasted potential which is very disappointing. The game is pretty much the work of a single dev who cares for his game and puts a lot of time and effort into the development. Unfortunately all of that falls short because of the poor execution. FortressCraft Evolved is a great example why you can't develop a game on your own after it reached a certain level of complexity and player base. The dev is no doubt a skilful coder but less talented in the other aspects of game making. FortressCraft desperately needs a texture+model artist, ui programmer, and sound designer. Right now the game is completely out of balance. The poor visuals are overcompensated with needlessly high poly models and excessive lights. The game takes advantage of the engine's most cutting edge features yet you can't turn the music off or go back to the main menu once you've started playing. Distant blocks fly in with fancy animations but the machines right in front of the player are still popping in and out regardless of the graphical settings. These and many other issues lend the game an unpolished feel and greatly hold back it's success.Off course you can find people with insane in-game hours who just love it, but you have to keep in mind that the gameplay is heavily inflated. Early game is especially slow, all you do is wait on resources. I have 200+ hours in offline play but I was afk half the time - shopping, cooking or watching TV while the ores were mined and smelted. Every attempt I made to finish the game ended with abandoning the map after 15-20 hours, I always loose interest. To make matters worse there aren't any explanations how the dev intended the machines to be used, figuring out the right setup is almost impossible, you just don't have enough information about the blocks. You have to watch countless hours of Youtube videos in order to avoid frustration. Sadly giving feedback about your issues or interacting with the community in general is not a good idea. The game is surrounded with a ring of diehard fans who are unreasonable and the developer himself can be very unprofessional.A lot of reviews are complaining about the DLC but I'm OK with it. It has one of the worst marketing I've ever seen in my life which makes it appear as another greedy cash grab attempt, but actually adds a fair amount of content for a reasonable price. It's a good way to keep the dev motivated as I still hope that my issues with the game will be addressed one day.FortressCraft Evolved could be one of the best games this genre has to offer. It could be an excellent game to introduce new players to "blocky" games while still challenging veteran players. Unfortunately in it's current state the game is totally unappealing. If you are a hardcore fan of the genre you will be able to overlook the numerous shortcomings otherwise stay clear, FortressCraft will yield you nothing but anger and frustration.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 8, 2016
												Well... This will be complicated.First off, full disclosure: I recieved this game from the Dev after expressing my doubts and disbelief on the forums. The topic can be found here: http://steamcommunity.com/app/254200/discussions/0/528398719792747294/And on to the review itself...Fortresscraft is something I have difficulty playing objectively. I snagged the original back when I was a gamer on the Xbox 360 before switching to PC, and I was not impressed. It was a 'Minecraft clone', in the sense that it was blocky and HD and there was not much value in it other than blowing up the water and watching the broken physics for it cause it to spread across the entire world, but only after you had reloaded the level.Upon seeing this title on Steam, I was, understandably, not impressed. So, after downloading the Dev-given game and booting it up, I found a few things out.First, the game has some derps and issues. The tutorial can be confusing and derped at times, leaving you with little idea of what to do. I have heard there's a wiki up at this point, but there was not one when I started.You enter with little idea of how to do things, which can honestly be great. I've played Dwarf Fortress with less. Still, however, it's not a great introduction.Further on, I can see hints that this is something that I might enjoy and thrive in if I could only get it, for lack of a better word. It's not that the game is complex, it's that I just can't figure out where to go, after a bit. So many things that would really improve things for me are either missing, or I am not finding them.I know, and I can see, that this is really a good game, especially where it came from. I did have a bit of fun, and the mechanics are mostly solid, but I just couldn't get very far.Overall, the reason this is 'recommended' is because, in the end, I know it's a good game. It just isn't my type of game. I'll stick with my complex RTS addiction for my fix.In numbers: 6/10. Above average, at least. Steam really needs a 'mixed' review setting.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
												The game has recived a lot of free updates past release (in addition to a paid DLC/Expansion).Update 16 which came out a few days ago added a full overhaul of the game for beginners by adding a nice tutorial which starts the player on the right path to automation.It also adds missions to guide the player in his progress through the game.I've just returned to playing the game again after several months of playing other games and I'm impressed by all the work that's been put into this game since last I played.Still very much an enjoyable game with a very active and helpful comunity.--I love this game.The dev's are very active on the forums and updates to the bleeding edge happens frequently.And by active I mean he's actually reading and responding to threads on the forums.Even helped me out with my mynock problems x)Edit: After many more hours of playing I still LOVE the game.This is my reply to a question of "Is the game worth it?`" asked on the forums now when I've had about 80hrs of gameplay underneath my belt:YES!Now let me elaborate:I loved Minecraft, especially along with Buildcraft, Industrial Craft etc.I also enjoyed Factorio and other similar games.And I absolutely LOVE this game!// Rambling startI've played about 80hrs now and still having a blast!The developer is really active and working hard, his plans for the future seems (in my opinion anyways) awesome and so does his attitude.In it's current state I already do love the game. I would easily spend another 80hrs or more on this game in it's present state without any updates. With the updates then I expect that number to grow to insane amounts :=)Speaking of updates, you can either play on the regular early access branch or you can opt into testing the latest freshes code. The latter will crash and break so you'd HAVE TO MAKE BACKUPS (DAILY!) , but you would get frequent updates and get to test everything as soon as it's coded!Awesome!If you'd rather want things a bit more stable then don't opt into the Bleeding edge and you will be fine. Keep in mind however that this game is under developement and it's NOT a AAA+ development team behind it, but some indie dev which means this a true early access game.If you can't stand work in progress games, then you'd better wait untill it's more polished and done before you jump in :P// Rambling endTL;DRI've spent around 80hrs and will probably spend another 80 in it's current state (without any of the updates) which means it's worth EVERY CENT I've paid for it already!10/10 from me.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 12
												Fortresscraft Evolved is similar to the major tech mods for FeedTheBeast, with an emphasis on defending your factory from waves of enemies.  The graphics in FCE are good, but you can still play with an older PC - I'm using a GTX 650 and it's fine on medium settings.  There are many features that make it easy to build large structures - cosmetic and functional.  The Frozen Factory DLC is highly recommended - it adds a significant amount of content to the game.  The difficulty settings focus mostly on "how much time do you want to grind away", so if you are a busy person, you can still enjoy the full content of the game without "grinding."  The game is more about building, planning, and some exploration - it's not as action-oriented as FTB.  In fact, the monsters mostly ignore you in FCE - the monsters are all trying to attack the center of your factory.Summary:   If you enjoy tech mods for minecraft, check out Fortresscraft Evolved.
