number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 17, 2016
												This game will either be really fun, or rather boring depending on what type of games you like. If you like building complex machinery chains to automate everything then this will be a good game for you. If you like fast paced, action games... This probably will not be your cup of tea. That being said lets go over some of my thoughts on this gameThings that I like about this game. Self contained machinery, automation, building, and resource gathering that plays much like a minecraft modpack based around a single tech mod. The graphics, while based around cubes for the terrain, is actually pretty good. It has vastly improved since I got this game a year+ ago. Caving is just fun in this game. There are massive cave systems that put other digger/builder games like minecraft to shame. Example, there is a cave with a ravine right next to my starting base that is almost deeper than the entirety of the building area minecraft allows (at least vertically). Things I dislike/are Meh aboutSome aspects of the game are rather grindy, even on the "fast" paced version. Ore collection and smelting takes time, and as you get later into the progression tree you unlock things to speed this up. Unfortunatly the cost to create everything also gets pretty high. Energy production is really small unless you are playing on the fast version, Solar panels are almost worthless unless you choose to have eternal day.The "expected" time to reach the endgame (OET) is not bad, but the charge time is really long. Although this gives you a good reason to make a well fortified base!Overall those detractor points are rather insignificant to me, as they just extend the time until I "beat" the game and then get bored. Heck.... I haven't even gotten to the end game yet and I'm almost 50 hours in! This game is well worth the money to me and DjArcas is great developer that is active within the community!

												Although the game has a great design, has deep gameplay and shows a lot of promise, I cannot recommend it in its current state. It currently makes an unpolished and buggy impression, which may be acceptable for an early access game, but not for a game that has been officially released.For example, it took me several hours just to get my interface working. It turns out that the game seems to assume a 16:9 aspect ratio of your monitor. When I tried to load the game with my monitor's native resolution, which has a 4:3 aspect ratio, the interface was completely buggy. For example, windows were overlapping that were not supposed to, so that I could not see the entire interface. The game does not provide any warning when selecting an unsupported resolution.Other bugs that I have encountered include items on conveyor belts not being rendered at all under certain conditions (thereby making them invisible) and turrets not firing at the enemy, but instead making jittery movements. Also, I have encountered several bugs in the user interface. Additionally, the game crashes frequently when doing certain things, such as scanning for ore.Because this game has a great design and shows a lot of promise, I hope that the developer will fix these issues. Afterwards, I will gladly change my rating to a positive one.Meanwhile, if you are interested in resource management games with complex assembly lines, I would recommend buying the game Factorio instead. Even though it is officially still in early access, it is already a lot more polished than FortressCraft. However, the main disadvantage of Factorio is that you are limited to two dimensions (i.e. the surface of the planet), whereas in FortressCraft you can also build in the third dimension, digging deep into the planet.

												Good luck scouring forums for any sort of help at all. I advise to steer clear of the developer because he will just be sarcastic and rude with all his advice and assume you have been watching his twitch for months on end and that you have to know by now what each research unlocks and how to build some of the more complex setups that he cant be bothered to write in the help menu inside the game. after a few months i returned to the game saw some updates and progress and started a new world only to find much of the research had been jumbled up a bit. not a huge issue but when i had asked the dev where certain things were he just said "its in the help menu" well the item was in the help menu but all it told me is what is crafted with the item not how to craft it or unlock it in research... he swore up and down that it wasnt in the lab and that it was researched early on ingame. it was in fact in the lab and using the lab is a hit or miss on getting what you want unless you search the forums....searching forums would be great and dandy but the information is not always current like i said he moves things around changes where they go which means an old topic could tell you to research something entirely different and researching in the lab isnt an easy thing that takes a little power and a few moments.-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-until the ingame help menus actually give helpful information i cant reccomend anyone buy this game and put up with this cranky developer. its still a fun and interesting game and i will continue to play but i cant advise anyone to pay full price for this game. pick it up on sale or spend your money on a better game, also the early rush from EA was a bad move and its really not ready to be sold as a full complete game.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												Hey guys,this is my first review ever. Really like this game. I find it hard to remain interested in games after a day of smashing them, but im still playing this one. So that says something pretty big. Also my mrs is starting to hate this game as im on it too much.Pros -Exceptionally fast load time. once you double click the games shortcut, you are in world within a 15-20 seconds. great for those of us impatient or busy people. I really really hate bull**** loadtimes. I want to play a game not make a cup of coffee and come back while waiting for the main menu.-Good game progression.  for once a game that doesnt bog you down waiting for research, construction, or resource gathering/grinding. It has a nice balance of automation to the point where all that stuff can be done while you are off exploring. Ive often been off exploring a cavern and come back only to find that the slowest part of the system is myself and it is easy to get to the point of automation that most things become trivial (Wtf do i do with 5k copper now?)-enemies and death. you can make the game as hard as you like, and the consequences of death as permanent or trivial as you like in world gen. Which is really nice when you are still learning how to grapple around a massive cavern or falling down a really big hole.- The world. OMFG it is huge. The underground caverns are enormous, like really really really big and the terrain changes with depth, always serving up something different.-in game help. it is incredibly intuitive. It could be a little more indepth with some items but still very well thought out and just a blessing.-holobase function. you can track realtime how your network is functioning and where any bottlenecks are-good steam community who have most answers for you.-developer that is active on forums and takes interest in our feedback.cons-there is no way to pause the game as yet. you can camp out next to a torch or leave and come back (which is not that big of a deal due to fast load times) but pause would be awesome when you have the mrs trying to talk to you or a baby screaming at you. I understand the dev has said that it is a survival game but it could be a deal breaker for some gamers.-controls take a while to get used to. now and again im still trying to access hoppers with e. -the options could be a little more in depth with the sounds and music. took  google to find out how to turn off music (ctrl -m)-a coordinate system would make digging holes to your mining operations soo much easier. all in all a great early access game. very well thought out and designed. a clear development roadmap and it gives you what it promises. anyway back to the mrs tasks

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
												Before continuing into the meat of this review there is something you need to be aware of, while this game is aesthetically similar to minecraft it needs to be made clear that it is not a clone. The world made of cubes and mining had already been around before minecraft, and moreover its an aesthetic that is not something minecraft owns. If you can't get past the "all cube based games are minecraft copies" then stop reading here, onto the meat.Pros:1. This is a common one yet still important, the option to play with high or low difficulty in finding ore, the strength of hostiles, and even obtaining the energy you will so dearly need throughout the game. This is important as being able to enjoy the game from both a higher level and casual standpoint is a must.2. The hostiles, they are exactly what should be in a game like this, instead of only straight forward hit you and the face type ememies you have an enemy that will attach itself to your conveyor belts and such and devour all your ores making its nest ( the hivemind ) larger, and a little stealth cube thing that will drain power from your mining set up underground. Better yet, they still include a straight forward hit you in the face mob, and a little or dropping resource mob to boot for your tin needs.3. Instead of making you dig out a staircase, one of the most tedious  hardships one usually faces in "cube games", this game offers a high powered grappling hook, you can dig straight down and then grapple back up, this may seem overpowered however it will already take you quite some time to acquire resources and set up your automated mining and power system, if getting back to the surface were to take forever each time this game would be rendered unplayable by those of us who just dont have enough time.4. The automation that can be achieved in this game is satisfying, when you go from having to run back in forth to your copper mine set up to watching the copper roll in on a conveyor into your hopper then into your smelter, and at the moment you are looking at the 200+ stack of copper, you will feel a level of satisfaction on par with properly heating a plate of pizza rolls and not burning your tongue and throat.Cons:1. Despite what I said earlier about the hostiles, the game could probably use a bit more in this area, if you know what you are doing they are pretty easy to handle as is, there doesnt need to be too much more of this but some for sure.2. The learning curve, if you dont watch some videos, you are likely to flounder about having no idea what you are doing, this does hurt the game quite a bit. If you are against checking out some videos to figure things out this might be the deciding factor for you.3. Being a little to intense with the autmation, if you arent a fan creating (sometimes) complex systems to acquire, smelt, and convert your ore into useful objects then this game just isnt for you.4. The name, if you have played the old fortresscraft, then you go in expecting something quite different from what you will get, it is misleading and could be the leave a sour impression depending on whether you did your research or not.Conclusion:I gave an equal number of pros and cons, what comes down to is if you enjoy automation, and thinking, then theres a pretty high chance you will enjoy this game, if not continue on, and if you arent into that, but you still want to give it a go, thats awesome.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
												At the time I'm writing this review, I've got a tad over 50 hours in, and I feel like I'm just scratching the surface.The game is incredibly deep. It has found the perfect balance between difficult and fun - nothing comes easy, but everything feels great once you get it. To the same note, the game has an incredible amount of complexity, but with the research system, it's rarely (if ever) overwhelming.Even more than this, the developer is really responsive. You can just tell that this is his baby, and he is doing everything that he possibly can to make this everything we (the community) wants. -- And to that note, he has succeeded.I've recomended it to multiple friends, and we've all made the jump past the event horizon together. I'm not even sure if this message will reach you. If it does, know that there's another EPIC world waiting for you, but know that there is no return from it. You will be leaving your former life behind. (Trust me, I bought this less than a week ago, thinking this was just a casual game for my spare time. Now I'm pretty sure my family has contacted the cops and reported me missing)

content:
Posted: March 15, 2016
EDITGetting a trojan warning from fortresscraft's .exe  [See Comment section]How peculiar:http://puu.sh/nIHwo/d104fdc49a.pngIntroductionComing into FortressCraft my only survival building game experience has been minecraft. So I'd like to say my expectations were high. I had read FC Evolved was similar to Tekkit modded minecraft and I was getting excited. Firstly I dislike space themed anything - and this is definitely space themed - but I've found it to be fine.My first 10mins of gameplay I was confused AF. It's fun to learn and work out what you have to do - which could be avoided by watching a gameplay of FC Evolved on YT, but I wanted to throw myself into the deep end. I'm at 20+hrs in, 17hrs of which in this one world, where I like to pretend I know what I'm doing. And I feel I've barely scratched the surface.  Once you figure out a methodology and approach, and are fast acting on it, I think you could have a world up and running a LOT faster than what I've done in this first attempt - and that's one of the selling points, become efficient.Pros/ConsPros:+ Loads of gameplay+Looks pretty [I run at good, and occasionally stutters - my gfx card runs Farcry 4 at decent settings]+I love the mobility [compared to MC]+I love the grappling hook mechanic+I love ctrl+clicking to build 30blocks in a straight line+I love seeing a base grow and become automated+I love pressing K to find where I placed that ore extractor, because I totally forgot where I put it+Addicting gameplay+Always something to do/alter/change/move/collect/kill/mine/ping+You can leave it in the background/ALTTab and even on single player, the world continues to simulate - so if you have automated mining set up, you can do other things away from your PC and come back to collect smelted ores.Cons:-I wish there was lights - early on. Throwing a bright green torch is ugly and hurts my eyes :')-I wish conveyor belts could be placed with ctrl+click, as that would save me time-I wish the music was better? A lot of annoying sounds. I find it actually nicer to play with sound off becaues of this.- Confusing progression.Overall, I paid ~$15.00 for it[?], and it has been worth it. I plan to put a lot more hours in.PS.S.I walked upto that giant squid monster and instantly died. My reasoning being I saw an unknown block at it's centre and I wanted to collect it :^).

												If you like minecraft, factorio, infinnifactory, you'll like this too. Fairly mindless block bashing, slightly complex resource management, dumb mobs. Pretty too.My biggest issue is not being able to see what is inside your storage hoppers when there is more than one item in there, they don't act like chests as in being able to open them and view what's inside, but more like stacks, where you can only tell how many items are in the stack and only see the top one.Another is the spiderbot, which is supposed to defend your base, however it is a rubbish shot, and it spends its time getting in your way or damaging the terrain around and under your base making it difficult to move around. Need a way to switch it off or disable it.EDIT: Recent update made the Spiderbot better. No weapons at the start, upgradeable weapons thereafter and they've apparently made it a much better shot with the ability to target up to 5 mobs simultaneously. It still leaves holes and loot all over the place though.

content:
Posted: February 28, 2016
												Having never played minecraft, I come at this game fresh.  If you like a nice logistics game with good graphics and a blocky environment, I recommend this game.  It's fun and moderately challenging.  I do however feel it isn't really fully fleshed out.  There isn't enough challenge.  Unless you are grossly incompetent, you won't lose the game, and there is no feeling of dread that you are in deep doo doo and might lose.I do recommend the game and I do find it fun, but after awhile you realize you have reached a point where you have so many resources, you just don't have to worry about nothing and the challenge is all gone.  What the game needs is random events of some type that force you to cope with the unpredictable, or some sort of boss creature that attacks once in a while and might destroy parts of your base.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2016
												So after more than 100 hours in game, I can finally make my review: This game is very unique (in my opinion) to the other games. This game MAY be blocky as minecraft, but the textures are detailed, and pretty, with out them being blocks. They do have blocky hit box, but hitboxes aren't that important ;). So beck to the topic. You can build BIG mining operations, and factories, and what not, on pretty much anything. Because of the worlds size that is 200 LIGHT YEARS (or 1892146155423912000 meters !) long in every direction from spawn, you can build what ever. It's kind of hard and challenging to start up, but when you get a bit automated, you are all good (and challenges are fun, right?). Now lets talk about mining. You get an ore extractor, that mines ore veins. Each ore vein is different in size. Some can be up to 32 mil. ore!. That is going to last a very long while. But to do that you need to send power down, and then with conveyors, pipes, ore matter movers, up to the surface and smelt it.Goal in this game (right now) is to kill 4 overminds, with orbital strike. Now there is at least 100h of gameplay. But this is not like factorio (I still love Factorio tho), that you win, and not play anymore. If you win here, you can still do stuff! But if you kill them, nothing will attack you (for now)Now about updates and performance. Well, updates are often, and also you have different "betas" to play on, like Bleeding Edge. That is game where is new stuff, that will be put into mainline. But this comes at the risk. You can crash, your world can get corrupted, and bugs. Well, that is why its called "Bleeding" edge ;). Preformance is pretty decent. I have 8GB, and this game is in Unity 5, and I use only 40% of memory. FPS are very high, but if you request too much FPS, your world may not load fast.Now final part, the devs. As far as I know. There is one Developer working on this game, DjArcas. He has few other devs to help out. Also he streams on Twitch like 8h STRAIGHT! He shows all the programming, and how he works the game. Also, because Direwolf20 have played this, more people came in :D. But I don't think that DJ is getting enough $$$, for what is he doing. He indeed deserves more. You know, he needs food, and personal things. Also you know how models of blocks can cost?! Up to 10k$! those are some big bucks. But this means, more people = faster game development.So from this review, you can tell that I LOVE this game. This is legit, the nicest comunity, that I ever met. You need help with Game? just post a thread, and people will anwser :). Lots of nice people, and if the thread is something big (sometimes even small), even developers themselves will help you! Actually, they are on 80% of the threads, so that speaks for it self :). Thanks all! Keep it up!

												Fantastic game if you like building factories and advancing through a tech tree. This is the best mining/crafting/base-building game I've seen yet! At time of writing, there's over 20 hours of non-grindy mining and crafting before you get to the grindy end-game content. It's still being worked on, but the lower tiers of tech are highly detailed and optimized. You won't feel like anything is missing until you get to the end game content.If you liked Modded Minecraft, Space Engineers, Terraria or Factorio, FortressCraft is going to consume your life for about 5 days. Make sure to book time off work and make peace with your loved ones before you start playing.

content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
												Update - I wanted to update my review to note that the vast majority of multiplayer issues have been remedied: I am now able to play the game with my kids without constantly restarting or replacing someone's suit upgrades because of sync issues.  Hooray!This game's been out of early access for a couple months now, but it gets more content in its free monthly patches than a fully supported Blizzard game.  There is an upcoming, 8 dollar expansion pack that I'd gladly pay for (Dev's cat's gotta eat) based on what I've seen thus far.  To anyone confused about the patreon bit: A patreon sub enables a very small handful of cosmetic, VIP "bling" blocks if you will, and early access to the expansion.  It's a donation with a tiny thank you; not a sales' offer.My original review, less my comment on multiplayer:Factorio meets Minecraft, kind of like playing feed the beast/Industrial craft mods but with the cohesion of a single dev behind it rather than 100 separate mods in a package that never works or updates quite right.If all of that's greek to you, the game consists of finding raw materials, and constructing the logistics to extract, move, and process them, either into more logistics, research pods, or defenses against attacking wasp things.  The GOOD:Engaging base building gameLots of recipes to craft across several tiers of stuff.Good visual feedback on logistics letting you know what's working or notStill being actively developed (IE more's coming)The BAD:Currently there's very little variety in the enemies that attack you, or your defenses to deploy against them.Gameplay between the last available research and charging the OET (winning) is currently just a huge grind for more power generation.  I expect this gap will later be filled with more interesting content, but were the dev to win the lottery and stop making the game, it'd be poorly balanced in its present state.Overall, I could recommend this game: it's less than the cost of minecraft and basically takes the most interesting parts of minecraft to me and expands them.  WIth the mulitplayer issues fixed I expect this will be a fantastic game to play on LANs or with a small group of friends.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2016
												A technically complete game that is still being worked on, it's easy to dismiss this as a "Minecraft Clone" due to the voxel based game world. But there are aspects of FortressCraft Evolved that blow Minecraft right out of the water (and I really like Minecraft). For one, the world size. It's massive. I have found cave systems that could contain the build height limit of Minecraft, and then some. I have tunneled straight down and have so far gone well past 7,000 meters below the surface level, while Minecraft goes from 0 to a comparatively limited 255.As for the gameplay itself, it can be very technical. You have to build a logistics and mining network to defend your base from attacks, generate power, and be very careful not to feed any near by hive minds.In terms of how long you are playing? Well... I'll admit I'm probably not the best player, but so far I've put in 112 hours and haven't reached the "End Game" as of yet.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 20, 2016
												First thing: This is an early access game, things won't be 100% polished. In the state it currently is, it's extremely addicting and fun to play. You could spend 200+ hours even in it's current state and enjoy every minute. The developer, a single person, continually releases patches on bleeding edge. I'm in the beta (which is a step higher) and even there you get a lot of nice updates still. The core version won't tend to see updates often, so i recommend opting into beta.Onto the review!There is so much potential for this game. If you like minecraft but sucked at building and making things look nice, or like playing with redstone, then you'll love this game without a doubt. It also makes buidling a breeze with the ability to place an entire row of blocks in a single click. I don't usually go out and buy games, espically if I've never head of it. But after watching video's of it for a bit I really became interested. And man it's the best game under $15 i've ever bought. You won't find much of multiplayer quite yet (it's still somewhat of a wip) but there is so much to do even so. The future of this game will only get better. Even if it's current state was it's final state, I wouldn't feel like I wasted my money. So come join, support this game, tell your friends and your free time will never be used for anything else again.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21, 2016
												This game has had me obsessed for a couple weeks, and I gather it is still being improved.  However, I'm taking a break from playing it because it is getting tedious.  First, the game puts you on a short leash because of your need to keep recharging your suit.  After a lot of research and obtaining some iron and lithium, you can set up a camp on the surface to charge your suit and Arthur (your advicea and power done), but all the goodies are underground, and it's easier to not get lost if you dig your own tunnels.  There is also a short leash because your one and only smelter can only smelt 100 ore blocks at a time, yielding 25 metal ingots each time, and there are projects you would want to do (like get ore distributed to your doorstep) that require hundreds.  I've spent most of yesterday babysiting my smelter, and doing a little exploration while it's smelting the latest hundred pack.  Expect to do a lot of gophering before you can automate anything.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15, 2016
												put factorio and starforge in minecraft, and you get this game. Obnoxiously large world, vast, HUGE expances of caves, like Hang Son Doong big. Think it's just night because you can't see the cieling big. Recreate Dwarven cities big. This game revitalized that sence of wonder, being overwhelmed, and exploration that the first time I played minecraft did. Those that like Minecraft, and are a little done playing modpack after modpack and geeting burned out on it should DEFINENTLY play this game. and come on, it's only $13 (on 2/15/2016), why WOULDN'T you get this game?I must say though, that if your computer is a toaster, it'll get frustrating with the game turning into a slide-show. This game isn't exactly friendly on your ram or proccessing capabilities, but you can drop the detail and graphics WAY down and still have a good time, it'll just look like it was done on the N64. But, normally this game is gorgeous, provided you have the computer to handle it.For those of you who are experienced in minecraft (particularly tech mods) you'll discover that you will be making LOTS of controll based mistakes. Also, you'll have a decent understanding of tech progression, however, it is dificult to know ahead of time what you need to do. I would recomend that you play a few worlds to better understand what to do, and what way you prefer the most to do it. Your first few worlds are likely to fail in your eyes, this is fine, and fixable at just about any time, but you can always start fresh.I would like to see a more comprehensive creative mode, as it does not lend to helping you actually mess around with logistical ideas, and what not, which I would like to see. currently, if you have an idea to use a system, you have to just try it out, which makes experimentation a potentially costly endeavour.The short version is that this game is amazing, and any fan of starforge, minecraft, and/or factorio should most deffinently fork over the cash and get this game. it's not even all that much cash in the first place.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
												Many people seem to complain about the game being too grindy or the tutorial being not helpful because it only teaches the basic basics.Many people are apparently not playing the game in the way that this game should be played: by automating everything.The early game can be a really bad and boring grind, but only if you are either sitting at your base and waiting for your ore extractors to dig up some ore and then grab it to smelt it at your base or exploring too much too early and as result of either, not having enough automation going on, which results in slowing the game to a crawl.If you truly feel like the game is far too grindy, my advice would be to look up a tutorial or something that teaches you how to *actually* play.Oh and the latest patch brought a rather large amount of improvements to early game progression to help starting in a new world.The game itself can easily called a 3D factorio, although that would be a bit too simple - Fortresscraft has many features that allow it to be similiar and yet different, such as the world being literally infinitely deep and having massive underground caverns (which make the ones in minecraft look like caverns for ants) to explore.Overall, I can wholeheartedly recommend this game to fans of basebuilding, automation and tower defense. (The upcoming expansion will also add tower defense comparable to the Creeper World series, which is great too!)

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
												Love this game! It's a awesome mix of voxel building, and survival through tower defense.  If you like to design and build large complex machines on a massive scale then you'll like this game.  If you like to manage those machines to get the most efficient designs, you'll like this game.  If you're really into tower defense, you might be a bit disappointed.  There are a good variety of enemies, but generally all you do is build A LOT of guns around your base.  The only strategy that comes into play is keeping them efficiently powered through your machines.To win survival mode, you really need to think BIG.  Expect some of your structures to expand 1,000 blocks away from your starting base (although the majority will likely be within 500 blocks).   A general rule that worked for me is whenever I first build something, I make sure to leave space around it to build 4 or 5 more in the future because it seems like you always need more than you expect.  You'll feel like you have a lot of empty space around, but by mid game you'll be wondering where all that space went.One complaint I've seen people bring up is that they get bored waiting for materials to be crafted.  If you're bored, you're doing it wrong.  This game is all about building big machines to automate production.  If you're sitting around waiting for research to complete - how about using that time to build more power generators to vastly improve research speed?  Don't have the materials to build more power?  Then go explore the world for new ore veins and build more machines to harvest it for you.  You have the tools and resources to build more mines and assembly lines to create more supplies than you know what to do with.My only knock on the game is that a lot of information is missing from the in-game help.  If you want to learn many helpful tips that will take your base to the next level, expect to spend some time looking online or in the steam community pages for information.The positive spin on this is that the developers are very active and are improving the game and adding new items/features on a near-daily basis so perhaps they haven't found the time to finish the help menu or aren't settled on the final stats of an item yet.

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 29, 2016
												If you like Big Pharma, Inififactory, or Factario you might want to check out this game.Personally I think if you like Kerbal Space Program, Rim World, or Prison Architect you might also like this game.First thing, even though this is a voxel based game, it is far from a minecraft clone. That was the biggest thing that made me hesitate buying it, but I am glad I was wrong about that.The game is far from perfect. There are bugs and annoying things. However, the dev is constantly working on it (and if opt into one of the branches you get nightly updates).In the course of a year, the game will seem like a completly new game with all of the the additional features and content. Yes there is DLC, but there are still free content updates as well. However, even if there was not, you are more than getting your moneys worth with this game.I find it rediculous how peopel will hem and haw over buying this when it is on sale to like $5. If you like the game you get 100's of hours of gameplay (Many players get 1000's of hours). If you don't like it, you are only out $5.The fanbase is supportive enough that many people donate to the dev through Pateron. This is one of those games (like Dwarf Fortress) that will continue to be in development for years. I won't go into the details of the Pro's and Con's or anything like. Plenty of other reviews do that. I will just say to check it out.EDIT:Just a thought I recently had. The 3D FPS nature of the game will mean that setting certain things up will take longer than in games like Factario (even ignoring Factario's blue print system). Thinking about it, I just wanted to emphasise the similarities to Infinifactory.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2016
												Nothing but problems.1.) Lighting:The lighting system as it is currently implemented is completely broken.  Bloom effects are amped-up through the roof while ambient/"natural" light is nonexistent, making this a very dark game - such that it is borderline unplayable.  I cannot begin to describe how difficult it is to see anything while playing.  Reference the attached images and judge for yourself:  https://www.dropbox.com/sh/esvp0oxvj0acs7v/AACsUL_dAlfPxAZReeVmVO2ea?dl=0Depicted is a subsurface coal vane about 1-2 blocks below the surface that has been exposed.  One screenshot shows the coal in natural light, the other with a flashlight directed at it on maximum power.  Also included are screenshots of various tunnels being illuminated by a flashlight on maximum power.2.) User interface:There are very few user-configurable audio or video settings. - No brightness/gamma control - No UI scale control - No key binding (must exit and change within the Unity launcher)In addition, the control scheme is extremely awkward.  It is completely alien to that of any other game, including Factorio and Minecraft.3.) Save time on shutdown:For some reason, this game implements a savefile compression system that activates after you confirm that you want to exit to desktop.  This system will operate for well over a minute before allowing the game to shut down unless you cancel it by clicking "exit now".4.) Sound design:The sound design in this game is a bit of a let-down.  It tries way too hard to be a blend of retro-futuristic bleeps, bloops and machine sounds, but ends up sounding more like a bunch of stock files that were tweaked in Audacity.  This is not a deal breaker by any means, but it really helps to make this game feel like a cheap one-off.  (The main menu alone contains audio elements that pop and crackle as they move around, and at least one horribly obvious 60Hz ground loop.)I cannot in good faith recommend this game to anyone.  I was very hesitant to try it based on the other negative reviews below, but I purchased it for ~$12 w/ DLC nonetheless at the recommendation of a friend.  I will be refunding this title immediately.Caveat emptor.To the developer(s?):  The main problems with your game are not related to lack of features or content.  Your game is desperately in need of usability refinements and technical polish.  When it comes to your UI and lighting systems: Instead of trying to defy convention at every opportunity, take a few hints from other games that have been massively successful.  In addition to everything mentioned above, focus on the little things that make a huge difference - like placing "tutorial" elements into dialog boxes, instead of floating them above peoples' heads or behind machines where they will never be seen.System specs for reference:2560x1440 144Hz displayGTX 980tii7 5820k32GB DDR4(All overclocked)

												I never write reviews but since this game just became my most played game on steam and i'm still on my 1st map so i think I should share my experience.It's addictive, it's a lot of management, there's always something else to do. Last time I got this deep into a game was WOW 10 years ago. If you got something to do you need to do it right, always think bigger, large scale. I ended up redoing my whole base a few time and it's worth it, it's necessary, if it doesn't work you're doing it wrong, think bigger, automate, optimise transit for you and your ressources.It may not be 100% complete, lots of much wanted helpfiles aren't done yet but I prefer a good game with active work in progress than seeing the end of it. Best indie game ever, much better than most AAA titles, be ready to sink hundreds of hours on normal mode.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2016
												I have been submerged in the game for a number of days now. I have barely scratched the surface and yet I have about 50 hours on each of two worlds I have created. There is a lot to like here, if you like building games, you get to start from about nothing and work up from there. If you have played Factorio it is kinda like that, and not like it too. I think the research in Factoria can be a lot faster, but then I haven't really automated enough in FCE yet to know if that is true. The 3D aspect is a lot of fun, and the world shaping and stuff just eats up my time. I level hills, fill in valleys, build walls, make neat tunnels, etc. I have never played Minecraft, but my understanding is that the movement and shaping in FCE is much faster and easier. I guess it looks similar but does play very different from my understanding.All in all I have really been enjoying the challenge of finding the ore, building up enough to work to automating getting it to the surface so I can smelt it and then use it for research and more building stuff.I would recommend watching a play through or two on youtube, there are some great folks there. Even though the game has changed over time the mechanics are mainly unchanged so you get a good feel for how much there is to do and to play with!tl;dr I liked it a lot, you should get it.

number of helpful: 8 of 14 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 29, 2016
												This is, by far, the best survival game I have ever played. the combination of Tower defense, automation, survival, and exploration is exquisite. Not only that, but the sheer amount of replayability is staggering. Each playthrough is unique not just because of procedural generation, but also because each playthrough is a new chance to try new automation methods, new turret setups, design new power grids, etc. if you aren't very patient or don't like intellectual games, however, this may not be for you. The first play through will take a while, as it takes a while to learn everything, and creating massive mining and manufacturing operations is very difficult, even for a veteran Talos Principle player like myself. The game has a few flaws, such as the fact it is very taxing and creative mode is rather lacking, but other than that it is great. Heck, if you have any questions, you can ask the developer directly by tuning into his daily developement live streams on the Projector Games youtube channel. I give Fortresscraft Evolved a 9/10.

number of helpful: 40 of 77 people (52%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								When they say "infinite worlds" they really mean it!  I decided to test this and built a structure going from the surface (Y:0) and built all the way up to 3,254...  I could have kept going, but let's be honest, that would have been pointless.  So then I decided to find the floor of the world, and dug down to 9,153...  And I could have kept going.  Minecraft's 256 block height limit is put to absolute shame, as this game shows its beefy and well-constructed voxel engine.  I'll admit, I'm going to use Minecraft as my comparison here, because Minecraft is the definitive voxel game to compare to.The game's view distance is comparable to that of Minecraft's 15 chunk view distance, which means you can see a lot.  In Minecraft there's a survival situation which revolves around food.  Currently in FortressCraft Evolved the survival situation revolves around body heat.  You're in a constant struggle to keep yourself cool enough and warm enough at the same time.  Standing in fire makes your body overheat, draining your power cells, and will kill you of heat exhaustion.  Staying underground or out in the elements at night can cause you to begin to freeze, and you can die of hypothermia as well.The game is looking good already in its pre-alpha state, and I absolutely can't wait for the full release.  Normally I'd say "don't buy this early access unless you're ready to deal with bugs," but in this case, the sooner you get it, the less you'll end up paying in the end.  So it's at your discretion, buy now and save, or buy later for peace of mind.Some of the features work, some of them don't, but you'll still find plenty to do in this game.  Better pack yourself a lunch, because you're going to be playing this for long hours.

content:
Posted: April 13
												It starts so well, it is like Factorio or similar factory/base building games, but being in 3d makes it a lot more exciting. The problem is that after a while, you have the basic factory and there is nothing else to build. You do unlock some more objects but they are crafted in a moment and then placed and then you are done. So you are adding occasional new little machines or boxes, but you aren't actually building a base, and you certainly aren't building a 'fortress'. There is really no fortress or base building at all, you just build a basic factory, and then instead of tower defense, you just build 4 lasers and put one in each corner of your base and it kills everything. Later you need to upgrade that by adding a rocket to each corner but you will complete the game like that. There is really no tower defense gameplay in here, no shaping the paths and no multiple tower types with synergy etc. It is just a line of flying monsters that head straight to your core and get killed by lasers when you aren't even there. And even if they don't die, it doesn't matter because there is no penalty for them killing your core. It just regenerates and is back to normal 2 minutes later.The game seems great at first, but it all falls apart after a while and you see how under developed the whole game is. I suggest getting Factorio instead because although that game is 2d and doesn't have the exploring and digging for resources, the actual factory building is more fun, more balanced, and less of a micro management chore. Also the combat is more promising because at least you have to fight back in that game. Also there are a more and better mods, including one that lets you fight back with planes etc. FortressCraft has some mods but not many, and most of them don't do much. You might get a new storage box or something but there isn't anything that adds anything significant to spice up the gameplay. Almost an amazing game but falls short.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2013
												Updated Mar 10th: Green thumbs all around, developer is putting too much effort for me to be a whiner.Updated Dec 29th: Back to a red thumb, survival is just too empty to call this a game.  Still very much "in development" even though it's missing the EA tag...Updated Dec 2015While this game is no longer in Early Access, some of it still feels very much "beta".  This is not a bad thing, at least not in this instance.  For example, the graphics settings are very basic.  You'll be forced to live with Jar Jar Abrams due to any light source emitting massive amounts of bloom.  So your options are going to be darkness, one light, or blinding nova of brightness."So what?" That's pretty much what I mean by still feeling "beta".  Don't like music?  Better also not like other sounds, it's all one slider: Volume.  Some other GUI issues pop up, like no exit to menu.  You must always head to your desktop, and since the game has stringent survival mechanics and no pause...well it's either full exit or no bathing."Just GUI issues?" So far, that's about it.  I mean there is a lack of content (trees that grow, plants that grow, a sun/moon/sky/weather) But these, to me, are fluff.  The base game is there, the mechanics are sound.  It just needs the finishing polish to make it a full game."Lack of Documentation" There is still a big issue with information in game.  You need to craft item "Thing" which is made up of items "A" "B" "C" and "D".  Item "A" is made up of "B","C", and "E".  Item "B" is made up of "E".  Item "C" is made up of "F".  And item "D" is made up of "E","F" and "G".  Confused?  The help menu helps, but it's just a start.  (Back to feeling beta...)Lastly, I feel the AI is just not there.  I see some slugs, and other minor mobs.  But nothing that screams "life".  The planet (always snow, nothing else...) you land on is a dead husk, with aimless monsters.  Again, the mechanics are there they just seem under utilized.No modding that I can find, can't even change textures.  Might need to use a fancy program to edit files though.Anyway, do I recommend the game?  It's hard to say, I really enjoy playing it.  Would enjoy it more if modding was there, or at least information as to how to mod.  Until then, it has plenty of hours worth of content to keep you busy, if you're after a crafting/building game with really bright lights.  So I give it a green thumb, though with my track record with plants it might as well be red.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2015
												Great game!  I have 50+ hours at the time of this review and l like that I still have a LOOONG way to go to experience all the content.  The tech tree is quite extensive and feels well balanced.  This is a logistics/base building game, so don't think it's just a minecraft clone because of the blocks.  Completely different gameplay and goals.  It takes actual strategy and planning, and the only way to "properly" play is to automate everything.  You should not be carrying ores around and crafting by hand otherwise you're in for a long, slow grind.Edit: update after almost 200 hours of gametime... Still fantastic.  I love the fact that the developer is still actively working on it, continuously adding new features and fixing gameplay issues for free.  Meaning that's not even including the expansion pack.  He listens to the community for good suggestions, but also has a clear direction and reasoning behind gameplay elements.For the price you are getting an absolute steal in longevity and entertainment value.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 9, 2016
												While still in the development stage, FC Evolved still provides a plethora of things to keep you occupied while build and advancing your way through the technology tree.I would like to see some more in the way of building materials but with the games heavy focus on the tech and the logistics of collecting resources, I am not sure we will see much improvement on that front.  That is not to say that building is a wasted effort.  With a little bit of creativity and ingenuity you can create some pretty impressing structures and fortresses.   The method of researching new tech through discovery and a later stage Research Laboratory was a welcome change to other methods I have seen leveraged.  I cannot wait to see what awaits for Tier 4 and beyond.The survival mode GUI is still a bit rudimentary but it has been promised by the developers that it will see improvement by the time the game is finished.  A hopper GUI is a much anticipated addition.All said and done, FC Evolved is an immensely immersive game that will provide hours of frustration and enjoyment as you work to gain new tech and build the most epic of fortresses all while trying to fend of the attacks of the local population.I will continue to play and look forward to the further development of the game and happily purchase any and all DLC and Expansion packs to support the amazing work done by the developers.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 11, 2016
												Now that it's had a bunch of updates and I don't think the base game is going to change much more without DLC I think I could write a proper review.Still worth a thumbs up, there's hundreds of hours here if you can stick with it. The only criticisms I have are: the inconsistent naming scheme for PCBs and research pods - why not just name them after what they're made from like everything else? the agonisingly slow start - early expansion appears to be restricted solely to add hours played, even though most of it is just waiting for ore to be smelted or items to be researched the boring reliance on tiers, or multiple versions of the same object as a way to increase complexity - having fewer items made from multiple ore types would be better IMOAll of those are easily fixed through modding or completely disappear within 5 or 6 hours (sooner if you know what you're doing).It's pretty smooth sailing from there :)

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 2, 2016
												Fortresscraft Evolved is a very orginal game indeed. Looking for a minecraft clone? Then you're not going to find one here. After many years of running modded minecraft servers, I was quite sick to the back teeth of the game. That being said, I did get this game thinking there would be some similarities and expected to get bored very quickly. This game, quite simply put, is amazing. The developer is nothing short of a genius!The game has you start with afew supplies, after crash landing on an Alien planet. You are given a small tutorial, and then thrown into the deep end. At this point, I went and watched a few episodes of Direwolf20's lets plays. After being educated a little.. I jumped back into the game. You begin by scanning for various ores, and setting up mining equipment. While this is happening you will be also scanning new blocks and plantlife. This accumulates research points which you can use to unlock new research projects and equipment. It's not long past this point, you realise that 5 hours of game time has passed, and you've simply got lost in this enormous game! By this point I had found my first 4 ore types, and had begun building a system of convayors that could fill my smelters on the surface. Research seemed very simple at first.. but another few hours in and I was now constructing a lab and researching new projects was taking several hours at a time. This was ok though because I had so much other stuff to do while this was happening. However.. the bigger your base becomes, the more power you use.. the higher your base threat becomes.. and it's not long before you threat analyser is telling you.. "Attack immanent!". Now for those like me who love the tech, and the factory side of the game.. the invading alien swarms will only attack your central hub.. and once it's health is 0, it just reboots. That is unless you're playing hardcore.. and then its game over. So as I went deeper into the ground, I realised just how big this game was. Some of the caves, from top to bottom, were bigger than minecraft, bedrock to sky... I would liturally hold my breathe incase I fell off a ledge, as death meant I would drop all my equipment. So far i've been 1,187 blocks deep.. and everytime I go exploring, I just can't explain the feeling of being so small, in caves so large.. This game is great for those wanting some survival, some tower defence, and some tech. I love all the machines that automate the ore collecting and the minecarts that collect the ores.. the way the power system works, and the defending of my base. It really is very well balanced... and it has just the right difficulty level to keep most playing, and not getting bored.10/10

content:
Posted: January 16
												Automate or perish.This game balances resources just right such that progressively every new item in the game turns into something you'll need hundreds or thousands of and will thus set up automation for producing it. With the "plentiful" resource and power settings, nothing feels grindy at all, but even then you will eventually burn through even multi-million ore resource veins, and have to open a second mine for that ore (eg. gold was mine when producing vast numbers of missiles).If you like Minecraft tech mods, this game will exceed anything you've done before.My only complaint is multiplayer, which seems a bit laggy even on a 1Gbps LAN, though I haven't tried tuning it yet.

												This game is phenomenal. I have hundreds of hours into this game and keep coming back to it night after night.It does live in the same family with Factorio but it's not fair to either to say they are the same. content:
Posted: January 15, 2016
												If you like modded minecraft (with tech mods) or factorio then this game is definitely for you, It takes that concept of industrialization, automation, and tech progression and builds on it massively. Not only that, but It also adds some actual threats for you to deal with (we all know that minecraft mobs aren't a threat at all unless you specifically go looking for a challenge) and adds a bunch of cool QOL features like a grappling hook and better building mechanics that improve the experience a whole lot. Yes, as some other reviews have pointed out this game does have its issues, like inconsistent inventory management and sub-par UI, BUT, I think that all of the benefits greatly out-weigh these quirks and result in a very enjoyable experience. I would definitely recommend this game to anyone.

												Really amazing game, with a very active developer :D I can recommend getting this, and even the DLC to support this amazing game!Game has mod support, which is being improved as time goes on. Quite easy to mod the game to your own liking, if unsatisfied with the balancing of the game. After 500 hours, the game is still offering new challenges, with the newly redo of the Hard Mobs difficulty, whole new challenges appears. The new Casual mode offers a great alternative for those who might not have unlimited time to play the game, with a little boost to early game infrastructure as well! :D Community is very helpful, and the modding community as well.Having completed the game a few times, on different difficulties, I believe the game still have more to offer for me, as there are still machines that I havn't played around with. number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												"Minecraft with machines" is what I'd say if I had to describe Fortresscraft in three words. They look similar and play similarly for the most part.However, FCE is focused on machines, rather than farming. Even in an unfinished state it has significant depth, and the blessing of a dev who is happy to listen and to incorporate ideas from the community. The game has had constant updates since I first purchased it, and I keep coming back after the major ones to replay and see all the new content. It's already great, but once finished it will be fantastic. It's very worth the purchase.*UPDATE*The latest updates have had some issues IMHO. The game is still a lot of fun, but the Frozen Factory expansion is very grindy. The only reason I've kept playing is because I can fire it up at work for 6 hours and leave it alone.There's also a distinct feeling that the developer is no trying to force players into playing a very specific way and thus destroying the freedom that made the game so great in the first place. That's his prerogative as the designer, but that doesn't make it any less disappointing. If some of the more heavy-handed tweaks are able to be turned off in the future, I'll update the review, but that doesn't seem likely. I still recommend the game, but not as wholeheartedly as before.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15, 2016
												FortressCraft Evolved, Is a remarkable blend of mechanics coupled together in awesomeness. Its like Factorio and a VERY tech heavy MODDED Minecraft had a baby together but didnt want it, so along came DjArcas and he raised and nurtured this creation into something magnificent......... and he's still making it! He is accepting feedback and development ideas from his discord channel and his twitch streams, I dont know many folks that do this, even in this day and age!Well, the shear magnitude of the game world is breath taking, finding a cavern throwing a glowstick and watching this fall without hitting the bottom, makes your stomach backflip and try to climb out of your mouth, meanwhile trying to navigate and plan routes for conveyors is merely one of several things that you will end up happily wasting several hours and more than one occassion!The progression is fantastic, the way it gets your mind thinking of ways to automate or improve a system. All in all, this is a beautiful game that has more than enough in content for the price as it stands and there is only more to come!!

I honestly didnt think i would like this game now im hooked i Dont notice what time it is till its waaaay past the time i need to get off. it is a lil slow in the beginning but once you start getting conveyer belts going you cant stop.So I crash land first time nooo idea what I'm doing. scan some blocks research some stuff find some ore. make trips back and forth to charge power and get ores. thought this is tedious make some belts n laser power no more trips. look for more ores.... WTF im under attack by what ... ooooo i made the wasps mad. set up turrets go back lookin for more ores. died died died some more. ooooo im to cold down here make better gear go deeper. ... how'd i die that time ... oooo toxic fumes..... make more gear go deeper. build lots and lots of more goodies. go exploreing ..... wth almost craped my self when i ran into a giant worm spittin acid.  more turrets ( feels safer .... ) Honestly i could go on and on but theres so much to build / explore n do in this game it would take a long time to explain it all. but if you enjoy crafting / survival / builder games with logistics n factory line setups i would suggest this for you its waaaaaayyyyyyy better than minecraft it just has blocky voxels that look waaaay better than minecrafts anyway.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 23, 2016
												FCE is a voxel-based game.  That is where any similarities to that oft-compared "other highly popular voxel-based game" ends.  The point of FortressCraft is to build your base/machinery/infrastructure, and let it do the work for you.You start out having crash-landed on a planet with with the most basic of machinery.  Your Central Power Hub to produce power, a research station to perform basic research, a smelter to smelt ore into bars, for use in the crafting station.  Selecting the easier resource difficulty levels will also give you a bonus coal deposit right near your CPH with the machinery needed to automate coal delivery right off the bat.You then start finding resource deposits, placing extractors to mine from them, and collecting ore to smelt to then craft the machinery needed to automate that whole process.  As you discover different types of blocks, you can perform research to be able to craft new machinery to work faster or perform other tasks.  Once your basic research at the research station is all complete, you'll need to build a laboratory to continue higher levels of research.Once you've got your infrastructure rolling along nicely, producing metal bars and power at a good rate, your base threat will increase to the point that the wasps start attacking.  Thus begins the tower defense aspect of the game.  You'll need to build a defense network to deal with the bugs.  And, of course, upgrade that network as your research and production levels increase, to deal with increasingly strong bugs.The best part of this game, though, is the developer.  DjArcas is constantly adding new content into the game, and live streams development quite often.  A lot of game developers claim to be highly involved with their community.  And some even live up to that claim.  But Dj is the only one I know of that interacts with his community live on Twitch while he's writing the code for things that he's talking with the community about.  Many of the machines currently in the game are the result of suggestions made while he was streaming development.If you like voxel-based games, city-building games, or strategy games, or any combination thereof, I highly recommend you check out FortressCraft Evolved.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2016
												The game is quite nice if you like Minecraft with automation mods. There's a good number of challenges in the game, including having to defend your base against continuous attacks, making sure you maintain sufficient energy production and making sure your automation lines remain running efficiently.On the downside, the combination of digging, searching for resources, defending and maintaining power easily becomes overwhelming, even if you automate everything! It isn't a game to sit back and relax, and it continuously keeps you busy, which can be exhausting at times. There's not that much to explore and the entire game is quite misty, giving it a bit of a depressing feeling and making it lack scenery worth looking at.Recommended? It depends what you like. I spend quite some time in it and liked to play it, but I believe it isn't for everyone. If you like challenges and automation, go ahead. If you like exploration, you wish to relax or like nice scenery, there are better games out there.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
												A must have for fans of modded Minecraft and Factorio.Automation from the ground up is aim of this game, so it's good to see a game like this, in it's current state, with the vast array of machines and upgrades it's possible to get. And it's blatantly clear how much there is for the developer to add, this is a game that you will spend well over two days (not two days in real life, but 48 hours in game) on now, come back and lose even more time later, with a bunch of new content.While the tutorial maybe boring and dull, leading you through utter basics, the game features a world gen that is awe insipiring, with canyons carving scars in the terrain and caves seemingly without a bottom. Not to mention a literally infinite world.A gem that I might have otherwise over-looked.EDIT:I will clarify about the games "status". It is a FULL release, with active support. It means there are bugs still in the game, but these are patched and fixed by the developer. It is by no means early access, the main game itself is complete, with DLC (coming, as of time of writing) to expand on the current content, not a cash grab. And to be frank waaaaaay too many games use early access as a shield to divert attention away from it's bugs. FCE is different, the dev fixes the bugs rather than throwing "EA!" in the face of bug reports. What more can you really expect from a (single) dev who also is adding content, polishing and bug fixing his game all at the same time?

The dev can come off as mean and facetious, and the community can come across as elitist and sanctimonious. In short, they do not suffer fools. I don't care about that. As long as they keep doing exactly what they do, what resulted in such a great game, I am happy to support them all.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2016
												TL;DWTR:It has a steep learning curve.It is a challenge.It is a factory game.You get attacked.You try to endgame.You try to endgame again.If you love slow paced 'crafting/automation' games (like Factorio, but not 1 hour and you're done), with a sense of acheivement when you build that massive (3 dimensional) factory that does exactly what you ask, while you are being attacked, and trying to grow your factory, so you can be attacked more while you try to endgame, then you will very much love this game.It starts slow, and has a steep learning curve, but players who can bear to not have their hands held, will love it.NTL;WTR:I love the Battlefield series of games.I love getting into a fresh round of fast paced action.I love killing those 4 blokes who all came up the elevator at Siege of Shanghai C.And most of all, I hate the fact that players who have all played the game a long time and acquired knowledge and experience in the game think it is their right to "Always be on the winning team". Where is the challenge in fighting a bunch of noobies that don't know what they are doing? Where is the fun without a challenge?FortressCraft Evolved is nothing like Battlefield, thank goodness.There is no teamstacking. There is no "How the f did he get me". But it is a challenge. And it is fun.I've only owned it for a little bit. And when I first started playing it, I wasn't sure what I was doing, and not much has changed for newbies. Spend a week on making a proper tutorial for new players, and the player base may just grow.The primary developer does listen to community feedback. Heck, he even ASKS for it. Sometimes he downright ignores it. But few times has the primary developer's actions been detrimental to the enjoyment of the game.My experience of my playthrough currently (And all my time 187 hours is devoted to one single game)Start off.WTF am I doing?Oh, I get it.I don't get it.Need more power.Need more ore.Need more bars.Need more power.Researching cool stuff.What is that thing in the corner of the map.I won't do that again.More cool stuff.More cool stuff.Make  un-cool stuff do cool stuff.Still playing around.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2016
												I bought this in early access and (at least I think this is the game I remember) I hated the movement (getting pulled to the center of a block when stopping).  It bugged me enough to not give the game a chance, and seemed more like a creative mode minecraft at the time with some fast building tools but I wanted a survival mode.  Uninstalled and didn't touch it again.  I believe that was December 2013.Then recently the Frozen Factory Expansion came out and took another look at the game (and apparently all the updates to the game over that time period added a ton to the game).  Amazing.  Like minecraft and factorio mashup but better looking, fast digging and building tools, lots of machines to research, every block type has to be scanned, super fast travel with the grapple, using lasers to send energy to remote excavators.  Been playing and watching "flexible games" play this on youtube.  I'm hooked just like when Minecraft and Space Engineers first came out.With the current sale I bought another copy of the game and the DLC for a family member to play with.  Edit - And because I have fallen in love with this game, just bought a copy full price for another family member, but they are going to have to earn the expansion by playing the game.I read on the forum someone running out of RAM while playing.  He has 6000 machines.  I have maybe 20 machines and can barely keep up.  This game is about automating your assembly lines.Wonderful game.Edit - 25 hours in and now I am finally "getting it."  How to set up assembly lines, automate my mines, run my laboratory at a decent speed by setting up generators and energy storage efficiently.  10/10 game.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
												tl;dr It's tough recommending this game, but the bottom line I think I've got my money's worth and I think you probably will too.Pros:+ Great game concept. Cons:- Progression is broken. This game is about automation, but buildings' prerequisites and research requirements are set up so that you WILL spend hours grinding through things manually, and you WILL spend hours waiting on unavoidable bottlenecks. The game fights you every step of the way- UI is broken. There's so much information that's not presented to the player (eg what research does), or presented in one of multiple places. There is a contextual help, but it really needs to be fleshed out to fill in huge gaps.- Mobs are completely uninspired. Wasps will fly without stopping directly to the heart of your base, only attacking a single structure (the one that gets less and less important as the game progresses). There's no strategy to defense aside from supplying power to however many turrets it takes to kill the enemy.- Low quality models and animations. Not super important considering the above points, but jerky conveyor belts sending items through each other, guns and enemies shooting globs of goo through walls, and everything else is just kind of distracting.Those are some pretty massive cons for a game with only one pro, but I've got 38 hours in this game and only spent $8. Buy it and play it while watching TV or something. Or don't buy it and just play Factorio.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 29, 2016
												This is a game that requires investment of time and effort. It's not for everybody, it doesn't offer a steady dose of action packed mini achievements and it isn't something you just pick up and go, before you reach the end you'll have put in around 200 hours into it and it's said that the Frozen Factory expansion adds another 100. And that's not counting the time you spend outside the game planning your base if you're like me.Most of the time in this game is spent building stuff and setting up elaborate pipelines so you can ... build more stuff. You can avoid the automation but then the game gets grindy, plus it's becoming harder and harder (both because of extra limitations to push people towards automation and because barriers to automation are removed so it's always the easier option).The game isn't very hand-holdy. It purposely drops you in a situation with fairly little guidance outside of the first few hours and leaves you to your own devices. That said, recent changes like the mission system have made things easier by pointing out short and long term goals.The developer is active and about once a month there's a big patch. Usually that means extra functionality too, new machines and/or new abilities. Often there are some nerfing changes that force you to rethink some things, a bit annoying at times but ultimately for the better (or so one hopes).I've had this game since it was in early access and it has really gone a long way since then. Back then it was a nice demo which showed a lot of potential. Now it's a downright good game that's getting better every patch.

content:

Early Access Review
								For those of you who's initial thought is "this is Minecraft in another form", this is not true. The only thing it shares is the "block building". Vanilla MC does not have process automation such as mining ores, ore processing, power distribution grids and so forth. I've played both and they each have their strengths. Even though the game is in early access, the devs are very active in both updates and in the forums. I'm happy to be part of the group who are playing this game as it matures into a polished, completed product.I hope you enjoy this game as much as I do.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												This game is alpha at best. Doesn't say early access on the steam page though. Buyer beware...The graphics and sound effects and music are all very amateur and at times downright glaring and annoying. Some graphics are completely out of place  in the game compared to others.The survival game experience is completely unbalanced, certain resources such as power are massive bottle necks with almost no upgrades for a very long time. The difficulty settings to make survival have any point have a massive gap between too much and too little. If you want there to be ANY reason to defend your base against raiding bugs, you have to play in hardcore mode with permanent character death, which will happen in some cheap, unavoidable way at some point. Otherwise, your CPH being destroyed just means it respawns 10 seconds later. You can completely ignore the tower defense part of the game until end game when you are trying to complete the "win" condition.The game has potential, and maybe in a year or 2 it'll be where it needs to be to be a complete game. For now, just play Factorio or Terraria
