content:
Posted: January 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								Fortresscraft is a fun game in the places it works, but there's a ton of emphasis on that, because there's a lot of places it simply doesn't. Because it was originally made for the Xbox, the controls on the PC feel terrible and stiff, and the frame rate is consistently below 6o fps. This could be just me due to not having a high processing power but while I had Skyrim on my PC, it was never as bad as how this game performs here. Building is slow and I feel like the UI is far too much of a struggle to put up with. Furthermore, this game is still in early access even though it's been in development for more than two years. What has hindered te development this long, I really can't imagine. I enjoyed what I could do when it worked, but I feel like compared  other titles of this genre *coughcough* Minecraft/Terraria *coughcough* Fortresscraft doesn't add up in end. Not every game can and should be like the rest, but it should at least live up to the standards set by it's competetitors, and unfortunately, FortressCraft Evolved really doesn't do that.

number of helpful: 13 of 25 people (52%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 28, 2016
												Fast version:  This game is slow, the temperature mechanic is interesting but frustrating, the game is complicated in a non fun way, building things is okay and the monsters are annoying in a non fun way.  Everything is constantly in a state of waiting on everything else, playtime is the devs #1 selling point. Get factorio instead.FortressCraft Evolved is like factorio mixed with minecraft.  With all the cons of both.******************************************************************************************Complexity******************************************************************************************Factorio gets its complexity through simplicity.  FortressCraft gets its complexity through complexity.Factorio has these eight raw resources: wood, coal, iron, copper, stone, oil, water, alien artifacts.  Very different and used for different ends; of these most everything is done with: iron, copper, oil.  Simple, it becomes complex as your create new resources.FortressCraft has 14 (? by the wiki) ores alone, each one can be turned into plates, wires, coils, pipes, and PCBs.  It also has 13 (?) other resources which you find, they can be very hard to find based on your starting seed. (Organic Rock I am looking at you).  FortressCraft also has 11-13 (?) items dropped from mobs that you need to collect.I will start with my frustrations with organic rock.  You need organic rock to make smelters, why? I have no idea.  Organic rock is sometimes found in caves.  Caves are dark and cold.  You only have so much battery to keep yourself warm and the cave lit, so bring 1000 torches made from coal they provide light and warmth.  But don't stand too close or they will begin to overheat your suit, stand precisely something like 1.5 blocks away from it or it is worse than not having one.The first time you look for organic rock it will be easier as you can scan for unknown objects, not all of them will show up but hopefully a couple will.  As a new player instead of collecting all of them you will likely be like, "wtf is this weird thing, i'll scan it for the research when I get back."  After this there is no organic rock scan to use later.All this to make a couple smelters.  But smelters also require tin plates and Basic PCB (the copper ones) and all the dependent research.  See the problem.  Fortunately the game starts you off with one smelter you can use, that will deliver you the high throughput of 4 bars per minute at a 4:1 ore to bar ratio.  This leads to maybe being able to make a smelter within the first hour of playing.  Don't worry you will definitely be mining enough ore with the extractors provided. The game will constantly bug you to improve the extractors and also bug you that they are constantly offline as they are backed up. If only I could smelt all this ore.You will be manually running around fetching ore for several hours as conveyors require a copper bar and a tin bar per square. 2 bars each, 2 conveyors per minute, need hundreds of conveyors to connect mines to smelters.Then you need to build the machinery to make plates, wires, coils, PCBs.  Keep in mind storage is very hard to come by as hoppers are very expensive early on, so you can't just build a storage bin for each of these materials immediately.Now you can make the research lab (if you didn't accidently spend all your research points on everything else and screw yourself permanently.)  The lab itself takes a lot of copper, but smelting copper is trivial right?  That isn't the problem with the lab though, the lab can consume 15000 power per second (pps) and the assembler can consume something like 500-1000 pps.  Up until this point power has been trivial, an extractor takes roughly 2 pps, the smelter takes somewhere around 5-10 pps.Do not connect your lab directly to your central power hub, it will take all the power just to charge its own internal buffer.  To combat this you need to make more power generators and energy lazers and probably make a new coal mine at this point, so while you are waiting on the metal to set this up, you are waiting on the lab to finish its research, also did I mention that about now you are going to get attacked, better build turrets.  Also did I mention that your lithium mine will probably have a bunch of plants eating all the ore on the conveyor you built, better build some more turrets and batteries and lazers to power it all.  But you need those for the lab too, better get more smelters going, but guess what your suit also needs all that power so you can find more organic rock without dying of hypothermia.  Also you can't leave your base because a bunch of wasps are attacking and they don't seem to stop coming and you need that lithium to build those batteries and the purple plants keep spawning and you need to shoot them too.So you run around killing wasps, trying not to die from hypothermia, out of research points, making sure lithium isn't getting eaten, and collecting metal bars so you can hopefully do something is this silly game.You have now been playing for ten hours.******************************************************************************************How it fails******************************************************************************************It is so hard to explain how needlessy complex and slow this game is.To pull from minecraft and factorio, the furnace is made out of stone blocks.  It makes perfect sense, the limiting factor is how much ore I can find.  Which leads to needing more furnaces, which leads to more ore, etc.  It is an exponential that I want to ride up.To mine something in FortressCraft it needs an extractor, lets assume we have those.  They need power, each one needs at least a basic laser of power.  Lets assume we have those.  They each need to have line of sight to that laser or have batteries to connect them all and the laser needs to be powered likely by another laser.So what should happen is I run back and forth making this mine amazing and making my smelting amazing too.  But you are bottlenecked constantly.  Your new basic smelters will take 8 ore per bar, so we need about 4 extractors.  Which is 4 basic lasers, which is either going to be some crazy triangular setup to keep line of sight or you are going to need 16 ish batteries.  For each of the three basic ores, maybe more lasers for lithium as it is found deeper underground and more everything for copper as you will need a lot.That many lasers just isn't going to happen early on so we will need to upgrade.  Good news there is a better type of laser available early on, the MK1 laser is 10x stronger than the basic laser.  So we can just point one in that direction easy.  Next the conveyor belt can only carry one ore at a time, so perhaps we need to use normal conveyors instead of basic conveyors but replacing the conveyor is being bottlenecked by the very smelting we are trying to upgrade.  So lets just smelt the bars right at the mine its an 8:1 throughput increase.But each smelter takes a full MK1 beam of power, now you are running multiple MK1 lasers to your mine and you have the same problem you had before.  Plus smelters stop working at lower elevations (for some reason?).FortressCraft is like 4+ seperate linear functions instead of one happy exponential.  And once you finally decide to stop increasing one of those functions none of the others can increase either.  For myself it was power for the lab, I just stood there feeding plates, PCB, and research packs into the lab for hours.  It was already running 10 power generators out of energy, even at that my 1 million coal mine was already draining faster than I would like.It is always the same answer: There is a solution to that, that you can't make.  I can't even talk about how research works as I am out of space. Basically you scan unknown blocks, there are only so many unique blocks in this game.

number of helpful: 34 of 67 people (51%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is in early alpha and might be a lot of fun, when it is completed.At the moment however, it lacks the simple design of its predecessors (i.e. Minecraft?) which left me cursing several times.It all starts with a rather buggy menu - there is a small camera driven animation which hovers in front of several signs....which - unlike any current games - do not light up when the mouse hovers over them.Getting into a single player mission is even worse because you have to click the empty space in the middle of the screen (no text or anything like that to actually tell you to do so).When creating a world, the dialogs appear unresponsive. (you click the button - wait for a second or two, click again, ... until you are thrown into the world)In game there are some nice mechanics, namely the survival against the wild system. (your suit keeps you warm on a frozen planet and if its power is fully depleted, you die after a short time).But in my opinion, this is one of the biggest flaws at the moment:There is a brutal world out there, trying to kill you and you have to fight it from the very beginning - without much help or direction from the game.While several games have recently tried this "do what you like and see what comes of it!"-approach, this game has you fighting for your life from the very first moment and thereby hinders any attempt at  a shallow start (again, think Minecraft: hacking away at those mud-cubes, only to find out they're almost worthless - but you didn't die from that and could switch over to actually mining something useful)However, there are too many unexplained phenomenons to actually rush into this game without any knowledge.After reading a few guides it might start to make sense that you should simply search for coal to power your equipment - but if you've yet to read those guides you might spend the first attempt at survival cursing.Simply because you start with several fancy technologies in your inventory and can't place them or know what to do with them in the first place.Then there is the awkward mining process - it feels counterintuitive having to repeatedly press the mouse button to mine. (why can't I keep it pressed like in Minecraft and it simply keeps mining?)I'd say its got potential once several flaws are fixed.But at the moment there are simply too little hints to actually get started and enjoy the game without reading several guides.

number of helpful: 154 of 307 people (50%) found this review helpful10 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								--Update 8/15/15--Dev warns Steam users not to purchase game."DjArcas ‏@Fortress_Craft Aug 13Review : "You should not have released this feature until it was 100% bug-free"YOU shouldn't have bought an Early Access game. ¬.¬"---FortressCraft could have been a really great game, but I cannot recommend it in good faith. I say "could have been" because development has all but stopped, even though it's still in Early Access. There are currently game-breaking bugs, such as segment loading/saving errors that result in lost items/constructions, invisible walls, unloaded blocks, etc. Sometimes half the world just doesn't load and everything you've built gets deleted. What is FortressCraft Evolved?There are two modes: Creative and Survival. Creative is the same as any other generic Minecraft clone. Survival is a bit more interesting, and it's where I spent most of my hours in-game. The premise of the Survival mode is a mix between Factorio and Minecraft, where your mission is to basically collect resources and build infrastructure with the end goal of...automating the collection of resources to let you build more stuff. There are "plans" to include enemies/combat to give a bit more of a challenge for players who don't just want to mine. Right now exploration isn't that fun. It's a fairly bleak surface world with repetitive caverns below.Why Should I NOT Buy This Game?Game-breaking bugsLack of updates from dev teamPoorly thought out game elements (e.g. The math behind power delivery is completely broken. When you connect batteries, they do not share power instantly, it "leaks out" over time. Even with fully upgraded lasers, which transfer power from object to object, it's impossible to fully power the most advanced types of objects currently in game, such as MatterMovers)*Fairly boring/lack of content after first few hours (Granted, that would be fine for any Early Access title, but this game has been in Early Access for YEARS now and has completely stalled)*Note: Some of these issues have been fixed by a third-party mod, called LazyMod. Yes, a player made fixes to the game that the developer wouldn't/couldn't. The game Developer then asked the mod author on a Steam forum how he was able to manage these things...that's a bit disheartening. Why Should I Buy This Game?You enjoy automation/upgrading/resource collectionYou don't mind weird glitches, placeholder graphics, or reverting game save filesYou want to support an independent developer who has, in all honesty, probably lost interest in the game

content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												My primary reasons for enjoying this game are that unlike modded minecraft, this game was designed from the ground up to support these complexities. As such, you can create large numbers of machines (with animations) working in one area without the performance issues minecraft encouters. Also, the multi-tiered ore system is enjoyable, with different environmental hazards at different levels making digging deeper interesting.The downsides I find with this game are primarily in its aesthetic. There are no biomes excepting the default snow/hill template. This makes the surface world uninteresting to explore. Also, the lighting effects need some tweaking as they reflect off of machines/conveyors in odd ways and make playing the game at night, or attempting to make the factory indoors less enjoyable.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game seems to get a lot of crap from other players, and I see what they see. However, with a little time, reading, and work I actually started to have fun playing this game. The confusing interfaces, controls, and something else about the general feel of the game is outputting, and when I first launched it, within 10 minutes I slammed the book shut and stored it on a high shelf. But I gave it a second chance, this time more open hearted. The game is playable and fun, you get to mine, use the resources, build machines, and expand. You just need a guide to do so. The interfaces? Very counter-intuitive and inconsistant. Overall the game is rather well done, has room for improvement, uses a great concept I'd love to see more of in gaming (automation of resource refinement), but just has some painfully rough edges. If the developer(s?) would devote one long, productive day solely to interface enhancement and a bit of easier to understand starter stuff, then the game would feel a lot better. Also, remember, this is early access! It definitely feels it deserves this flag, and I hope it can fix these issues. If so, this game can definitely be something great in my library.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								I really want to recommend this game, but I can't.  Writing this review, I can't decide if I should recommend it or not.Pros:-Voxel is always fun.-Building tools allow building large structures without much work.-Developers seem to care about their players, replying to reviews and all.-A TON of blocks. Even dozens dedicated to building lunar and space stuff.---------------Cons:-More demanding than most voxel games, due to shaders.-Some things just don't fit in (e.g. the weather staff's mesh that controls weather is nice and smooth, but it's a voxel game.-Annoying robot flies around telling you what block you have in your hand.------------------------I know that this game is early access, so I know it'll all get better.  This review is based on my personal opinion.

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								     Do you like Voxel based games? Do you enjoy hardcore-esc environments? Do you enjoy standing by a lamp, hoping you won't die of hypothermia? Then this is the game for you! In it's mechanics, it is kind of like minecraft. You need to mine to collect ores. But it isn't just "Punch tree, get wood". You need to loacate your crashed spacecraft. You need to fend off againts enimies. You need to stay warm, to prevent hypothermia. You need to cool down, so that you don't get heat stroke. No matter what it is, the game can prove to have difficulty. You can't simply afk and let all of your ores melt, you have to sit in just a precise place, so that you don't overheat, or freeze.     But, it's not all hard. The game also serves with a small robotic friend(Who needs power, go figure) that helps you out. He doesn't do much, but he can keep your suit powered, so that you can maintain your heat levels. You can explore giant underground tunnels and caves, with boundless possibilities! You could simply enjoy walking around on the surface of the planet.     I reccomend this game. Not because I play Minecraft and other 3D voxels, but because it has good mechanics. Sure, at first the game is confusing, but aren't all games confusing before you learn how to play them?

content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
												Epic game.  Quite feature-rich and playable, while still being in active (and community engaged) development, yet designed with the innate desire (I would say promise, if this wasn't the world of software with its ever-emergent unknowable bugs) that its development will never force a world reset.  The dev is on the forums almost daily, actively engaging with users re: feature tweak/addition suggestions, bug reports, balancing issues... rather than buying a buggy in-development game and getting cryptic or dismissive responses to your suggestions/issues from the obvious PR arm of things (as opposed to the techies who know what the bleep you're talking about), you're buying Minecraft-esque access to a living, /thriving/ beta version, with much less endemic issues than Minecraft, ALONG WITH front-row tickets to real-life large-scale game development unfolding in front of your eyes.And, it is incredibly well-optimized when it comes to visual/computing-resource playability.  My favorite feature of the game, far and away, is found not in the gameplay, but in the settings menu: click a checkbox, set your target framerate, and the game will take ahold of the quality and render distance settings in order to keep you achieving that.  In a frenetic base with umpteen-gazillion things going on, it'll automatically turn down shadows and maybe kill the render distance - just like our IRL brains would tend to focus on a small subset of the goings-on in a real hectic factory - while during landscape exploration, you can get the voxel equivalent of Skyrim's brilliant vistas.  (Hint to DJ: World-gen structures of awesomeness maybe?)Geeky stuff aside, the gameplay... wait, never mind about "geeky stuff aside."  If you just want another alien shoot-em-up with resource management and base-building mechanics in the tactical background, then this game isn't for you.  If you want a tower-defense game where mobsKilled is proportional to resourcesAvailable through some arcana, this isn't the game for you.  If you want another (Modded) Minecraft, where you have the option that the base can be there just for aesthetics, or for helping you The Player become the Great Lone Warrior and Loot-Collector of Your Infinite Domain (not that many take this option, but from some of the forum posts, quite a few do), this isn't the game for you.BUT, if you want a game that blends ALL these elements, plus ever-present environmental factors, automation systems that would appeal to Rube Goldberg and Henry Ford alike, and a strong requirement to Go Forth and Explore... then as long as you can handle the irreducible complexities of such a system, this IS the game for you.  This is the game for the MacGyvers of Minecraft, the Fords of Factorio, the Kings of Kerbal, who want to apply their problem-solving, epic-failing, and grand-constructing skills to an infinite-yet-efficient landscape and a stable-yet-expanding game mechanics platform (with official modding support much closer than with Minecraft).  If you're geeky, 10/10 would recommend.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2016
												I've really enjoyed the time I've been playing this game.  The mechanics are quite simple but the interactions among them create a rich sandbox environment.Some of the recent videos posted emphasize how extensive the caverns can be.  It's not an exaggeration.  The world is immense and the 3 dimensional aspect of the game is absolutely integral.  And advanced base can easily be to scale a few hundreds meters across and a thousand meters tall (or deep may be more accurate).The developer is extremely active in the community and is constantly adding new things to the game.  I strongly recommend the game.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 10, 2016
												FortressCraft Evolved is definitely a game that can absorb a lot of your time because of how expansive and intricate it is.  And that's a good thing!  I find myself constantly experimenting, changing, and iterating my systems to take advantage of new tech or just to maximize efficiency.  As of this writing, I have 200+ hours in game and I plan to at least tripple that.At first glance, it might look like Minecraft or Factorio.  But this game is much more than that and really isn't comparable.  This game rewards efficient, scalable design, not one-off systems.  You can do many things by hand, but eventually, everything must become automated.  And that is a good way to understand the game.  You must automate everything.For the price, this game is definitely worth it.  I've spent more on games that I've played less.  Additionally, the planned expansions sound exciting and definitely something I will want to play.My recommendation: if you like designing or building systems, this game is a must-have.Quick update: I'm now well over 400 hrs in game and still loving it.  The developer continues to add to and improve the game with more great features.  This is a fantastic game.

content:
Posted: May 1, 2016
												Great Game! Wish there was a survival mode with infinite stuff in inventory so you can just explore and play with stuff just for fun. It does not make sense that it stays cold throughout the whole game except in the magma layer. it is really weird. in real life after a certain depth, the deeper you go the hotter it gets. I can't wait till water and realistic liquid physics are added. Can't play this game easily because of difficulty of crafting and stuff. but I have been watching vids of the game and it looks awesome so far and it has a lot of potential. needs some changes regarding temp. and stuff to make it more realistic. Survival needs a mode where everything is already crafted and put in inventory so we can just have an exploration mode with all the biomes, survival elements, and enemies of survival, including the nova, and you can still die in this exploration survival mode. I noticed dripping water sounds underground, water can't flow if it is 10 below C.  I noticed sandbox mode does not have biomes and stuff, and it is so LAME! sandbox mode should just be in the survival world. Be ready for a LOOOG time crafting and seeking stuff out, and building a base, here is a tip. watch some youtube vids about this game so you can learn tips and tricks, and get base ideas. This game is a good buy, if you can get into this game and start enjoying it, you will have HOURS of playtime. in my opinion exploration is the best aspect of the game.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 16, 2016
												An amazing game!!I have put a lot of time in the last few months into this game and keep coming back to it almost daily to try new strategies and to see what dev has added to the game (which is done almost daily).   I have never personally experienced a game that had such an open forum for the development of a game.  As a long time game player from games back to Everquest, WoW, Minecraft, etc (and even back to the days of Zork and before) I can't remember ever having the opportunity to give feedback on something and have it actually become a part of the game.   (Don't expect every idea you come up with to be implemented, but if you have a well reasoned and thought out idea you stand a shot).Fortresscraft takes some work.  If you are looking for a game you just start up and have it hold your hand all day while you mindlessly hit a few keys, then this might not be the game for you.   But if you like a challenge and are looking for a game that is constantly evolving and growing, a communitity of players who will help you if you have questions, and a game where you can go online and watch the developer streaming as he builds new game content then you may want to consider this.I am addicted to the game and although I have a lot of hours of play time I am nowhere near completing it.   Like the old saying goes, "it isn't about the destination, it is about the journey".   The journey of playing Fortresscraft Evolved for me has been a blast.   I only wish every game I had ever purchased had given me so many hours of fun and enjoyment.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2016
												I've really enjoyed the time I've been playing this game.  The mechanics are quite simple but the interactions among them create a rich sandbox environment.Some of the recent videos posted emphasize how extensive the caverns can be.  It's not an exaggeration.  The world is immense and the 3 dimensional aspect of the game is absolutely integral.  And advanced base can easily be to scale a few hundreds meters across and a thousand meters tall (or deep may be more accurate).The developer is extremely active in the community and is constantly adding new things to the game.  I strongly recommend the game.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 10, 2016
												FortressCraft Evolved is definitely a game that can absorb a lot of your time because of how expansive and intricate it is.  And that's a good thing!  I find myself constantly experimenting, changing, and iterating my systems to take advantage of new tech or just to maximize efficiency.  As of this writing, I have 200+ hours in game and I plan to at least tripple that.At first glance, it might look like Minecraft or Factorio.  But this game is much more than that and really isn't comparable.  This game rewards efficient, scalable design, not one-off systems.  You can do many things by hand, but eventually, everything must become automated.  And that is a good way to understand the game.  You must automate everything.For the price, this game is definitely worth it.  I've spent more on games that I've played less.  Additionally, the planned expansions sound exciting and definitely something I will want to play.My recommendation: if you like designing or building systems, this game is a must-have.Quick update: I'm now well over 400 hrs in game and still loving it.  The developer continues to add to and improve the game with more great features.  This is a fantastic game.

												Great Game! Wish there was a survival mode with infinite stuff in inventory so you can just explore and play with stuff just for fun. It does not make sense that it stays cold throughout the whole game except in the magma layer. it is really weird. in real life after a certain depth, the deeper you go the hotter it gets. I can't wait till water and realistic liquid physics are added. Can't play this game easily because of difficulty of crafting and stuff. but I have been watching vids of the game and it looks awesome so far and it has a lot of potential. needs some changes regarding temp. and stuff to make it more realistic. Survival needs a mode where everything is already crafted and put in inventory so we can just have an exploration mode with all the biomes, survival elements, and enemies of survival, including the nova, and you can still die in this exploration survival mode. I noticed dripping water sounds underground, water can't flow if it is 10 below C.  I noticed sandbox mode does not have biomes and stuff, and it is so LAME! sandbox mode should just be in the survival world. Be ready for a LOOOG time crafting and seeking stuff out, and building a base, here is a tip. watch some youtube vids about this game so you can learn tips and tricks, and get base ideas. This game is a good buy, if you can get into this game and start enjoying it, you will have HOURS of playtime. in my opinion exploration is the best aspect of the game.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								I picked this game up yesterday, because it's only 4 bucks, and I liked Minecraft quite a bit. I was hoping Anthony's review was a bit of an exaggeration, but even after dozens of hours playing Minecraft, I was pretty lost after about a half hour playing this game. There were birds flying around that I couldn't kill, with text attached to them about crafting (Not sure if this is a bug or one of many confusing features), and even with tutorial screen at the beginning, I was still clueless. It kind of feel like it was written for someone who already has a lot of experience playing this game. I think I was supposed to find my crashed ship, but when I went to the area where it seemed to have gone down, there was just some "power thing" floating well above where I could reach it. I was able to mine a few rocks and trees, but couldn't seem to craft anything with them but torches. Even after chopping down trees, I saw no way to turn those into planks, or construct anything. Survival mode in Minecraft starts you with nothing, and no endless menu of things you could eventually build, which eases you into what eventually becomes a very complex game. I'm not sure how much more complex this game is supposed to be, but it's almost impossible to get into a game when I don't have the slightest clue what I'm doing. I'll try watching a Youtube tutorial on how to get through the first few days, but since this is still Early Access, I'd really recommend to the developers that they consider a very basic, starting from scratch, survival mode, and slowly introduce new features. I usually don't need my hand held figuring out games, but this one almost requires it. Assume the people playing your game have never even heard of a game like this before, and teach them how to play it. Right now, a 6 page tutorial on topics that make no sense to a beginner, isn't helping. I think I could really get into this game, but right now it's almost impossible, even if I wanted to. Please consider a more basic starting point for beginners, Devs, and teach as we go, rather than bombarding us with a bunch of information and features from the get go.But all in all, I'm going to recommend this game because it is Early Access, and the Devs do seem dedicated to making improvements.TL;DR: Survival mode is incredibly difficult to figure out, even if you've played Minecraft, but at this price point, this game is still worth picking up.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								I am right on the fence about recommending this or not so I will go forth and say at its current sale price of $3.99. The game is worth it. In the main game you start out in a seemingly random area with a supposed crashing ship that is locked on until it crashses. You find your crashed ship via light beacon piercing high through the sky. Your initial objectives is to stay warm which is done by burning trees or if you are lucky, coal if it is within eyesight. From here on out is just a slow climb to gather resources like coal , iron and so on to get upgrades and eventually some sort of automation of ore harvesting and smelting. There are some interesting features like the ore scanner which scans blocks and is further identified at your reasearch station . It also lets you scan for things that you have not identified, useful for finding new ores or for ones you have previously found. There are a few useful features that are thoughtful and useful and they blend in with game mechanics as to not seem overpowered.  This game is not without its flaws. There are a number of bugs I've encountered. -When your ship crashes you cannot relocate your starting area without some sort of tool later in the game but it glitched and I accidently had it placed far from my base and I couldnt basically continue reasonably. -Saving your world and continuing later seems to initiate that crash scene again and again, destroying everything I've built that was in its crash radius, though it left me with 2 starting areas. I lost everything in my inventory though. The menus are convoluted and half of the buttons seem to work correctly. For example when crafting there are arrows that let you change the quantity of the batch but the arrows dont change anything as if they are just apart of the graphics.All in all if you like these types of creative games. I would get it on sale as this game has great potential but dont want to risk much more as we all know early access has just become a legal excuse to sell an unfinished product.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								     Do you like Voxel based games? Do you enjoy hardcore-esc environments? Do you enjoy standing by a lamp, hoping you won't die of hypothermia? Then this is the game for you! In it's mechanics, it is kind of like minecraft. You need to mine to collect ores. But it isn't just "Punch tree, get wood". You need to loacate your crashed spacecraft. You need to fend off againts enimies. You need to stay warm, to prevent hypothermia. You need to cool down, so that you don't get heat stroke. No matter what it is, the game can prove to have difficulty. You can't simply afk and let all of your ores melt, you have to sit in just a precise place, so that you don't overheat, or freeze.     But, it's not all hard. The game also serves with a small robotic friend(Who needs power, go figure) that helps you out. He doesn't do much, but he can keep your suit powered, so that you can maintain your heat levels. You can explore giant underground tunnels and caves, with boundless possibilities! You could simply enjoy walking around on the surface of the planet.     I reccomend this game. Not because I play Minecraft and other 3D voxels, but because it has good mechanics. Sure, at first the game is confusing, but aren't all games confusing before you learn how to play them?

content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
												Was great, but it turned into a boring grindfest.There was so much potential in this game, and I liked it for a while, but I can't really recommend it anymore.  It's changed into a money grab and you can tell that the passion has left this game in favor of "what shiney can I put in the game next."  This game heavily suffers from unpolished feature bloat simply for the sake of bringing in more cash.  For instance:1. You have 1! biome, so forget exploring.  From the moment you step foot on the planet, you've seen everything it has to offer until you dig down for miles.  2. Grind for the sake of grind.  The equipment tiers are mostly just numeric advantages with color change, and very little functionality differences.  This is just to waste more of your time.3. Huge vertical distances, just for the sake of it.  I'm not kidding, you can dig a very long way down before reaching the different levels, and this would be a feature if it weren't such a barren emptyness that you are digging through.  There's no point to the far distances other than to add to the transportation grind, and just to say "it's a huge world!"4.  Dev prices things to fit his financial needs rather than to be competitive in the market.  The expansion has a price tag of 15 bucks, which is more than the original game!  A complete "screw you" to the loyal fans who bought the game originally.  Hell, I payed less for fallout 4 expansions than I would if I were to buy this one, and that's a AAA title!  Get real.5. Monsters are an afterthought, with no real pathing, pathetic AI (because the dev can't be bothered) and a silly minigame based on your production levels.  There's no real threat at all to yourself except from falling damage.All in all, these things make the game feel unpolished and the dev seems to have an obsession with gadgets and machines and cares little about gameplay.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								Bought this on sale for only $2.24 (I feel like I stole something!!!)....after almost 40 hours invested, even in the early access stage it's worth ten times that. As mentioned in other reviews, think tech modded MC and Factorio had a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ child. Hate using MC as the reference, as it seems almost every vox type game gets compared to it....but, unfortunately popularity & timing made it the "benchmark", and in my opinion, this game will well surpass that mark in unique playability. Love the fact that it's not overly easy to "run away" with production like some of the MC mods....you know, the ones that you play 3 hours and you no longer have to do anything except design a new house....the exploration & mining remains a requirement. I love laying out mines & methodizing my gathering/processing lines....Not much of a "builder" fanatic, I stick to industrial style buildings, so my typical asthetic is: square, gray, door, mine, the end....so can't really comment on the building aspect. Already polished for the stage it is in, going to enjoy watching it grow....at the time of this writing, dev released another primer for the next update, so no worries about the "dev mysteriously disappeared after selling X amount of unfinished product" as I've bought into many times prior, I'm pretty sure they're here to see it through. Love the game, love the genre.....if you're reading the reviews, then you should probably grab it before it hits the finish line & prices go up to what it's truely worth!!Finally found a gem!!

content:

Early Access Review
								Monotonous version of Minecraft with machines. I don't know the first version on X360 but Evolved, in this Alpha stage, isn't so appealing. Wait until Early Access ends.Why i didn't like it so much:1- Graphics is the real problem. Low framerate on Good preset (but it's good on Simple, so kind of OK). Models are horrible, especially block ones (like ore deposit boxes, ore extractors, ore refineries etc.). Also still buggy, time by time i see through blocks; can't see distant lands.2- Survival mode? What is that? The only survival in-game is hypotermia which doesn't affect your gameplay. You only die and respawn. Ah, and your robot companion needs a power core. That's all.3- GUI isn't so useful.4- You have to identify every kind of block which i found it as a donkey work.5- This game needs small amount of interactive guides imho. Only a small amount of them.I'd like to make a more solid recommendation but it's unbearable in this state so wait, don't buy it now. This is my last Early Access title, i guess. I'm not a type of feedback guy, so, i shouldn't buy alpha and beta stage games. You shouldn't too, if you feel me.

content:

Early Access Review
								Terrible. Multiplayer is very glitchy, and messes up your inventory, among other things. You can only go a few minutes away from your base because you have to constantly recharge or you'll die. Even worse, the station you start out with can't be moved, so you're stuck in the same area. The ores required to advance in the game are so rare that you die before you can bring them back and recharge. View distance is limited, making it look awful. And if you want to see in the dark, you have to use a headlight, which consumes power extremely quickly.

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 29, 2016
												Take a pinch of Minecraft, add a dash of Factorio, bake at 400 for 10 minutes and you have Fortresscraft.Pros-Infinite 3D world        -100's of hours of entertainment       -Many options to change the way the game goes on each playthrough        -community and developer are very active on Steam discussion boards       -constant patches adding new things for FREEPros/Cons- Since game is still "under development" things may change drastically to the point where old setups will not function the same way. This can be a good thing if you like the challenge.Cons- For inexperienced gamers this game may be a little difficult to get into due to (IMO) insufficient tutorials and guides. (Edit Tutorials and guides have been added/advanced)        -If you're looking for a Tower Defense game wherre you can channel your enemies down a certain path, this is not one (enemies fly right through walls). Overall I would suggest you just try it out. It's not expensive and you can get 80+ hours of enjoyment before looking for DLC. And if you get to that point, the Frozen Factory expansion likely would add another 100 hours of gameplay (depending on skill level).

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
												I have been playing FCE for a few weeks now and can say that it's scratching itches I didn't even know I had, along with others I knew. The game is early release so understand that it is not completly finished and evolves. Sometimes things get nerfed to ensure balanced play, reduction of exploits that deminish the fun quality. But also things are constantly added, and new features arrive on an almost daily basis (when using bleeding edge version). Additionally a fair number of mods have been created, with more on the way that make your life even easier. Think of factorio and minecraft put together, but in a super cool symbiotic way. Follow the tutorial. Sometimes things are spelled out to you but you just have to look (example blue text hints that flash occasionally), or the mission system that shows outstanding items. Do them in order and make your life easier. the key to everything is automation, but it can take a little bit of time to undersand that and get setup. There are also modes for those who need an abundance of resources to blast through the game as quickly as possible. Think real mines in the real world...ore comes out of the ground, transported to crushers, and smelters and then transported further. The game thrives on being very spread out, and you have a huge world to do this in, so spread out! Think giant fortresses built that consume your resources. I'll be enjoying this game for a long time to come. You ask, is this worth it? Yes, for sure, at least in my opinion, and I've been a gamer for many years, of different flavors.

content:
Posted: August 8, 2016
												Totally hooked. 15 hours in and I've barely even scratched the surface. Never thought setting up power relays. mining conveyors, and weapon platforms could be so fun. The graphics are fantastic and every machine I've used so far has very clean animations. Has a decently high but fun learning curve and screwing around with components, reading the very in depth help menu, or asking people on the discord can clear any confusion up quickly - even the devs are on the discord. I've played minecraft with over 200 mods on a single server and it doesn't even come close  to the things you can do in this game, the pictures I see posted constantly of other peoples creations just make me want to work towards that point even more. Not to mention once you get to a certain point in the game you have to set up defenses to start killing waves of enemies that show up to visit you every now and then.For those of you thinking this is just a minecraft clone are dead wrong. Highly recommended.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23
												This game has a lot of elements: Exploration, Crafting, Automation, Logistics, and some tower defense.The game begins with a survival feel. You craft, with a strong push to automate. As your base grows, some basic tower defense elements emerge.The cave systems are vast, and exploration is necessary to progress. A few hours in, you will realize this game dwarfs minecraft by thousands of meters. This game is not minecraft, despite the voxels.Factorio is commonly compared, and it does take a lot of elements from this game.Extensive in-game help and mission system helps to shorten the learning curve. If that isn't enough, there are hundreds of youtube videos covering most every aspect of the game.Networking & server support.Modding supportThis game gives you more for your money than most. It is actively being updated, and is constantly evolving towards the dev's vision.the Frozen Factory expansion is well worth the price adding easily another hundred hours of content after the base game.

content:
Posted: July 22, 2016
												If you like creating, efficiency, logistics and exploration then this is the game for you.  You will spend hours figuring out the best way to run your base.  Get it right then have to redo it cause you need to move to a higher tier of building.  You'll have to manage power output, which metals need to be transformed into wires, coils, plates and PCB's, probably more I don't know about yet cause with my time played I don't think I've reached tier 2 yet.  Which all can be automated on factory like assembly line.  This game can be addictive.  It's the next generation of Civilization addiction imo in regards to the 1 more turn.  But with smelting enough bars to craft that item or research that upgrade to progress your operation.I noticed some reviewers don't like some of the changes, which I don't get, from what I understand the changes made added more logistical problems to solve.  Which in my book is a great thing.  This game has so much depth to it you just won't believe it.  Oh and I forgot to mention you will have to defend your base against attacks.  So yeah theres that to.The game is a bargain at twice the price imo with the amount of content and play time I've already gotten out of it.  I was lucky enough to get it on sale and bought it on a whim after reading the description of the game and watching the videos.Highly reccomended for logistical types.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23
												TL;DR - Great game centered on logistics systems with free-form voxel construction and wave defense.8/10Factorio meets Minecraft. For those of you that aren't familiar, this game is about planning and constructing logistics systems to gather and process material (Factorio) set in a voxel based world with essentially no limits on the ways you can build with those voxels. (Minecraft) If you like Factorio, go ahead and get FortressCraft Evolved. I think you'll like it. If you like Minecraft however, you may want to watch some game-play videos, as there are many aspects of Minecraft that don't exist in FortressCraft Evolved. This one really gets your brain going. Resources are abundant on default settings, but difficult and time consuming to extract. As such, intelligent and cleverly constructed logistics systems will provide an immediate advantage to players with the smarts to create them. Maximizing the available resources is a constant goal, and to that end the player can continually upgrade or change their systems in attempt to better utilize what's available. On top of that, building is a key mechanic to the game and players can spend as much, or as little time constructing decorative building as they desire. Oh, and there's a wave defense mechanic slapped over the whole game. Not really sure how I feel about that, but it doesn't get in the way.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												I'll start by saying that I am having an amazing time with this game.That said, it's definitely a niche offering. I used to play a heavily modded Minecraft (let's start by not pretending the game isn't influenced by Minecraft), but there was always the issue of mods not working well together. Different machines needing different sources of power, for example. Then everything would break when there was an upgrade. It was a hassle. FCE provides the experience I was looking for w/o that hassle. It's more akin to a 3d Factorio than Minecraft. There are negatives, of course. FCE has the nickname toilcraft for a reason. There's a lot of manual labor involved in ramping up automation. Resources are generated slowly, and you'll spend the first several hours waiting for ore to smelt into bars, even AFTER you know what you're doing. You start with one ore smelter, and there is a lot to do before you can even build a second. I find the slower pace relaxing, but I'm old. YMMV. I like the fact that I can carry on a conversation with my wife & watch TV w/ her while playing.There IS a rapid resources mode now that makes this somewhat less of an issue, but you'll still be doing a lot of running around manually smelting stuff for hours to get things going.The world is also really bleak and depressing. That's by design, but after a while it gets to you. A bit of biome diversity would have been nice. I haven't tested it, but it also doesn't seem to have Minecraft's nigh-endless size. It's big enough, though. Summary: If you're a Factorio player who would rather work in a 3d environment, you should check this game out. If I prefered 2d overhead to 3d, I'd be playing Factorio instead of this.

number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 4, 2016
												It's hard to give this game a bad rating. Pretty much everything about this game is really good. It's fun and me and a friend played it multiplayer and absolutely loved it for about 4 days. So why thumbs down? Well there is one huge flaw that I just can not get over.In order to progress beyond a certain point in the game you need an item called a Perfect Faceted Eye. It's a drop you get from killing creatures in the game world, or supposedly get from creatures in the game world, me and my friend found none after more than four days of game play. No matter how many slimes, wasps and or other creatures we killed we never got this drop. We tried multiple worlds, increased our threat level, built slime magnets, killed everything in site for hours and hours and hours and still no drop. The problem is you need at least a few of these items to mine crystal and without getting any in drops you can't even get to the point where you can manufacture your own. Crazy huge flaw, feel like I wasted my time and money, should have multiple ways to get this item and or mine crystal and without it you pretty much hit a giant wall that you'll never be able to get around. Tutorial is a little weak too, like for the longest time I was possitive that you could not add items to the hopper. I was amazed when I found out it was the T key. LOL, no drag and drop option like everything else you literally have to select it in your hot bad, face the hopper and press T. A little funky but not enough for it to be a problem. Fix your drops and I'll come back and give you a better rating. Until this I honestly can not find myself recommending this game to anybody.EDIT: I just wanted to add that if you look online this is clearly a problem that a lot of people are having and is something that isn't taken seriously by the developers or the community for some reason. I can only guess that most people are not having this problem but after 70+ hours, my friend having played 190+ hours, and after receiving every other type of drop except this specific drop shows that there is a problem with this game. It is broken for some reason and nobody cares. It being required to progress the game pretty early makes this a really bad problem. Buy at your own risk.

content:

												This game is absolutely fantastic.One major plus to the game is that the main developer (DJArcas) streams a lot of his creation process, between bug fixes and new features, and is relatively easy to get in contact with in a variety of ways- causing a unique sense of being part of the game's creation.The game itself is amazing. Starting with the graphics, all of them are fabulous. They might as well be considered the best- loading very quickly, with little to no lag, unlike most games that try to have good graphics (even with a not-so-good laptop or PC!).On to the gameplay, there is a ton of content, tons of machines to build and resources to gather, while still not flooding the player with too many options. There is a story, somewhat, as well. You crash on a planet and try to get off (this is definitely not the best description of the story), which adds a point to the game, rather than pointless building.This may not be the most coherent review ever, but these are the main reasons (among many other) why I have nominated this game for one of the Steam Awards.

number of helpful: 9 of 18 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 20
												I really wish I could recommend this game, I really really do but I can not agree with the direction the developer is going.   I have had this game since the early days of early access, I've had fun playing it but it's never been "finished" and time after  time I have to set it aside before picking it back up due to ground breaking bugs. Scroll to the bottom for the TLDR;I've had worlds corrupted on me, ones that have had hours worth of work put into themI've had major work lost due to sudden crashesSeveral updates have causes existing worlds to no longer be loadableGranted all of these are while it was in Early Access, frustrating but can be expected from a game in development (hence putting it aside and trying it again later)Well it's been out of Early Access for a while now so I thought I would give it another go around, unfortunately there are still issues that while not "game breaking" are 'game breaking'.I have a HTC vive and the game starts up in VR mode every time, unfortunately VR mode isn't useable as the game won't load pass the world creation "into", even while loading the resolution is lowered to the point that it's not even playable.  That's fine, I can play it 2D except:There is no way to force it not to start Steam VRWhen it starts Steam VR it doesn't start it properly causing Steam VR to error out until restartedI have to catch the right time in the loading screen to hit space to switch over to 2D modeThen there the other issues with the game:Still crashes occasionallyWhen you exit the game it doesn't quit, steam thinks it's still running and won't let you restart until you quit steam and reopen steam (not just the game)There are still issues with block placement and Orientation and getting everything to align correctlyI understand that the developer needs income to continue development, and I'm good with the fact that additional content is coming in the form of DLC but am rather on the fence with the patreon content.... There is something to be said for the privilege of getting early access to something, but some of those items are in my opinion "Core" items, that should be part of the base game (Mutators, since mods break achievements) as well as the fact that the "base" game isn't finished and is still buggy.  It comes across that new content is being developed to bring in income, bugs are being fixed while new content is being made but of course new content takes times and effort (which in turn slows down bug fixing), it leaves a bad impression on me that new content is being made to bring in income before the base game is even  finished.   The fact that the content is good and useful is conflicting, I want to support the game and the developer but at the same time I won't be buying DLC for a game that still doesn't function properly.TLDR version;I really want to like and recommend this game but I can't, it's still isn't complete and New content is being released before bugs are fixed in the base game.Game is buggy, crashes to desktop.Even if you quit properly it won't relaunch unless you completely shut down steam and restart itIf you have VR capabilities (HTC Vive) it forces the game to launch in VR mode, except VR mode doesn't work

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												For me this is one of the games that I can play for a very long time.But be warned that this game is not for everyone as it is complex and takes time.Time for gathering resources depends on world difficulty and can range from fast to taking forever.Base building time is not so much affected by difficulty (once you have the resources) but takes some thought to have a good layout. You can even screw up without knowing until it is too late. For example when you do not protect your conveyor belts and have uncontrolled hive mind growth.So before starting I recommend to read some guides and/or the wiki. If you are not willing to read then you may have a hard time. The tutorial is very basic and the ingame help is not enough to understand everything in the game. There are no scenarios or extended tutorials that show you how to master the game.Once you know how things work out it is really enjoyable to build up your base and to automate the tedious processes.The frozen factory expansion is not required immediately for this because it extends the late game. Have played over 100 hours and just about to begin with the additional content. For that amount of playtime it is well worth it in my opinion.The user interface is the part of the game that needs the most improvements. It makes some tasks more complicated than they should be. If you are deterred by this fact then better wait for improvements. It already improved over time but still needs more time.My recommendation:If you are looking for a complex game that requires time or already played minecraft with technical mods like industrialcraft (especially if you like Gregtech) then this is likely a game for you.If you are looking for a game with less complexity and quicker progress you should look into Factorio first and come back once you need more ;)

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2016
Love the game.  Have played it hundreds of hours and I am still interested in playing more.Bottom line: one of the most worth it games I have taken a chance on in years. Pro:If you like building things and seeing stuff work then you owe it to yourself to buy this game.  The game also has an interesting tower defense side to its gameplay where part of the stuff you build needs to be geared toward taking down waves of angry bugs which increase in strength as your power usage increases.  The workshop mods also offer interesting options to tailor the game to your liking.  I.e. if you hate worrying about inventory space there is a mod for that.. or if you like building stuff but dont want to go for full automation you can get a mod to have much bigger hoppers.Cons:For me, the UI was not built the way I default assumed the controls should work.. however, it turns out the developer put alot of thought into how to setup the UI to allow you to build some really complicated stuff and I found that the more I played the more I was totally happy with the UI choices.There are some points when I first started the game where I didnt know how I was supposed to proceed.  With the help of google and the very friendly game forums these were often quickly resolved.Why all the drama...There are alot of reviews focusing on the personality of the primary developer and things he said in this place or that place.  Frankly, I couldnt care less if he insults everybody or offers a massage with a happy ending.  Its irrelevant.  The game is fun, and I found it rediculously worth the price.  I did not buy it because I needed a new friend and hoped the dev was that guy.[edited to fix formatting]

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 8, 2016
												Totally hooked. 15 hours in and I've barely even scratched the surface. Never thought setting up power relays. mining conveyors, and weapon platforms could be so fun. The graphics are fantastic and every machine I've used so far has very clean animations. Has a decently high but fun learning curve and screwing around with components, reading the very in depth help menu, or asking people on the discord can clear any confusion up quickly - even the devs are on the discord. I've played minecraft with over 200 mods on a single server and it doesn't even come close  to the things you can do in this game, the pictures I see posted constantly of other peoples creations just make me want to work towards that point even more. Not to mention once you get to a certain point in the game you have to set up defenses to start killing waves of enemies that show up to visit you every now and then.For those of you thinking this is just a minecraft clone are dead wrong. Highly recommended.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23
												This game has a lot of elements: Exploration, Crafting, Automation, Logistics, and some tower defense.The game begins with a survival feel. You craft, with a strong push to automate. As your base grows, some basic tower defense elements emerge.The cave systems are vast, and exploration is necessary to progress. A few hours in, you will realize this game dwarfs minecraft by thousands of meters. This game is not minecraft, despite the voxels.Factorio is commonly compared, and it does take a lot of elements from this game.Extensive in-game help and mission system helps to shorten the learning curve. If that isn't enough, there are hundreds of youtube videos covering most every aspect of the game.Networking & server support.Modding supportThis game gives you more for your money than most. It is actively being updated, and is constantly evolving towards the dev's vision.the Frozen Factory expansion is well worth the price adding easily another hundred hours of content after the base game.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
												An interesting concept, being a blend between minecraft and factorioIt's decent enough, however I personally found that the early game suffers from "many paths, only one that is any good"The tutorial teaches you about power automation, which is good.The tutorial does not teach you that you can put multiple ores into the same hopper, and the game obscures that fact by only showing you the most recent item.  It seems you 100% need to do this to get your smelter operating with any sort of efficiency.  It should be part of the tutorial.It feels like giving players access to the research path before they have _built_ the smelter upgrades and the suit & robot power upgrades is a mistake.  It consumes a ton of resources and takes focus away from the income engine.There's lots of other odds and ends you can waste resources on early game, research is just the one that got me.So the early game is not as broken as I thought, however I suspect it's been optimised for someone who already knows how to play.  New comers without existing knowledge are likely to get harshly punished for sub-optimal play.This is something that both minecraft and factorio seem to handle quite well but this game drops the ball on

content:

Early Access Review
								Aside from looking like a potato crudly taped to a monkey with down syndrome, Fortresscraft has some good Ideas... but can the company use them in a way to complement the game?Im gonna answer that right off the bat, no it can't. This game realeased in early access more than 4 YEARS AGO and I still have a better time playing the orignal one on the XBLA. This game completly fails to motavate you to do anything at all. It starts you out with a drill gun that can dig through ANYTHING IN THE GAME so I had no reason to craft a better one even if you can. It also starts you out with a ♥♥♥♥ING LASER CANNON so there is also no reason to get a better weapon either, y'know im not even sure if theres enemys in the game to shoot at. I did find little flying robot things that I could'nt collect like a perk (like in the first one) and I tried to shoot them with the Mega Death Death Ray Gun that it just gives you and it just wizzed right passed them. Speaking of robots you have a little robot thing that follows you around and shows you the block you're carrying incase your completly brain dead. Lastly, it spawns you with a 3 tourches  that emit enough heat to burn through the earths crust. See, there is this system much like thwe hunger in minecraft in here but with tempeture. And scince it spawns you in the middle of a blizzard I decided to make a house to get warm in. And after I made a house of wood and stone and waited for 5 minutes I did not get any warmer. So I dug in the middle of a moutain hoping to get warm and littarly nothing happened with 5 blocks of stone on either side protecting me from the cold. So the only way to get warm is by getting items that emit heat. But scince the crafting system is as easy to work as rubber stilts You're. Basicly. ♥♥♥♥ed. But when I was on the brink of freezing to death I decided to die in good lighting, so I set down a tourch and withing 12 seconds I overheated and died ... so ... ya.

								Monotonous version of Minecraft with machines. I don't know the first version on X360 but Evolved, in this Alpha stage, isn't so appealing. Wait until Early Access ends.Why i didn't like it so much:1- Graphics is the real problem. Low framerate on Good preset (but it's good on Simple, so kind of OK). Models are horrible, especially block ones (like ore deposit boxes, ore extractors, ore refineries etc.). Also still buggy, time by time i see through blocks; can't see distant lands.2- Survival mode? What is that? The only survival in-game is hypotermia which doesn't affect your gameplay. You only die and respawn. Ah, and your robot companion needs a power core. That's all.3- GUI isn't so useful.4- You have to identify every kind of block which i found it as a donkey work.5- This game needs small amount of interactive guides imho. Only a small amount of them.I'd like to make a more solid recommendation but it's unbearable in this state so wait, don't buy it now. This is my last Early Access title, i guess. I'm not a type of feedback guy, so, i shouldn't buy alpha and beta stage games. You shouldn't too, if you feel me.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								PROS:- Nice graphic @ 60 FPS...- awesome quick build...- only spended 2,24€ on this game...CONS:- ...but really slow graphic build up- ...with absolute no tutorial at all (if it's really only the 6 text boxes, when beginning the game, then make a better tutorial, like in Minecraft)- ...but still want my money back, because the game doesn't work at all- crashes continuous @ 60 FPS!!!- the controller support is terrible, why not using the mapping of the X360 Indie Game version?- the keyboard get's turned off every 5 minutes (runs perfect on windows)- not working achievements (follow on Twitter, Run on 64 Bit version maximum settings, only two examples)- absolute no music or ambient at all- multiplayer games not really easy to set up- crashes if I end the gameCONCLUSION:I played this game allready on Xbox 360 before and it was a great game, but here in the PC version allmost nothing works. The controller support doesn't work, you can't configure your block set, can't switch tools and many other things too. The keyboard set up works so far, but often the keyboard get's disabled for some weird reasons. If I dig down, to get on lower levels, it get's stuck at 500 blocks lower level. The graphic doesn't build up anymore and the keyboard get's disabled. Please don't tell me, it's because my PC is too weak. The game runs allways at 60 FPS, so really no lag at all. Only the graphic doesn't build up. One of my biggest issue is, that there is no playable tutorial at all. It has so many new functions in comparisson with Minecraft, that a player can't know all that. To figure it out, would be probably a very long try and error. If the heavy bugs get solved and a short tutorial get's implemented, I give it another chance. Else I declare the game as dead. -.-'I can live with not achieveable achievements, they're a nice add to games, but not necessary. ;)But bad controls and tons of crashes are an absolute no go. :'( (\s/)

								This is a great game with a good potential. However now, in it`s current state, it has two problems. First of all, it is vey, very buggy. Look at any part of the game and you will find bugs. Player falls through the floor, items cannot be moved to inventory, capacity of smelter changes randomly, sometimes items just disappear while dragging.Second problem is balance. Prepare to wait a lot and to make many monotonous movements. Dig and recharge, dig and recharge, dig and recharge, dig and recharge, dig and recharge, dig and recharge, dig and recharge, dig and recharge. Then go to smelter and smelt for an hour. Capacity of smelter is low (and changes randomly) so you cannot just leave game and go for a walk.Of course, there is automation in this game, everything can be automated. But you`ll spend hours and hours to craft automatic resource processing. And these hours will be very boring.I dont recommend this game untill all bugs are fixed and long hours replaced with brief breaks.

content:
Posted: July 30, 2016
												Well the last straw was that the machine to see what you have stored in your "mass storage" requires the DLC. However, the game will let you craft it (at large resource cost). DLC for a basic quality-of-life interface? Nope.The good: Great ideas, and many original ones.The bad: The base game is not ready. Early-access level at best. Power-creeping DLC. Some performance issues, especially with a few people on a small-ish dedicated server. Also, unlike Factorio, for example, this game punishes you for trying to automate - all factories have small costs, but all automation machines have huge costs associated with them. It should be the reverse for obvious reasons. And lastly, I have some security concerns about the mod system, as it is DLL-based.Will probably revisit in a few months if it seems like it has improved.

content:
Posted: January 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								this game may not be entirely feature complete yet, and doesnt have a clear goal, but seeing it is in active development with competent, friendly and skilled developers, i see no reason not to love this game.it is currently a sandbox creative with a sandboxy survival modes game, soon to be a game with creative and a true survival game mode with creepy crawlies...it has similarities to minecraft, sure, and no doubt people will compare the two games to each other, but it is different on a multitude of levels and scale, and in a lot of areas.i leave it up to you, the new player to find out what exactly, as i found that some players find different areas overlapping then others...as for what is actually in the game, it works for the majority and is good fun, though not to much is there yet, but if it doesnt work (properly) it is highly likely that there is work being done on the subject which fixes or improves it the next or coming update(s), and if you report a bug which hasnt been covered properly yet, the devolopers will be very happy to fix or at least as soon as they can, and they let people know what they actually do.you'll likely get a response anyway unless its considered trolling.there are currently big feature updates on the roadmap to diversify the game and improve it as far as i know, which will make this game from a good alpha/beta, to great up till amazing released game. (*cough* *transportation* *cough* *fluids* *cough* *to name a few* *cough* *cough*)i'd say if you like voxel based games, give this a try, its different from the norm with its machines and ideas, definatly worth the few bucks/euros it will cost you, though i have to warn you, there are bug, but this is normal for a young game (currently alpha/beta).i paid, and i dont regret it a single bit.

number of helpful: 8 of 17 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								Written as of Alpha 1.11 (or 1.13c multiplayer, whichever you prefer). I have not played a lot, but from the meager 2 hours there are a lot of things that, unfortunately, made this a waste of money for now. The price tag would be justified if the game weren't the mess it is now. There are ofc a lot of pros to it but the amount of cons, and the form they take, is just a little too much. Also, as much as people would love to say it is a Minecraft clone, the similarities end at "block based building" and "mining". You could just as well place Space Engineers in the same category then.Pros:- Infinite worlds, a la Minecraft (better than the 256 block height it has anyways)- Good potential for a crafting system, unlike any other Minecraft-ish game- Research, blueprints, power system, different mining modes- Much more realistic processing and production, with ore smelting, refining, and producing items and gear- "Health" system with temperature, power levels and hypothermiaCons:- Buggy UI and menus, to the point it becomes very annoying- Lack of a proper tutorial (there is one but it's messy and sometimes unclear)- Buggy creative multiplayer with no proper netcode or player sync- Extremely buggy survival multiplayer (lots of ore duping without even trying and more)- Very odd color scheme and graphical design choices for blocks and machinery (more of a personal opinion, but ir sure seems off)It's a good game, with a lot of potential, but it's a shame that the bugs and clunkiness of it made it very hard to play. I will definitely check back in a couple updates and hope it still was a good investment. For people who can cope with bugs and still enjoy a game, go ahead, but there are too many things either unfinished or (partially) broken right now. I still recommend it tho because of this future potential.

number of helpful: 7 of 15 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2016
												I purchased this game primarily to play with my son as he's a big Minecraft fan and it was appealing to him.  Multiplayer, at least "out of the box" did not work for us.  Computers would not connect and always generated a "connection timed out" and UPNP needs to be enabled or port 27012 forwarded statement within the game.  Sadly, there is no option of just clicking on your steam friends name and sending an invite.     I ended up spending over 3 hours troubleshooting this error to finally give up in frustration and decided to refund this.   UPNP was enabled on both PC's.  Port 27012 was forwarded in the router and added to the firewall exemptions. I even went as far as to drop all the firewalls and see if that would allow the games to communicate. It did not. In this day and age UPNP enabled on both PC's should just work. It doesn't with this game, or at least, doesn't with me.  Throw me in the "computers for dummies crowd" or whatever, but I can say with complete confidence that many titles on Steam and elsewhere have a very smooth multiplayer connection system that works with a few clicks of the mouse. This does not.  When I spend more time troubleshooting a games systems than playing the game, it's time for me to move on. In summary, right now the multiplayer connection system for this title  is archaic at best. It feels and looks like something I'd play in a Early Access game.   I suppose it could be a good game, and I'd love to revisit this title once they clean up their attempt at multiplayer connectivity.

I enjoyed Dwarf Fortress's user interface more than that.

content:
Posted: May 13, 2016
												The bad reviews for this game are unfortunate, because I've enjoyed many hours of play.  Fortresscraft Evolved has a lot of features I like in a game and has kept me attached to my computer screen for way longer than my girlfriend would like.  “Yeah, cutie, I’ll be to bed soon.”  But that never happens.  One recent (and ridiculously long) negative poster had 801+ hours of play!  He must have enjoyed the game much more than he admits and definitely got his money’s worth!On a side note first: I did not get this game for free, am not being paid to post a positive comment, and aren't using some fake account to skew the reviews. So for the TL:DR portion of my rant....I'd like to rebuttal some arguments about the game as to prevent misconceptions.The game is a complete, but open ended, fully playable game, and is constantly being updated with more features added and patch fixes for minor glitches.  If there are resources with descriptions like "not implemented yet" or "has no use yet, but will soon", it’s because that is a new feature only recently added to the already expansive game!  Anyone complaining (IMHO) about the game not being complete, is really only complaining that the developer refuses to stop adding more and more features to the game!  And how is that a valid complaint?!  If you think you’re going to jump into a new game, play for a bit, with the sole intent on “beating” it, you’re looking at the wrong game.  I’m sure one day there may be an end-game, like Mojang added to Minecraft much later after release.  But for now, feel at ease about spending your hard earned cash on this title. (which is cheap in comparison to much lesser games) Watch some videos.  Learn some strategies.  And enjoy the open ended-ness of the gameplay in its current high-content state.I’m looking forward to the upcoming Frozen Factory and Magma Core expansions and am fully willing to buy those as a DLC if that’s the way the dev chooses to go, because I’ve already gotten way beyond my money’s worth with the way the game is now.  Cheersies- "Don't push the button anymore, Brother!" "I love you Penny!"
