												Simply AWESOME!Warning: This game will suck up a lot of your time so prepare to have your rear end planted firmly in your seat... worth every minute though.I have read it's a clone of Minecraft... uhm, sure, if an Orange is a clone of an Apple. Mods make Minecraft what it is, and this game already has amazing content without mods.If you are into machines, automation, logistics and a 'never ending' world (there's no bottom like bedrock in MC... it just keeps going!), superb graphics, regular new content and a development team that has your constructive input and interests at heart (within reason of course)... then this game is for you.There's even a development live stream where bugs are fixed, content added, input considered, questions answered and... a cat?!!! Who else does that!?  :-D

												This is a good game that scratched a similar itch to Factorio. I don't know about you, but I love conveyor belts. While you could call this game Factorio in 3D, it's unfortunately not as polished as Factorio. It has a very annoying visual glitch (on my system) that causes power lines to be visible as flickering lines through walls, and there are some very frustrating game mechanics that are never properly explained in-game. I don't regret spending money on this game, but I'm hoping that continued development on it sands off the rough edges.

												i changed this game to recommended, because the devs are involved. But i have underlined a few aspects of the game below. This game is really fun, but i have experienced many multiplayer bugs.. something i only intend to do with this product. as i would not like to play alone. The developers are responsive and are actively looking at their forums to fix bugs. i have adjusted my review to accomodate that. My summary for the game is good. lots of play time. but there are certain things that i think will be refined over time.. and i really hope that they do happen.. i have seen many games that the devs are not actively involved in. so i hope this isnt the case for FCE. because its complex. and diverse. The tutorial is a bit lacking. but apparently the missions are intended to slowly teach the player how to do things. is this game worth the money. yes.. you get bang for your buck. is this games multiplayer experience going to improve: we have to wait and see . my bug list for multiplayer can be found here. http://steamcommunity.com/app/254200/discussions/0/359543951706440293/

												I like the game, and it intrigues me a ton, but I really can't enjoy it because of it's optimisation. I'm pretty sure I'm the one whose on the wrong side of the fence here, because my computer isn't really up to par with most of the games steam has to offer.Don't get me wrong, I REALLY appreciate the work the devs put into this game, but because I can't enjoy it due to my pc's limitations, I'd really appreciate a refund. I've only played about 8 hours of the game but most of the time, I spent trying to fix the graphical options and later having to google "how to run fortress craft with decent frame rates full screen" and watching tutorials that'd hopefully fix the framerates so that the game would be a lot more enjoyable.I just can't enjoy the game even with a tiny window; I have a knack for tolerating unbearable framerates, but I guess I couldn't bear how the game worked on my computer, as games like Minecraft ran almost smoothly here; it's been frustrating me for a while now. I hold no grudge against the developers, as I've seen lots of YouTubers genuinely enjoy the game, and I know how enjoyable the game is. But I would really appreciate it if I can have a refund.

content:
Posted: November 12, 2016
												Being slightly more casual than the average gamer, I do enjoy games you can wander away from.  While FortressCraft does not have a pause function, it does have the ability to go at your own pace, despite the developer mentioning once or twice in the community that style of play is discouraged.  I may be doing it wrong, but it is still fun (for me).Just having finished the second world in basic (no DLC) it is definatelly one of those games that eats time.  Sometimes it is just redesigning the logistics chains, sometimes it is waiting for research/smelting/manufacturing, and sometimes you are lost in deep caverns and swear the path home is just around here somewhere...As many other reviews have stated, it is a voxel game so it looks like many others in the genre, but definately has it's own place as a hybrid explorer/builder/tower defense.The game does not try for a hand-holding open world story experience.  This is about setting goals, and working with the randomly generated environment to achieve them.

content:
Posted: January 17
												Once Upon a time, there was a man named Ballerquest, he liked games like factorio and minecraft. One day he was bored, so we went to the Steam store to look for a game that would be similar to one of the games he liked.He came across a fancy game called FortressCraft Evolved. He saw that it was almost a combination of minecraft and factorio. Ballerquest decided to download the game and tried to convince other people to get the game after that. He played the tutorial and he played and he played. He convinced one person to get the game so He can have a friend to play it with, Because he was feeling lonely due to the lack of mobs that spawned. After that person got the game Ballerquest decided to try multiplayer, soon they both found out that multiplayer required a Universal plug and play. Ballerquest’s friend went off to refund the game. Ballerquest was now depressed, so he went to play some single player on FortressCraft. About a few days after that he went to make a new game due to his confusion over power supplement. He did the tutorial quickly and went to scan for known ore veins after he scanned a bunch of fauna. (Then it happened:) After scanning, Ballerquest’s screen froze. He went to restart his computer but it would keep freezing, then he tried lowering the graphics. Still no good, He then tried to scan a bit farther away from his base. His screen would still freeze. On 1/17/2017 Ballerquest had enough with this nonsense and went to put a bad review for Fortresscraft. But he wouldn't give up so easy. He now plans to install More coolants into his computer and try again. After that he learned that there is no need to get salty over a game and that there is many other games out there that are just as good as Fortresscraft. The End.	Let your hope make you glad. Be patient in time of trouble & never stop praying.								- Romans 12:12

content:
Posted: November 9, 2016
												Fortresscraft is a very good game. The game is about building an orbital power transmitter, load it with energy and use it to kill your enemies. You have to mine ores, automate production and build defence for your base. The mapping of the world into the Voxel landscape is good and believable. The progression is very long, very good and very fun. Whenever you are starting to get bored doing something you get a machine that does it for you. Also, i like that the frozen factory expansion ores are already in the main game, so you can continue with the expansion without having to start over. There are bugs and crashes, but i still give it a thumbs up because i never lost any progress, so i guess i can accept one crash or another.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 29, 2016
												First time I am writing a review here for any game! This is actually the first game where I really felt a compulsion to do so xDI'll start with a simply pro and con list for a quick reference of what to expect, before I write a bit more about it:+ lots of puzzle solving and planning ahead+ game occupies your head even when not playing it (a rarity)+ great sense of accomplishment when you see a personal project finished or succeed (I cheered when I saw my first Cargo Elevator come up fully loaded with Iron Ore, unloading it all on conveyors towards smelters)+ graphics (may sound odd for a voxel-based game, but on the higher settings it has great lighting effects+ a good intuitive 'rule-system' (the first 5 minutes is a tutorial which shows the very basic controls, but after that you will have to figure out all the rules on your own mostly, unless you want to be handheld the entire process by reading wiki's every 5 minutes. The ingame help encyclopedia (H) gives you just enough information at times, but doesn't give everything away thankfully).- Occasional bugs (I only remember falling through a lift at times, or a lift only going up to 32m instead of 64m, though that was because I was playing the game on low-end pc at the time instead of my regular pc, if I read some comments correctly)- Occasional freeze (mostly when doing multiple Coloured Ore pings too rapidly, probably my processor not being able to handle that though?)- Annoyance of the constant wasp attacks, where at one point I simply stopped building Threat Reducers since they required too much power compared to what they delivered. Besides, the penalty for not killing the wasps was absent, you only lose your command module for a minute which didn't bother me that much, since most of my power came from other devices which were not affected by the Wasp attacks.In short: Fortresscraft Evolved is an amazing game, really. I never played it's predecessor or any other 'Minecraft-clone' as people sometimes refer to these kind of voxel based games. But really, from all the MC vids I have seen, FCE really adds quite a few layers to that formula.It's been a long time since I played a game that has me thinking about it almost the entire day long. 'How am I going to deal with this or that', 'What am I going to do next?', 'What's my next project going to be' are questions that occupy my mind the entire time, even during work or on the train home :D Now, that's the sign of a great game, if you ask me.Apparently I actually bought this game during Early Access phase, but wasn't really impressed at the time (mid 2014). I only tried it out recently and it truly feels finished right now (and yet still it gets regular patches, the developer actively approaches the community for new ideas, etc.)I think the best way to express why this game is so great is through a few examples, instead of writing too generically about it. Basically the entire FCE adventure is a constant chain of small puzzles that need to be solved in order to continue:Last night I had just dug a second shaft towards a Lithium deposit, right next to an older shaft which had a Iron deposit I was already mining and sending upwards using a cargo elevator. These two shafts were only separated by a wall of 1 voxel wide. Within this wall I had also dug a 1x1 voxel wide column downwards to place the Laser Power Transmitters to send power deep into the earth (like the name says: these devices spread your power/electricity to remote places easily). However, this second shaft was right in between the bottom of the first shaft and the horizontal tunnel where I was mining the Iron. In order to keep supplying power to this horizontal tunnel whilst also delivering power downwards into the second shaft I had to fiddle around with batteries and Laser Transmitters in such a way that these devices were not in the path of either elevator shaft, yet still were in sight of the ore excavator at the end of the narrow Iron Ore tunnel. The solutions are often numerous, but each has it's up- and downsides. 'Do I dig an entire new shaft upwards just for these Laser Transmitters?', 'Do I widen the Iron Ore tunnel so I have more space for the batteries/Laser Transmitters to place inside the wall between the two elevator shafts?' or do I simply abandon the project altogether and find a new place to mine Iron. The answer to that last question is almost always: 'NEVER!'. You always want to find a solution, constantly analyzing the situation, figuring out the most efficient and best way to solve the numerous puzzles that you will be facing. And the beauty is: these puzzles are not bound by any hard limits (like most puzzles games, where you have 'levels' that you need to solve to proceed to the next) but they overflow in each other; the solution to one problem brings an entirely new problem with it! Or it might solve multiple problems at once! Also very important to acknowledge: You create your OWN puzzles! Everything you face is your own doing. You were the one that dug this shaft here. You were the one that decided to mine this Iron vein instead of that Iron vein. You were the one that decided to place certain machines too close together so that when you had to expand your base you ran out of room for lack of planning.I could name more and more examples, but I think the above illustrated perfectly the feeling you get when playing this game. You either crave that sensation or you don't (basically if you have a logical, analytical mind you enjoy this game, if not...  stay away :P ).

												An amazing game for the puzzle/efficiency addicts out there. I've come across from Factorio/Infinifactory, and I'm loving the increased complexity, exploration aspect and the sheer challenge of just getting to the deeper ore deposits and surviving. Taking the automation genre into 3D makes for an amazing game. The UI needs work, but once you get to grips with it, it's surprisingly easy to use. I'm personally not a fan of Minecraft, as I tend to get bored with pure survival/aesthetic building games pretty quickly. This game hits all the areas that I enjoy in one package: Exploration, problem solving, combat, automation, logistics and the challenge of tweaking your factories to improve their efficiency.The game has been rock solid stable for me and hasn't crashed once in the 50+ hours I've racked up playing, sometimes well into the small hours of the morning. I'm eagerly awaiting a more stable and comprehensive multiplayer experience. I've only just reached T2 ores, but I'll be buying the expansion anyway as a developer this good deserves support, plus I have no doubt it will add greatly to the experience.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2016
												FortressCraft Evolved is a game that takes place in the distant future. You start out in  a cinematic event, in which you haplessly attempt to dock your personal spaceship into a space station, only to be ejected by a meteor impact, and to crash on  a terrible, freezing planet. At first progression is slow. You will likely need to cling to your Central Power Hub (CPH) to power your suit, or suffer a hypothermic death. Before long, you will likely set up automated means of collecting ores and smelting them into bars. There is a ladder to progression in the sense that you must set up automated mines for new tiers of ores, set up logistics to get the ore back to the base, create machines to assemble devices, and eventually upgrade you suit to go deeper and discover newer ores. However, spread out across the planet, are creatures called hiveminds. They are encased in a thick, resinous shell that can only be destroyed with high-tier explosives/machinary. After a while, the hiveminds will become a problem, as they will spawn 'mynoks' (cis) on top of your conveyer belts, which will eat passing materials. This causes the hivemind's shell to grow, until it reaches/destroys your CPH. As well as that, there are swarms of wasps that will attack your base on the surface, and will attempt to shoot acid at your CPH to destroy it. The penalties of the CPH's destruction vary from losing the CPH's power to losing the game, depending on the world's difficulty setting. There are, however, a few ways to stop this:Using your space-aged ray-gun, powered by your suitSetting up automated turrets, powered by power cellsSetting up an ARTHER turret, a simple turret powered by power cells and controlled by your companion drone, ARTHERCharging/Arming the giant spider robot that patrols your base (this only works for surface attacks)Anyway, that's about the gist of this game. If you decide to give it a try, then have fun, good luck, and happy digging!

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20
												FortressCraft Evolved is a great game that gets nowhere near as much recognition as it should. Though often compared to other things like Minecraft, FC:E is far removed from the style Minecraft presents and should never be considered in the same vein.You're on an alien planet, for a start, crashlanded after a great big asteroid smashed into the station you were about to dock in. So, where to begin? Well, you start with a Central Power Hub, some simple machines, a fantastically powerful Build Gun (which is upgradeable) with which you can mow down mountains or build massive plateaus with little effort, and you have to find yourself some resources.With the handy Scanner, you must scan the world around you to be able to research new machines, ping for ores, and plunge the dark depths of the grandest caverns you have ever seen to discover new resources further down, beneath the surface.Then comes the automation part of the game, which is arguably the largest part and a great logistical challenge. You'll have to start with simple automation: getting Copper and Tin to your smelter. A few conveyors, a storage hopper or four, and before long you have bars with which to build new items, blocks and machines. Next comes Iron, which is deeper down in the ground. Then Lithium, though this ore is deep enough to attract the voracious Mynocks to your conveyors, which fuel a dark threat hidden in the caverns if they eat stuff off your conveyors. So, after having placed some turrets and provided enough power, you have Lithium safely automated.So, now with plenty of bars to spend on base expansion, what does an accomplished crash survivor like yourself have left to conquer? Worry not, for there are still several hurdles to overcome. Enemies will come to find your base, attracted by the increased energy your base produces as you expand. Vast deadly caverns lying below those precious Lithium veins provide new challenges and environmental dangers. Hiveminds stalk your base, lying in wait for that one block of conveyor not covered in turret fire to plant a Mynock on it.As your base grows, so do the dangers, so there is never a dull moment.That's all I will say, since you really should experience the game for yourself. I have more than 900 hours in this game, and I have enjoyed every one of them. There's nothing quite like putting all your hard work to use in calling a bombardment from orbit to exterminate your enemies. For the price, this game is absolutely worth it!

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21
												I would describe this game as huge, complex, challenging, yet fun and outright addictive. Don't bother about the negative reviews, I think it comes mainly from players who start Fortresscraft expecting to embark on a sweet Minecraft-vanilla clone, which it is not. There is a steep learning curve, but if you can allow yourself a few hours to familiarize and learn your way around the game, you will be rewarded with a great experience.One could more or less compare this to a Minecraft with many technical mods on steroids. It also roughly resembles a 3D Factorio, in the sense that the game involves setting up huge automated assembly lines and logistics networks to provide for energy generation/distribution, ore mining/refining, transportation, research, manufacturing and base defense (nervous local fauna will harass you on a permanent basis).If you love mods like Buildcraft, Industrialcraft, etc., or games like Factorio, I definitely reccomend that you give Fortresscraft Evolved a try.

content:
Posted: February 10
												To anyone who isn't sure about this game it's like a 3D Factorio, However this is only a comparison to understand the gameplay and not a comparison of quality or content. If this next sentence is a pun please pardon it. The fact Fortress Craft is 3d adds so much more depth to the game. I will warn you, this game is difficult to begin with but new "missions" guide you through the basics without actually feeling like someone is holding your hand. In my personal experience I tried to play this game and honestly I got stuck and frustrated I was trying to be reserved instead I should think big. Your save file can be created with a special mode that enables gameplay to go by a bit quicker, but even still the complexity of this game allows for so much time to be spent. Sometimes you might think, "Is the end",  "have a I finished it" and I can promise you that you'll probably stumble upon something that unlocks a whole new chapter of gameplay. I personally think it is well worth the money and as a side note the Dev are brilliant a few times I've posted on their forums about ingame queries and about 90% of those posts get a response from a Dev. The dev are always releasing bug fixes that have been brought to their attention from the players. This game is fantastic as it is but I can't wait to see what wonderous things happen in the future. Move over Minecraft FTB.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 7, 2016
												I really like the idea of this game.  It is basically heavily modded minecraft meets factorio.  You are in an open world / sandbox with lots of resources.  You can explore and exploit those resourcs similar in a manner to minecraft.  However, there are enemies which wish to destroy your base, so your resources go to teching up and building defenses.  Id love to see a lot more games like this.  I had a lot of fun, but I didn't finish it.  It does have its problems.The good:It is a wonderful minecraft like game and the designer does a lot of nice things that other games can certainly take a hint from.  For example, you can access any object at any distance as long as you can see it.  IE:  To craft things you do not need to walk to your crafting table, you just have to look at it to use it.  To pull stuff out of a storage system, just look at it, even if you are 60 blocks away, and you can access it.   Then you also get a grappling hook that lets you move around very quickly.  This is an invaluable too.   There are lots of technologies and systems to build.  The Bad:The documenation is terrible.  You have to spend research points and you only have a vague idea of what it is you are getting.  You also can research things early on that you can not build for a long time, due to tech requirments.  Also sometimes there are "packages" of research items where buying just one item is useless because you will need to buy 2 or 3 others to complete the set.  If you spend too many RP points, you may end up stuck (although ultimatly you can get out of this hole, but it can block you for a while).   The tech tree is also just a mess and the organization on the build tab makes little sense.  Often I have to search for the item I want to craft because I have no idea what tab it belongs.    The mechanics of how to progress and how to use things are often mysterious.  There is a wiki, but it is often out of date.  You shouldn't have to use an in-game wiki.The ugly:This game is grindy.  The designer just makes things take a rediculous amount of resources in terms of materials, power requirements and crafting time.  A good example of this is some machine that will take animal parts and turn them into some generic part that you can craft items with.  This machine takes a huge amount of power, and takes 5 MINUTES to craft 1 component.  You may need 20 to 80 components to craft some of the items you want.  So for 20, you are looking at 1 hour and 40 minutes.  It gets even worse, it takes 10 raw material to get 1 component.  And gets even worse, that these components will rot unless they are put in yet another setup that is also power hungry that extends their life time.  Its nuts.That is just one example, there are others, like the 100 MILLION units of power needed to charge a certain object, that you need to do 4x.  With several stacks of turbine generators, it can still take like 4 hours per charge.  This isn't fun, its boring.  Many of the crafting recipies just require rediculous amounts of material for no good reason.Summary:For the price, the game is a great deal.  I had a lot of fun with it until the grind killed me.  Maybe Ill check it out again in 6 months to a year.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
												so after a hiatus from FCE i've managed to rack up another 25 hours in the last 3 days, suffice it to say this game has improved signifigantly since i last played (around the time my first review was written) my previous review was full of candor, i was only trying to point some the holes in the progression.i would like to add, for anyone who had read my previous review ... i went into the game expecting a different game experience and it relfected that disappointment in my review. in any case i was happily surprised when i started up a new world again. before the game was simply too easy, 1 million+ piece ore veins and no hostile mobs were my biggest issues. the tech tree progression is a lot smoother now and makes more sense. Pros:-extensive tech tree progression ( lots of new higher tier machines)-survival is more apparent now-unique mobs-early game progression is much more balanced -more building blocks added (windows and a few others)-very few bugs/glitches ... reletively polished-new base defense system .. awesome :)Cons:-still some unfinished UI elements, nothing gamebreaking-no penalty for death-still no compass or map feature of any kind  .. lost your base? easy, dieing is the fastest way to find your base :)-the giant Spider bot like to step all over you a lot :P (doesn't affect gameplay but is annoying when trying to see something its standing on lol)now knowing what to expect from FCE has been a better experience for myself, so if you resource/power management and logistics and really strange mobs trying to hinder your progess constantly then grab this game. side note: the Developer seems to be a lone wolf on this game so dont' expect a lot of new content to be added on a schedule like other games. updates a little slower for this game but the dev is working his tail off to produce this game :)

								I am so into this game! number of helpful: 17 of 36 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								When I first read the game description I got quite excited as I thought of it as a Minecraft in a more futuristic environment. I've been playing for a few hours now and I find it rather frustrating. Mainly because some of the features just don't make sense and are not well explained and the worst of all: survival you're basically locked to just one world, it's NONSTOP snowy and windy and all you actually hear is the generator's humming and the wind blowing. So not only does the frustration add up, it's basically also very frustrating.I made the mistake and got my brother a license as well as multiplayer was announced and again... was very disappointed as many features were not included and to date I have not managed to actually get a server running and even if I managed, it basically would only be a creative server. No thanks.It doesn't help that the EarlyAccess information box targets a release towards the end of 2014. It's 2015 now and still far away from release. Worse: if you follow the dev's twitter (or twitch) account, you can actually follow him streaming other games. I think I stopped following him after he started playing the borderlands pre-sequel and even gloated about how much he played and streamed recently... at the time mostly borderlands. I wonder at what stage he actually tries to finish the game, rather than playing and streaming other games but his own. Obviously not much, otherwise the game probably would have been finished before the end of 2014 as promised. And I will not go into all the whining he does on Twitch and Twitter how bad money making is via steam and that he could do with a bit more games being sold etc... So far, I cannot recommend this game at all if you're interested in the survival part. I cannot talk about the creative part, but then again - it says it's survival... and as that part is certainly by far not close to be finished or any good for that matter.- world setup basically non-existant (other than free name choice)- world setup features that are in with placeholders restrict to things like difficulty, and I think the amount of resources- world setup cannot change the world you're landing on, or the weather, so you'll forever be stuck with annoying nonstop wind sounds... snow... cold... and wind... and snow... and wind... if you don't die of hypothermia, you'll either die real-life of boredom or the after-math of a depression- it's nice that conveyor-belts etc. are being big announced in the screenschots but what's the point if it doesn't explain how the system works (and that's a big downer in general... many features have no explanation, i.e. research, what gives points, why would you scan things, what's the point... etc.) and for some of the resources I ran back and forth (very repetitive) for an hour and only had enough resources for one item, far away from any automatism... I wonder how some other players managed that.Anyway, the game has been released December 10th in 2013. It's January 2015 and game is still in EarlyAccess. That should answer if you really want to buy this game or not. If you don't believe me, feel free to follow his twitch and twitter accounts. I unfollowed the dev on all platforms shortly after his borderlands streaming, if I could, I would have requested my money back at that point.

content:
Posted: April 19
												Absolutely fantastic game!Sci-fi voxel game with cool machines, lasers, weapons and monsters!FCE is a great construction/destruction type game that offers a lot of depth and creativity and I fully recommend it.You will enjoy this if you enjoyed these other games:From The DepthsFCE isnt as complex but still has a technical aspect and is very stisfying when everything works well like you imagined.TerrariaFCE is more tilted to the scifi and is 3d of course.  It feels very progressive, like terraria, and you are only limited by your imagination.Anarchy OnlineThe grind in FCE is there of course, and is very adjustable...so much so that it feels like your not grinding at times. Anarchy online of course is not a construction type game, but it has great character progression and a satisfying curve, like FCE.If you mash the 3 games mentioned above together, you get a simulacrum somewhat like Fortresscraft Evolved...I love it.  My brother and I play together on our own server and we both highly recommed it!Anyway, just my 2cents.

number of helpful: 11 of 24 people (46%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								I have mixed feelings about FortressCraft. Granted it is still in development so I'm going to forgive a lot of things, but anyhow.This is by all accounts a MineCraft copycat with a few extra features. The graphics aren't nearly as pixelated as minecraft but most of the blocks 'glisten'. though one good feature is the fact that I can copy and paste structures to quickly create buildings and landscapes and the number of block types is also really nice. controls are a bit unresponsive and result in a lot of misplaced blocks. there is also a seemingly infinite range for placing/removing blocks which, while at sometimes is really nice, is actually quite frustrating when you accidentally delete a block on the otherside of your building and have to trudge all the way over there to place it again. FortressCraft Evolved has a lot of potential to be better than MineCraft but at the moment I recomend sticking with MineCraft.

content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								AT THE POINT OF WRITING THIS THE GAME IS IN EARLY ACCESS ~6/16/2015~This game looks and seems like it could have a lot of potential but in the current state that it is in I cannot and will not recommend this game. There is pretty much little to no content that really keeps it worth while in the current state. I played 1.2 hours of this in survival mode and pretty much just gave up on it because, for one the content that is in survival mode is little to none other then just ore automation and two once you get it all up and running there is nothing to use your precious ores that you have collected and you just feel like you have wasted time. The upgrades in the game are all still in development so you cant really upgrade anything either so you don't really win at all.One huge mistake is they went upon development backwards in my opinion! They started the game out as multiplayer and did single player as a add on when they should have focused upon single player which would provide more things to do. Without a good single player core how do you expect to have a good multiplayer? It doesn't really make sense at all to me at least... Which makes me kind of sad cause this game looks like it has a lot of potential but in the current form I really just cant say too much good about it.Please Dev's don't give up on this game because of all the hate! Just keep working at it :) If the game gets to a more playable and enjoyable state I will change this review! What we need is more things to craft,upgrade, and just simply do more then building a red and blue house with our buddies. If we really wanted to do that we would get together and get out the old legos from our shelf!So overall I wouldn't recommend buying this at the current state simply not enough content and things to do!

content:
Posted: October 9, 2016
												I really wanted to like this game. The grapple mechanic is really cool, so are the glowsticks, the hiveminds are huge and imposing, and it runs pretty well. But there are multiple design decisions that are very annoying, and I found myself asking "why?!" much more often than any game since the n64 days.Here are some of the thoughts I had in the first couple hours:Is it day out? All the fog and excessive shadows are making it really hard to see stuff. Maybe I can change the gamma in the settings. I can't? That's annoying, I'll just turn off the shadows. Okay... nothing changed, that's annoying.Wow, that's a deep hole. Maybe I can find some or down there. Wait, why did it suddenly get so dark? I could see everything when I was looking down, and I can still see the lit sky above me. That's annoying.Good god! What the hell is that damned noise? Oh, it means there's a crystal nearby. I don't need those yet, so I'll just turn down that sound. Oh I can't... that's annoying.Okay, I have some ore extractors set up with automated power delivery. I should automate smelting next. Oh, I can't make  a smelter without some research. It's annoying that I need to do research for something so basic. Fine, i'll move my starting smelter so I don't need to wste time carting resources. I can't? That's annoying.Well, if I can't bring my smelter to the ore, I'll bring ore to the smelter. Wow, the conveyor belts are pretty expensive in terms of resources AND time because of the lack of smelters. I'm going to need a lot of these too. This is pretty annoying. Oh cool, lifts are much better for getting in/out of my iron and lithium mine than the grapple. Oh shoot, I can't actually get the lift shaft all the way down because there's an errant coal vein in the way that I can't remove. That's really annoying.Geez, I finally found enough of this obscure resource that I can't scan for to make smelters for all the starting materials. I finally can begin sutomating something interesting. How long has it been? 4 hours... huh... I don't feel like I've completed very much. That's annoying...Do you see the pattern here?

												This is a game that definitely pertains to creating a factory out of the world, and it's a great idea. The environment is nice and it gives a basic tutorial on how things work. However, for all of the advanced information on how everything comes together to become a complex automatic system, you're mostly on your own. I usually like to do everything personally, and this just doesn't work for me; it ALL depends on your machines to do the dirty work for you. I won't simply smack it down for others. As a matter of fact, it's a great game for industrialistic people who want to create an advanced system that works effectively. But if you are patient, and you aren't a fan of these types of mechanics, then I would say it's best to look elsewhere.

number of helpful: 9 of 20 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								Short version:FortressCraft is basically a Minecraft + tech mod clone, minus Minecraft's charm. With a side of difficuilt and awkward to use interface. Plus an extra helping of bugs (even for early access). Not recommended. Longer version:On startup Fortresscraft greets you with possibly the most detailed and intricate menu ever. This turned out to be a bad omen though as it's also possibly the most difficuilt to use menu ever. Difficuilt to the point of needing a tutorial to navigate. However after much random mouse button mashing I managed to overcome this hurdle and start a new survival world. Alas, I was one of the lucky few. We should spare a moment of thought for all those poor souls who failed to navigate the main menu, and instead flocked to Steam's forum for a solution... on how to use the main menu.Once the world had loaded and the ringing in my ears caused by the really LOUD crashing ship passed I came to another hurdle, the help screen. I quickly browsed over the help text and tried taking in as many hotkeys as I could. There are a number of them as the only way to select a tool is with a hotkey. Which you can't rebind. After skimming the help screen I tried to close it by pressing escape, nothing. Tried clicking on stuff, nothing. Only after rolling my face across the keyboard, not once, but twice! Was I finally rid of the cursed help screen. (edit: The escape key sort of works in the latest version)With arch-villan help screen defeated I was finally able to take in the world, the very bland world. This is where the clone shows through. Even the block's textures have that familiar MInecraft look, albeit high resolution. All other voxel games have moved away from cubes into their own form of voxels, and all of those new voxel games feel nice and fresh.  So coming back to a cube game can feel a bit underwhelming. Made worse by a world that has nothing going on. It's just snow and the occassional tree. Totally lacking in features that convince you this is an alien world.The actual game, in it's current state, is centered around building an automated mining network similar to many Minecraft tech mods where you have mining machines that feed a conveyor of some sort. You then need a power network to run those machines etc.  So far the stuff in game is similar to stuff I've seen in mods. Which isn't a bad thing. Expanding on these ideas could lead to somewhere interesting. But.And it's a big but. This game has a lot strange design features that either take away player agency or are there to♥♥♥♥♥♥you off. Like the decision to go against the convention of every other game in this genre, and reverse the block breaking and block placing mouse buttons. Those buttons are so ingrained now that I'm constantly wrecking my machines or digging holes when I meant to place a machine, infuriating. Then there is the bizarre inventory mechanic where you can't choose what you put into a machine. The game decides for you and it's pretty much always the wrong choice. So you have to wait around for the machine to finish then hope it chooses the correct material next go around.  Finally the inventory or lack of. The inventory is just for show it lets you know how much of each block you are carrying and that's it. Since it's non-interactive you can't organise it or anything you can usually do with an inventory. The only thing it lets you do is spew blocks everywhere via another hotkey. A number of those blocks will often get lost because of physics bugs. Spewing is the only way to get stuff from your inventory into a storage container. The problem being another container in the vicinity will suck up your block spew. Meaning you need to empty that container then try again. As you imagine can this becomes a real chore, real quick.

After 30 minutes or playtime I felt so sick that I had to stop playing and have no incentive to play this ever again.The Ideea seems good but the execution is terrible. I do not recomend this game.My rating: 2/10

								I remember when I first encountered Minecraft on a fluke. I figured hmm, this looks like♥♥♥♥♥♥visually but the concept sounds good. Several hours later.... what just happened? Did the game combine a metric ton of fun and interesting core elements making it "stupid" addictive... yep. It'd been a long time. I figured I'd snatch this $9 game called FortressCraft Evolved while I was browsing other titles. That's well spent. Even in its current form there's a good amount to experiment with.If you're impatient but also want to play survival you can modify some core xml files related to resources and a few other things. Mess around and enjoy.If you like these types of games there's quite a few that suck ballz and aren't worth playing for free. FortressCraft Evolved is one worth the current price. Time will tell as it "evolves" how much more it may be worth. Odds seem in its favor based on what I see in the content and its direction.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								where do i eve start? first the good points, it's basically miecraft with a built in tekkit mod, which i find to be amazing and if not better than both minecraft and the tekkit mod itself, why you ask? let me explain, FCE literally has infinite worlds, with no block height either, leaving the possibility to build things on a scale previously never seen in a voxel type game, there is a complete method to automate everything, which if like me you hate spending continuous hours digging and mining, is perfect, ad using tekkit as my example here, unlike tekkit where nothing is really self explanetary and you spend longer looking at a wiki page finding exactly what you need to build what in terms of resource and machine's, this gives you the basics, collect ore, smelt and craft and thats it, sure it's a pain locating said ore, but heh you get that in minecraft, the difference is i find an ore vien in MC and i get 10 ore from it, here you can get hundreds of thousands of ore before it is depleted thats a win. another plus is the fact it runs on unity... unity is great, it really is and it plays wonderfully on my low end laptop without any lag spikes, bugs or glitches, which is brilliant.now, the bad points, (yes i understand it is early access and things take time) while there is a survival mode, there is nothing survival about it other than you can freeze to death which sure, is a cool mechanic, but easily avoidable, the ingame 'guide' feel's to be lacking in information, like whats the little icon next to the lamp icon? and what is the secondary battery? things like that could use some further explination, some of the textures are a little low quality and seem 'cheap' like basic model designs, the tool for example, the animation makes the whole think look like all the parts are just hovering there and aren't really connected to each other, but thats not exactly game breaking.summery: basically this is a great game, while it lacks the features other games provide with mods, this has everything as stock, it runs brilliantly on even low end machines and i can only imagine what it loks like on a top end rig, as it is early access there are still plenty of things that can be improved on and added, which given how much i feel i get for this game paid £1.49 during a sale, is great, would i pay full price for this? as it stands sadly no i wouldnt, when more is added? certainly, at the time of review i have spent 8.2 hours game time having purchased it only two days ago, 10/10 will recommend

content:
Posted: August 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								Lacks polish on every corner unfortunately. Yes this is an early access title and yes EA can have bugs. That's not what i'm talking about.The overall concept of the game is great.The balancing and core ideas of the game are great too. It's very clever above all how the progression in survival works and forces you to preserve materials on every corner even after a couple of hours.But just about every core feature that's in the game feels irky / buggy to work with:The bad- Right click accidentally with your building gun on any machine and it will deconstruct Losing ressources that were in it and generally being a nuisance.- The whole interface is very problematic, disappearing cursor, unintuitive controls, buttons that dont work as they should. Nothing gamebreaking, you eventually learn how to work around them. Inconsistent use overall. (Some things require "e" to charge them, some need to be opened first for instance...) Annoying nevertheless.- The Energy and Transport system are cool but very annoying to work with. Moving a line one block lower because you misjudged something and built it a bit off, good luck with that, will cost you a ♥♥♥♥♥on of ressources and a blob of interconnecting logisticshoppers.- Energytransfer. We have lasers that transfer power over 64 blocks but no cables that distribute power to something 2 blocks away. Instead you have to kinda misuse batteries to connect things. I suspect it's because of the 1 block 1thing development philosophy that this game went for. In the early days of Industrialcraft over at Minecraft they used cables that measured 1 x 1meter... not a perfect solution but at least you had something to work with. If there is anything in the techtree then it's way to far down. (Solar panels before basic cables ? Really ?)- The energy grid is very simplistic and lacks complexity once you see through it. It's just batteries / machines that have energy, or they dont now distribute evenly with limited tools.- Combat... should have left it out, it just looks really bad and unfinished and doesnt add anything to the game.- Once you have a bigger base you need some sort of navigating tools so you can dig straight tunnels to where you need them because the game is seriously annoying if you have to build 2-3 blocks to connect things. The game has a holomap for that and a map that is very confusing to use and needs alot of time to get used to. Simple coordinates on the scanner would have solved this problem entirely, but no, we have a bloated graphics effect.- Death doesnt mean anything. It just ports you back with ALL ressources. Take the survival aspect out of it if death is meaningless.- Unnecessary robots flying around in your face, and the spiderbot. Have fun with the spiderbot, it doesnt do anything except block your view in your base day in and day out.- The Scanner doesnt work proper. While the scanner is cool if you scroll the mousewheel once up or down you see that the thing is buggy. Pretty much sums up how such an easy spottable bug got past the Dev or that he didn't care about it.- Graphics are somewhat dated. Not a huge thing.- The name... has nothing to do with fortresses, should have named it Factorycraft or something.- Multiplayer is very buggy. The dev is not capable of reproducing alot of the reported issues. We could reproduce them on every single client in the first try. Well... yeah.Whats cool:- Ore distribution is really cool and works better than in minecraft as it forces you to branch out the base naturally and think of ways to make things easier.- The Scanner is cool.- Energysystem of your suit forces you to be carefull about your ressources.- Progression is really smart and fun. You can't just step away 10 hours and then have a ♥♥♥♥♥on of ressources, the limited automated storages make sure of that.All in allI get the feeling that whoever programmed this is potentially a great game designer but shouldn't be the person who pushes out any releases. Have someone that does quality control and treat this as a conceptual prototype. The game lacks an overall control / ui concept and now wants to leave Early Access.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2015
												This is a well thought developer's dream of a building/exploration game in a voxel world that wants you to build a self sustaining mining-ish operation. I say mining-ish because your resources are 99% dug out of the ground, but this isn't just a dig and build kind of game. You need power to live, you get power through different means. One of these means that takes it away from just mining are things like solar energy and the ability to store the electricity in batteries. If you like a sandboc voxel game and the idea of building a self-sustaining operation this game is for you. There is also a creative mode, but I can't speak much on this because that is simply not my general area of interest. The early game has a very good push to make you want to expand and evolve. The energy requirement to keep you alive feels very real when the game starts and after about 30 minutes of keeping yourself alive I most certainly experienced the wanting to keep myself alive with less direct input and the only solution to this was building things to sustain themselves. I would say I have done about 50% of what can/could be accopmlished in an average scope of the game (not a 100% copmletionist have to get every achievement kind of view). One way I like to way games is how many good hours a got per dollar. Currently I have 65 hours and I believe I bought it at $10 (USD). That's 6.5 hours per dollar which is far above my threshold of a game that should be considered bad if you play it less than 1 hour per dollar. I definitely got hooked on this game and stayed up late hours wanting to keep playing.  One of the best things I can say for this game is the small development team. The developer is ALL OVER THE FORUM. The developer always wants more feedback and seems to spend all day speaking to players and improving the game. It gets updated constantly and has a well thought out road map of what is next.  I would say invest now. Get your money's worth and enjoy I great new take on a voxel game. Also, I forgot it is moddable and the community will help with that. TL;DRIt's a good game. (I don't give 0-10/10 because it is meaningless in a 1 paragraph review). This game is worth your money and has a great theme and support to become even greater.

number of helpful: 5 of 12 people (42%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 26, 2016
												I am addicted to this game at the time i wrote this review, while the game is still in development i reccomend getting it. Basically this game is what you get when you mix Minecraft, a few of it's more technecal mods like Industrialcraft and Buildcraft and turn it into a full blown game. If you're a fan of Minecraft with those two mods then you should definitely play this, if you're a fan of voxel games in general i also think this is worth a try.When you start off you're about to dock at a space station in the middle of a meteor shower when it's hit by an asteroid and you come crashing down to the planet below because of that. At the moment your goal is to build up a base, research the local enviroment for things you can use and send some power in orbit so your buddies in orbit can get the damaged station running. While you're doing this you have to defend yourself from the local wildlife and trying to prevent the illusive hive mind from spreading and destroying any clump of resin you find on your travels as these will give you useful rewards.Let's start off with the bad:- The game is still quite buggy and unstable (when i wrote the review) and multiplayer is even more unstable. Running the game at a graphic quality setting higher than good will almost guarantee your game will crash if not your computer at the moment.- Enemies are quite buggy, going through blocks and if they die while inside of a block they could end up breaking the block they're inside.- The game punishes you if you mine ores yourself as you barely get any ore out of veins which forces you to rely on your trusty ore extractors.- This game is fairly hands off especially late game.- The game is also quite CPU heavy, if your computer has a weak processor i'd say either upgrade or avoid this game until you do get an upgrade.Now the good:+ The worlds are randomly generated which can be good especially if you get a good seed with loads of bigger ore veins. You can even change a few settings in relation to the map such as how common ore is, how fast conveyors move items about and how strong the enemies are and so on.+ While the progression has a few places that can be improved i think the devs have more or less nailed it.+ There are a set of upgrades for your suit, your floating bot called Arthur and later on the massive spiderbot that helps you defend your base.+ Automation is fun, especially when you get all four of the starter ores and you can build a basic power grid with coal generators, batteries to store energy and lasers to transfer energy from your generators to your extractors, turrets, even your forward outposts which you will need later on as you go deeper into the planet.+ This game is so much better with friends, although you can only play cooperatively at the moment as everyone shares the same base but you do all have your own inventories.+ The devs are very active, they try to push a patch out every month and sooner if the game has a massive problem. Every now and then they'll even throw in a feature that someone has suggested, complete with an achievement if you do use something a community member has suggested.+ The game has a creative mode which has been massively improved upon from the original Xbox 360 game, even the detail blocks have come over from there.+ If you have a massive problem with your game or computer there's a neat little system which aims to lower the chance your world will break as a result.+ Research is interesting especially when you get the lab, you scan the local enviroment and analize those scans to find out what they are and get a few research points for your efforts which you spend on new recipes and early on new technologies. When you research a new technology you'll either get something useful or a new technology which can give you something useful.+ On the technical side (at least i've heard) FortressCraft is one of those few games that makes good use of all your CPU cores no matter what so if you have a CPU with loads of weaker cores so if your machine doesn't have a CPU with a set of fewer, stronger cores then you might be in luck. This can be good news especially for AMD people as AMD CPUs (as far as i know) tend to boast a higher CPU core count compared to Intel CPUs of a comparable model.

content:
Posted: May 14, 2016
												Starting out can be rough, depending on your world. I tried a couple before I found one I was happy with. It will take time.The game is heavily based around automation, so you can continue to dig deeper and find new things, then automate those new things to get it all back to your base. At first, you will have to babysit things. You simply don't have the resources to get things rolling on their own for the first hour, maybe two. Watch a couple of videos on it. You'll see how others do things, you'll get a good understanding of the basics, and you'll have some ideas as to how to set your own system up. It takes a lot of time to really get a lot going on, but if building up to that isn't your cup of tea, then I might advise a different game type. There are several more mechanics at play here than in MineCraft, and pretty much any other game in this vein. It takes a lot of the concepts explored in Space Engineers, removes space, and instead focuses on mining materials and setting them up to work for you.

Edited:I have revised my review since it appears some things have changed. In my defence, I have not played in a while and the last time I had checked the history page it was showing things like this:Originally posted by DjArcas:As with every day, come join me in my office. https://www.twitch.tv/djarcas Patch in 4 days.Share:	             Apr 18Just under 2 weeks until Patch 7 is readyCommunity Announcements - DjArcasIf you're interested in seeing what's coming, and giving feedback, head over to here: https://www.twitch.tv/djarcas And read what's already been implemented over here: http://steamcommunity.com/app/254200/discussions/0/371918937259594309/Share:	             Apr 13Did you know....Community Announcements - DjArcas...that the dedicated server has been out and available for about 5 months now! Just look inside your installation folder for 'dedicated server' - if you want to be all neat, copy that folder somewhere, and then just run the batch file on your server! Other useful links people seem to miss! ;-) https://www.twitch.tv/djarcas https://twitter.com/fortress_craft https://www.patreon.com/fortresscraftFor what looked like well over a dozen patches...But as I went to get this information to back up my review, for your 'Are you joking?' question, I noticed you've posted about 'defecting from Twitch'. I'm glad you have. However, you were in the habit of simply posting a single paragraph followed by a link. If I (We) wanted to know more we had to follow the link and/or search for the patch info on our own. Yes, I know. It's not very difficult to do so. Especially if your game is the only one I care about. It'd likely take me 2-5 minutes to locate a change log. It gets rather annoying when you have a dozen, or even hundreds of titles in your library. And frankly, I'm getting more and more tired of hunting such info down. I've uninstalled many that either do not patch very often, or patch but don't inform their fans what they're installing on their systems.Maybe some things have changed. Or rather, obviously some things have changed. Or one thing? Never mind, I'll change my review. The reason for the review was because i was uninstalling several games. I considered uninstalling Fortresscraft, then noticed I still hadn't written a review of it even though I've had it for well over a year. Maybe over 2 yrs. And what I wrote is what I remembered about the game.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								I'm going to preface this review with this short statement: I "recommend" this game because I think not recommending it is too harsh. Read on if that confuses you.I've played a lot more Minecraft in my time than I'm prepared to discuss. There's a lot wrong with that game, and FortressCraft Evolved seems to be on the right path to fixing it. I've always found creative mode in Minecraft to be dull - for me, there needs to be the chance of failure/death, no matter how slight.  I've always hated the amount of time that goes to waste just trying to mine blocks in Survival, though, and FortressCraft has taken a great direction mixing the two. I don't really appreciate that the only way you can die is freezing to death... I know you can take some form of fall damage (with a really annoying screen effect), but I don't actually know if it can kill you. But! It's Early Access, and I can appreciate that these things take time.A few suggestions I would make, assuming that the developer(s) read(s) this:-Portable block identification. Some way to make it not a pain to go back to "home base" and have to identify things before you can use them. I get that it's unrealistic for Steve? the wandering hobo to magically know what iron ore looks like and how to use it, but it's willing suspension of disbelief. Honestly, I would more readily believe that a space-man on what was probably a mining ship has basic earth metals committed to memory. -Make the particle effect for "home base" visible on low graphics (that is, if we really have to have home base to begin with). There was an interesting glitch when I first started up the game that made the ship just fly off into infinity instead of crashing to ground. Since I started the game on fastest graphics, the purple light particle never showed up... unless the ship legitimately never crashed and flew across the endless map. I reset that world anyway, so we may never know.-The way chunks load is entertaining, but I feel like that has to be taking up CPU that could be used a bit more responsibly. I don't personally know enough about this to go in depth about it, just kind of suggesting that the animation be dropped in favor of chunks "popping" into existence.In the end, the game is solid, and I really believe it has potential. It's not going to be the Minecraft killer, but that's alright, since Minecraft is enough of a danger to itself. There's plenty of bugs to iron out, but like I already said, these things take time. All I can really hope for is that these guys aren't the Terraria team in disguise, making a quick buck and running off, leaving an orphaned game that could be much more.

								So far this game is pretty great considering it is still early access.I haven't personally had any bugs or game crashes.  Game loads very quickly as well as the world generation or world loading as you move around.At the time of writing this I'm 14 hours in and still haven't reached mid game.  I would guess even at the early access level of development there is at least 60 hours of entertainment to be found.If you're a fan of minecraft you might like this game, if you're a fan of factorio or crafting / automating style of games you'll really enjoy it.The only negatives at the moment I have is that there is no real threat in surivial mode death just spawns you back to your base, and mobs have not been added yet, but again, still in development and the games current status works well.  Also the progression to being able to do anything efficiently besides manual filling/unloading miners, hoppers, etc. is a little much.  I ended my last game session to finally being able to build my 2nd smelter, which is a bottle neck that limits progression more so then having a consistant progression of acomplishments.  But as i've said several times it is in beta so I'm sure as more mid game and end game things are added smelters will be more available early on. Overall the game is great and quite entertaining.  $9 bucks for what I expect to be 30+ hours minimium of enjoyment is better then any cost to entertainment ratio I expect from most AAA games.  And once they start doing more patches I'm sure I'll get even more enjoyment out of it.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								Well this game seems to be better in the future, so I give it thumb-up. The game, however, is not really worth a thumb-up at the moment, because the game is not really playable now.The developer says that the creative mode is easy to use, but I didn't see how 'easy' it is. Well if you have played Minecraft, and you like building, you should probably know the plugin WorldEdit, and that really make building easier. But although this game have a 'powerful' building tool, it can't really make any different. If I want to place a chunk, that's OK, but it's really a challenge to make the chunk in proper size and position. The 'powerful' building tool seems to be more like a terrain brush rather than an assistant tool. In my opinion, something that can be called building tool should at lease have all the function that WroldEdit have. And the build to me function didn't work at all.By the way, there are no slopes, even no slabs and stairs in the game. Although I can make it an model manually, is that really easy that I need 8 models of one meterial in order to create the roof? And I REALLY want some furnitures but I can't find anything that really seems to be furniture, and I even can't find doors.Also the survival mode is really hard to play. The ping tool in the scanner really fustrate me a lot, because it can make the screen bright violin and it's hard to see through with these on. Energy things is almost OK, but why can't power centre charge the research centre? Every time I have to move the energy cell right next to the research centre in order to charge it, and transfer energy manually.And the UI is hard to use. Something that I really want to complain is that, could I have an inventory? And also, drag-drop control is not featured, and I should first select the item in my hot bar, and then open the UI to feed it, and the energy centre have no buffer, so I have to throw in a coal every minute, before I can have any automatic machanic.So with all these problems, why I still give it thumb-up? The main reason is that I only get the game for 2.24USD (and I purchased 13.44CNY), that's far cheaper than Minecraft. And also you can't expect a lot on a game in technic preview stage. 4 years ago, I used to play the classic version of Minecraft, and that has even less function than this game in this stage, but everyone enjoy that. There's still a lot of time for this game to be improved, and I hope that my 2 USD will worth 40 USD in the future.So, it's still worth to buy it, but don't expect too much too soon. Buy it and put it aside for several years is OK.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												The sheer scale of this game can be overwhelming, But once you start to learn how to automate it can be incredibly satisfying to see your resources being fed through you base. I would go into your first world just as a learning experience and take the time to learn controls and how best to configure automation. I have only put 130 hours into this game and am still constantly rebuilding my base as i think of new more efficient ways to run resources. Also the tutorial is short and can leave alot unsaid, that being said PRESS THE "H" Key it is an excellent resource that new players tend to miss or overlook. The Dev has done an excellent job with this game and continues to do so.The price is entirely too low in my opinion and i would have been happy paying far more, with that said consider buying the DLC if you really enjoy this, but it is also not required as the base game is huge and continues to get new content.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2016
												This Review in one word: RecommendedThis game is mind-blowing. I didn't play for that long (only around 300+ hours and i want a lot more), but what i can tell for sure: FortressCraft Evolved is addicting, amazingly fun (mostly because of your own actions), diversified and sometimes (logistically) challenging.For me it has a good mix of gameplay pace, as it offers situations where you have to react fast (or let's say you want to be fast) and on the other hand you have relaxing base management, where you can think about your next "project" or just waiting for resources.Furthermore the game gives you more than one moment of satisfaction. In fact you have a lot of small and big moments. For example you established a new mining site, you obliterated your first overmind or you just reached a personal goal in producing energy / ores / bars. Or maybe you're going to build your Climate Control Center? It depends on your own personal preferences.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 17
												This game is freakin awesome.  The dev is a quirky dude but quirky or not you're a real hero to the indepent developers setting out on their own.  Well done good sir.  Still blows my mind that you did most of this yourself, by yourself.  I know you've had some help along the way but this game is a true triumph story showing it's possible to make something awesome on your own if you work hard enough for long enough.  The fact that you are about the only survival crafting game to ever get out of early access still blows my mind.About The Game:I wont re-bother saying all the things already pointed out about how it's like this or that game.  I'll just let you know what I like about it.  To start, It's great for the OCD in me as it gives one the tools to learn what you need without holding your hand so tight that you can't do what you want.  Less about building awesome castles, more about building awesome factories that automate every little task you can think of (Though you can still build castles that like,♥♥♥♥♥♥or even a castle factory).   Best part of this game is when after you've been doing things by hand for hours and finally figure out how to automate the process with logic systems and cool conveyor routes, the reward is a bit like a king sitting on his throne looking out over his land as the farmers and soldiers toil for his gain.  But much less 'slavey' than that sounds because they are all machines.Anyhow, this game is great for the creative in me and I bet if your easily addicted to fine tuning systems until they are perfect then you'll get sucked into this game right away. I'm 85hours in and still unlocking new tech.  From the looks of what the interwebs has to say, I'll be unlocking things for quite some time to come too.  Not all of it is just the next tier up kind of stuff either.  Research is done in a very creative way as there are two different ways it's tackled.  Early game most of it is just scans, a few hours in you'll build machinse the process cores and spit out research you can use as well. When you finally get a good automated process for it, it's very satisfying.  Anyhow, I've said enough.  I just thought this game specificly desereved some good praise as it stands alone unto all the clones you see around.   I hear a lot of people thinking this is just a minecraft clone but that couldn't be farther from the truth.  About the only thing these two games have in common is voxel landscapes.  Everything else is unique and from what I've seen, completely origonal.  And you can go a LOT deeper in this game then you ever will in minecraft.  Infact, if you go too deep you'll need special heating unit in your suit to keep your♥♥♥♥♥from freezing to death.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2016
												FortressCraft Evolved is like a much more polished version of Minecraft + buildcraft mod. The TL;DR is it's more or less Logistics Simulator: Minecraft edition with tower defense aspects included. Sometimes getting a specific item is frustrating because you use so little of it, you don't create a dedicated system of machines to produce said item.  That said, I am quite sure you can automate pretty much the entire game if a player was dedicated and skillful enough, though that is MUCH easier said than done. I cannot currently comment on the multiplayer aspects as I have not messed around with that (yet!). The cons are that the tutorial is fairly useless. There is a LOT to figure out, but once you get the gist of it, the game is pretty consistent. Another con that kind of irks me is that most of the mobs that attack your base do not effect the player in any way, so you literally clip through them with no repercussions.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 14
												Fantastic building and automation game!I really don't understand the negative reviews. The single developer has delivered a large amount of content and updates over the years. The game is priced low enough to make the DLC an easy choice to buy (plus you are supporting his efforts). The mod support is great. The game runs quite well considering the incredible size of your bases and world, and the massive number of enemies being hurled at your defenses.As far as as gameplay goes, if you enjoy resource gather, mining, and automation then this is about the best there is. Even after hundreds of hours I am still sometimes in awe at the massive underground complexes I have stumbled across and built myself. I do agree that sometimes the game can be a bit obtuse in the beginning, but once you understand that things are meant to be built on a grand scale everything gets so much more enjoyable and easy. Also, I will agree that some mods are must haves for quality of life improvements, such as, infinite ore stacks  and Tricky's hoppers. I know I know, Fortresscraft Evolved has fortress in the name, but where it succeeds most is as an excellent automation and mining game, and you won't be disappointed picking it up as long as understand what it is.

content:
Posted: January 18
												So much time lost. So much fun had.Likes: Complex tech trees. Every game is a different physical arrangement and gets you thinking about new solutions. Automation. Cooperative multiplayer. Designing a base is a lot like designing software, only it has nothing to do with my workplace so it gives me dopamine. Balancing tech progress with defense is a good time.Dislikes: I'm a multiplayer junkie, and the dedicated server (experimental as of this writing) still a bit on the clunky side: Chunk loading issues, getting stuck inside of nothing, other odd issues like that. I expect they'll be fixed with time. Definitely not enough exploration, there's pretty much no reason to ever leave the immediate vicinity of the base other than to nuke Overminds. Also, not enough threats in regions unknown. Game is generally pretty easy, even with Hard Mobs enabled, once you've mastered the art of efficiently climbing the tech tree. More challenge, please!

content:
Posted: January 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								You know those really grindy "free to play" MMOs where you have to do the exact same thing over and over again to get the cool stuff? This game is exactly that, but without any payoff whatsoever.-Want to explore the wastly huge terrain, that is randomly generated to look exactly the same every single time?-Sorry you can't do that cause you'll freeze to death in 2 minutes.-Do you want to build the ever expanding factory of your dreams that produces all the cool stuff you could think of?-Well you can't quite do that, but what you CAN do is run back and forth between your mining drills, and your ONE smelter for 10 hours straight to gather enough resources for 20 conveyor belts. YAAY!This game is marketed as a HARDCORE base builder, which is all about automation, but in reality everything is way too resource expensive, and all the vital resources are too far apart. You'll literally have to spend at least 20 hours with hidiously boring grinding to make any form of automation possible.If you want to play a basebuilder that isn't a minecraft clone but is ACTUALLY FUN TO PLAY, dont waste your time with this and go buy "Factorio" instead.PS: I know this is just in early access, but that is not an excuse for not having actual gameplay.

number of helpful: 9 of 21 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1, 2016
												This little gem caught my eye about a year ago, when it was in early access. I decided back then to let it mature before buying it. As such I was excited to see it was out of early access and the full release was out.As another voxel based survival game this one seperates itself from the pack by focusing more or automation and refinement, matched really only by Factorio (but in 3D!!!). It looks great, at first glance, until I bought the game and played it...It played smooth. REAL smooth, in that it was between 150 and 200 FPS. There is an option in the Settings menu to change that, but it didn't do anything. No change whatsoever. So you try restarting the game, and there is still no difference. Now that is a pretty basic thing to set up, so why it doesn't function is beyond me (again, in a full title out of early access). It hogged all my computers resources to keep up with that rediculous update speed. But ow well, let's play on!So you start in a tutorial setting, protected from outside influences by a forcefield, which lifts when the tutorial is done. Awesome! The tutorial is short but informative, so even after restarting hundreds of games I can't see much of a speedbump there, and it's practical...Until the shield lifts and a giant spider robot walks over your base, its feet several blocks away from its legs (assuming said legs aren't jerking over it's head).At this point I noticed the text at the bottom right of the screen saying Development Build...Okay, probably started a Beta through Steam???...uhm...no...the game is still in beta...and the spider is supposed to be some kind of boss enemy to be encountered later in the game, which was left at the players spawn probably to debug / test.Why do I have a Development Build for a game that has been out for 5 / 6 months and without running a Beta?This game is not done, and it is out of early access. I concider that seriously disrespectfull towards the customer and a violation of my consumer rights. I don't mind buying a product that isn't finished, as long as you're honest about that and don't play morally and legally questionable games.In 10 years of Steam patronage I have never ask for a refund, and to be honest I thought Age Of Survival warranted it, but at least they are honest about the game not being done yet...EDIT: People don't seem to understand, so to make a bit more clear: I liked this game, I really did, but there is no excuse for selling a game that isn't finished, that is still a 'Developer Build'. The moment we as consumers accept that as 'okay' we collectively accept blatant disregard for our consumer rights and those rights will disappear.Steam has agreed with my complaint by refunding my payment, so at least I know I'm not entirely wrong by fighting this...
