Posted: March 1, 2016
												This little gem caught my eye about a year ago, when it was in early access. I decided back then to let it mature before buying it. As such I was excited to see it was out of early access and the full release was out.As another voxel based survival game this one seperates itself from the pack by focusing more or automation and refinement, matched really only by Factorio (but in 3D!!!). It looks great, at first glance, until I bought the game and played it...It played smooth. REAL smooth, in that it was between 150 and 200 FPS. There is an option in the Settings menu to change that, but it didn't do anything. No change whatsoever. So you try restarting the game, and there is still no difference. Now that is a pretty basic thing to set up, so why it doesn't function is beyond me (again, in a full title out of early access). It hogged all my computers resources to keep up with that rediculous update speed. But ow well, let's play on!So you start in a tutorial setting, protected from outside influences by a forcefield, which lifts when the tutorial is done. Awesome! The tutorial is short but informative, so even after restarting hundreds of games I can't see much of a speedbump there, and it's practical...Until the shield lifts and a giant spider robot walks over your base, its feet several blocks away from its legs (assuming said legs aren't jerking over it's head).At this point I noticed the text at the bottom right of the screen saying Development Build...Okay, probably started a Beta through Steam???...uhm...no...the game is still in beta...and the spider is supposed to be some kind of boss enemy to be encountered later in the game, which was left at the players spawn probably to debug / test.Why do I have a Development Build for a game that has been out for 5 / 6 months and without running a Beta?This game is not done, and it is out of early access. I concider that seriously disrespectfull towards the customer and a violation of my consumer rights. I don't mind buying a product that isn't finished, as long as you're honest about that and don't play morally and legally questionable games.In 10 years of Steam patronage I have never ask for a refund, and to be honest I thought Age Of Survival warranted it, but at least they are honest about the game not being done yet...EDIT: People don't seem to understand, so to make a bit more clear: I liked this game, I really did, but there is no excuse for selling a game that isn't finished, that is still a 'Developer Build'. The moment we as consumers accept that as 'okay' we collectively accept blatant disregard for our consumer rights and those rights will disappear.Steam has agreed with my complaint by refunding my payment, so at least I know I'm not entirely wrong by fighting this...

content:

Early Access Review
								Most games start off easy and get progressively harder in order to balance out the players advancement and remain interesting. This game does the exact opposite. Maybe not in terms of skill, but in patience. The first few hours (if not more) of gameplay are incredibly slow. There is a general sense of just not getting anywhere. And when you do manage to get a decent industry up and running and you actually have the resources to get things done, you realize there was no point. At this point in the game's developement, the only thing you can do with the resources you gather (Id guess there are fewer than 10 useful ones) is making machines that automate...gathering more resources...With such limiting gameplay and more bugs than a rainforest floor, its difficult to imagine it leaving early access in the near future

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								Cons:This game randomly hard-locks my computer. This happens with no other program and I have throughly tested my memory.The menu does not pause the game, so you can die from adjusting settings (especially in the first 5 hours in a world).You're in constant peril of death for the first several hours of the game and after patiently strategeicly attempting for almost 12 gameplay hours in a world, I just got to the point of crafting the first 2nd tier item. Survival is frustratingly slow.You start with a single device to smelt ores, and to build another is a 3rd teir build and reportedly among the community takes roughly 30 hours of gameplay to get to. I have more than 20 hours and can still not yet survive going deep enough to *find* T3 resources.Can very easily jump into a block and see through the level. There is even a four-click method to see through the world reliably at any time you want. Major game breaker.Pros:The mining is automated for the most part as you grow. Then the smelting becomes automated. Then the building.Cool system, allows for huge top-end growth.Really nice voxel graphics.Summary:The ore mining/energy/processing is a really cool idea, but this game has screwball glitches, partial graphics failures regularly, inventory failures often, and total system lockups on a healthy computer. Lets be honest, this is a minecraft clone, and not worth the money.

content:
Posted: January 12
												Edit: After a developer reply on how to fix the crashes this runs smootly now (it never crashed since 2 hours at least). So i edited this to reflect more about my experience.However i still leave this review as negative, mostly since there is no "neutral" button, and since positive would not reflect what I exerienced / felt, while playing it.I must admit, that I havent progressed further than starting some basic automation.The UI get's in my way too often, and the tutorial is minimal, not explaining you lot's of things.Geting into automation is way too tedious at start.There is some weird sound problems for me too, like if i scan down there in a hallway the shrieking echoes forewer, having me to turn down the sound to an allmost absolute minimum.While the idea might be nice, the 3 dimensions just make it horrible for me personally, since the grappling hook probably needs hours of training to make you go up and down a mining shaft without dying every second time (after another two hours i found that shooting it repeatedly towards the wall while "falling" down a shaft you can actually land...). Digging deep and then bringing those materials back (automated, not running down there every 5 minutes) is a pain at the start too.The idea of needing unidentified blocks to scan for research is in my eyes not really good game design. An increased amount of ore or other resources per research would be much more apropriate (or did i not progress far enough still?).One of the things that hinder me most is the limited energy at start. Just because of this, and for no other reason i run forth and back 10 or more times to just set up a mine and build the conveyors and energy supply for it. While it could be fun to dig it, find a way for the belts and the energy transmition it gets dull, because 50% of the time is "running forth and back for energy".Some things are really nice in there too. Like distance not mattering for interacting with things, or the "build to me" feature. Unfortunatly nothing of this is explained in the tutorial, and i had to check some youtube videos and guides to even get the basic understanding of the game (and i'm one of those that dont like to have to watch let's plays to understand a game, i want immersion and learning in game).There is potential in it for sure. And i'll check on it again some time later.TL;DR:If you want a stable good factory builder then I recomend Factorio instead.If you want pure tower defence then there is 100 such games around.If you want a blend of both and you love 3d then this one is it.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								I played FortressCraft on the 360 quite a bit, enjoying the hunt for all those hidden little tools you could use to make playing the game more interesting. I especially enjoyed the idea of creating zed spawners. I must have created thousands of those things...But anyway, on with THIS game.I had to say this: it's not easy starting out. I had little time to read the help and starting tips before I realized that my suit energy was dropping fairly quickly. To top it off, I had to also wrestle with the controls before I was able to make my way to my crash site.But once I managed to get the controls down, I was able to start mining for resources. I got lucky and found a tin and coal vein inside the mountain I set up camp on, and eventually found iron and copper (though they were a long climb down into the earth.I think the suit energy idea is a good idea. It's going to keep you alive, and it allows you to stay out in the cold a while longer before you need to recharge. And the scanner idea was nice as well, though I think I know a tree when I see one. Unless it suddenly grows tentacles and tries to eat me. Then I'm just being eaten.And the new entities in the the game have given me more questions than answers. There are these flying robots that, when I kill them, drop ruined stingers. Not sure what to do with those, or what they are suppose to do for the bots, but it's interesting. And let's not forget the wacky-looking spider thing I found stuck on the mountain. That thing wouldn't die, nor would it move. I'm curious as to how all of those things got there.While this game is pretty fun to play, and the creative mode is a blast to mess with, I did have some general issues, ones that I'm sure some or most players will have run into.1. Resource Management. While I can understand that resources are going to be important for your survival, it just seems kind of ridiculous to have to travel hundreds of blocks away in order to find even basic resources (it took me over an hour to just find copper). And the majority of the time, my energy is being used to keep my few ore extractors going, or scanning for more areas to mine new resources. I've yet to find anything new.2. Control Layout.This is one of my biggest beefs, and for a good reason. As I said before, I had to fight with the controls for a minute before I could get moving, though it took me even longer to learn how to switch back to my scanner from my gathering tool. It also feel a little clunky, having to reach across the keyboard to hit a certain hotkey. I know the keys can be rebound, but I tend not to mess with that. Maybe a few minor rethinkings of the layout would be nice. Or controller support! I'm honestly one for full controller support, so maybe that could be a future addition.3. Crafting.The crafting system is relatively straight forward, which is nice, but requires resources that could take a lot of time to find, and even more time to gather. And even with the resources that are almost immediately found, the process requires more time and more resources. To illustrate my issue:8 iron=1 iron bar, 15 iron bars=1 ore extractor.It just seems a little tedious.4. Environmetal Hazards.Now, honestly, this is a cool feature, but one that needs some working. Heat keeps you from freezing to death, obviously. But what makes me a little irritated is the fact that you can't make heated rooms. It just seems like one of those things that you'd think would have been implemented a while back to help players better manage themselves. I'm really hoping it's added in a future update, though. Cold nights would be so much more pleasant.5. Terrain.This one is just something small, nothing major. But I feel like it's something that could be implemented at some point in even a minor update. Having to jump to go up another block gets a little tedious, not to mention it's a little hard on the spacebar (at least mine, anyway). Maybe the option of automatically climbing up one block could make an appearance in a future update.But other than that, this game is looking pretty good! I'm looking forward to seeing what the Devs have in store for futue updates, as well as what other players will suggest adding to it. This is a game that certainly has evolved from it's console predecessor, and it's done so pretty well.

number of helpful: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								Disclaimer: I have not played the Creative Mode.Even in Early Access this is an incredible game.  You start off in the middle of no where freezing to death with only the energy in your suit and a couple of torches and ore extractors.  You immediately have to set off to find your crashed ship to try to salvage whatever you can to just survive the first night on this planet.  Once you're accustomed to surviving the night, you can start exploring all that FortressCraft has to offer.  Building automated bases, suit upgrades, crafting, etc.The UI still needs to be cleaned up and more intuitive, but the devs are working on core functionality of the game first so expect a bit of a learning curve (if you have any questions the devs and other community members are always available on the forums),New updates and features are being released all the time, multiplayer was just recently released (there's still a lot more work to do with multiplayer, but at least it's under way).  I highly recommend this game.

number of helpful: 9 of 22 people (41%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16
												I really, really, really want to like this game, and for a while as I was starting out, I did. The elevator pitch is more or less "Factorio as recreated in Minecraft", and the first person element really does add that much more to the exploration aspect.Unfortunately, once you've got an assembly line set up for your most basic resources, the entire game's progression of tech trees turns out to be deliberately balanced a step or two behind parity with your current progress, such that you are always sticking your neck out, collecting stuff manually, and being forced to stretch your current equipment to its absolute limits to gather the new resource for the next tier of equipment, at which point the process repeats itself. It's less a game about automation as it is a never-ending masocore scavenger hunt. Which is a damn shame, because if just a bit more common sense were applied to the tech trees it'd be another masterpiece of the "explore, collect, build" genre. You still might be able to get something out of it, but I would advise caution. It's more nefarious than it looks.

number of helpful: 7 of 18 people (39%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												I really should recommend this game. It's 3D Factorio, and I love Factorio and 3D. Alas, while I kind of like it it's just too grindy and slow. The game gives you all sorts of cool tools for you to play with, but they're so expensive to build (smelters) or power hungry (automatic tools like excavators/belt layers and the like). The early game in particular is awful because of how hard it is to locate basic ores. If you find a new ore and analyize it before you've memorized or marked the location the ore won't show up while pinging unknown anymore, so good luck finding it again. This is but one example of many about how FortressCraft Evolved wastes your time with boring crap.The developer could learn a lot from Factorio and slash the power and material requirements for everything by quite a lot (like, a factor of 10), then it would be a fun game. Also other stuff like ping colored ore should be the default mode for pinging known ores, and that shouldn't be locked behind research or cost a ton of suit power. I'm not holding my breath for these changes though, the developer has released at least 7 major updates for the game since it left early access and hasn't reduced the grind significantly at all.Update: I tried this game again with update 10 and casual settings and got to the point where I was minining lithium. It's still just as tedious as it was.

content:
Posted: March 27
												It's rare that I give up on a game so soon into playing it but this would be one of the few times that it happens. I couldn't tell you much about how the game itself plays except that it really does lack anything which could be considered entertainment. The notion of a tower defence Minecraft-esque game sounds appealing but the way it has been done is just needlessly tedious. There are many mods for Minecraft which offer what FortressCraft is doing here but does it far better.Whats more is that the game is just plain unpleasent to look at. The UI itself is messy and vague. The environment itself is dark and neon in a way which isn't interesting or visually appealing at all and can be done much better as shown by games such as Subnautica. The draw distance, even when maxed, is actually far less than what Minecraft it capable of with shaders applied so you have this distinct horizon not very far away and the surface clutter can be seen hovering over an invisible landscape that has not yet loaded. The items held in the players hand block a good 1/4 of the screen which is distracting when you're looking around. Due to how dark the game is and how crucial machines are all blocks I found myself having to carefully peer at the screen to tell if I was looking at a hopper or a smelter for example. This unwieldly design also extends to the controls which cannot be rebound to new keys from within the game it would seem.The game is just an unwieldy mess of ideas that have been mashed together and don't really work when taken as a whole. I've refunded this already and I would suggest that nobody touch this game.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
												I'm not too happy about this one... The graphics are indeed quite good, and there are some improvements over minecraft (Yes, I am comparing this game to MC + Tech mods) including the jetpack, the flashlight and large ore veins.But there's also a bunch of problems which might be because this game left EA too early.Let's talk about progress. I normally play survival in MC, but in this game I got bored by it. Actually bored, not the casual play-something-else bored. If I want to progress, I need to produce a lot of bars, which means a lot of ore miners and even more power to power my equipment. If I do that I'll attract the attention of mobs. I could run my mining operations at a slower speed, but where's the fun in that? To make matters worse, the base income in ore, metals and power is so low that you REALLY need a lot of everything, for which you need a lot of resources. And you don't have those.ARTHER, that tiny flying thing by your side. I guess having it give you energy is neat, but I don't get how a tiny flying robot has better power cells and solar panels than you do in your space suit. In addition it's supposed to display vital information to you. But you can't really read that if it points away from you, or is sitting inside a wall.Threat level, while a good idea, is simply not working out. In the very beginning of the game you are not getting attacked because you're not mining/smelting enough to attract any mobs. But once your base evolves, you'll suddenly get multiple waves of wasps every 10 or so minutes. And your turrets don't target mobs immediately, so you need a lot of them.Wasps are the main enemy (before the heavies and bosses appear). But they are only a way to make your base receive damage, they aren't fun to defend against at all. If you build a wall around your base they fly through it, if you shield your CPH they shoot through the wall, they can turn invisible and invincible, etc.Fortunately there's that big spider robot which is supposed to defend you. Unfortunately it doesn't. When a wave begins it starts walking away and doesn't defend the base. I guess that it is actually heading towards the wasp's spawn location, but I'm not convinced that it does anything once it's there.Finally, the CPH. It is just an excuse to slow you down. In the beginning you may depend on it, but later on it is just useless. It is called Central Power Hub for no reason, it's like a PTG at 30% efficiency and you can't feed power into it from your power plant. It is the one and only target for wasps, yet it doesn't have any means of defending itself. It fires a beam upward in which you can't build at all, despite having no effect whatsoever (no it's a bad beacon). The worst part is that you can't even move it. Spawned on a hill? Too bad.This game would have been very good if you didn't had to constantly defend against wasps.Oh wait... I can change that :)[imgur.com]I had to stop playing or I would have wasted countless hours modifying the game and still not have the fun I was hoping to get through it... progress is still too slow.

content:
Posted: October 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								It's good so far, and it uses the Unity Engine, which means it's not a big corporate game, etc. A few things to note: This game is not complete, not by a long shot. I've already run into a LOT of bugs within my playtime already, below is a list of them.-- The 64-Bit Version may crash upon Quitting the game to desktop.-- Having more than one ore type in your inventory will confuse the smelter's "Feed Ores" button. (You cannot make a storage system without multiple ores.)-- The A.R.T.H.U.R or whatever it is called, requires a Power Core to be crafted for it to work proper again. However, you do not know this recipe, even after researching the black box and power suit upgrades.-- Right-Clicking items in your hot bar (using the mouse-enabled HUD) removes them from your inventory, forever. You cannot collect more of the item, you cannot see the item when using scroll wheel, etc. It's gone, forever.-- Using your mining laser on coal ore (or any ore) constantly will seem to continue mining the ore incredibly faster than an ore extractor, this is not the case, the blocks that appear dropped are ghost ore item drops.-- Game on "Fabulous" has issues with block animations, etc. The loading screen also freezes on that setting, even though the computer can handle said setting over 60 FPS (IE: Getting screen-tear since my computer can process faster even on Fabulous.) The setting can also lag computers that are far, far above the recommended requirements.-- The spider mech enemy does nothing.-- Your gun cannot hurt the spider mech enemy. (IE: The spider mech has no hitbox.)-- Sometimes, during the day, the solar cell on the suit does not work.-- Sometimes, even if you have enough power and research points, some research items will say they can't be researched.-- The world select button on the Escape menu does nothing.-- When creating a world with a custom name, the world's name reverts to "World" on game reload.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2015
Fortresscraft: Evolved is... awkward. Alright... where to start? Well, I suppose I should start off by saying I can tell this game takes inspiration from "industrial"-themed Minecraft mods, in that you're setting up production chains and transporting items and mining and all that stuff. The problem is it's only taken inspiration, and pretty much fails in every other regard.The good: Fortresscraft is initially simple and you might have fun for the first hour, but the fun soon stops as the game becomes a parade of annoyances, either due to bad game design, intentional grinding, and a slew of other bullcrap that keeps you from that carrot on a stick; progression.The bad: Now, you may be wondering, "Higgs, what's so annoying and bad about the game? Look at all the positive reviews!" To that I say; everyone is stupid except me, and you... if you listen to my gripes about this game. Starting off, the graphics. Now, I might be playing this on an ancient GTX630 graphics card, but that's still no excuse for a game with these sorts of graphics to not be hitting 60FPS, at the very least on low settings. The models are simple and bland, they look like they're out of a PS2 game (a bargain-bin one at that), and the blocky terrain clashes with this. The textures are muddy, dull and needlessly high-res, and have parallax for the most mundane things. The developer seems to have slapped on as many special rendering effects on top of the game to cover up the mediocrity of the art style, to the point that it can be difficult to see when some of the bloom effects or screen overlays do their best to blind you. As a result, the game tends to chug despite the low poly-count.The gameplay itself is, to a point, what you'd expect from a Minecraft ripoff. Break and place blocks. Simple enough, if the UIs weren't a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ nightmare to navigate. Every single screen seems to run on a different set of rules, and despite what might seem like a solid framerate your clicking and dragging will be laggy as hell. The focus of the game, the machines, are obnoxiously unexplained; even with the in-game help it either seemed to gloss over the function or rules of things lioke hoppers, which never EVER behaved in the way you wanted them to. I'd be fine with that if I could mine by hand, but you CAN'T. Ore blocks aren't supposed to be broken apparently, and yield junk when you turn your laser onto them. You have to place a grinder thing beside an ore vein, then wait for it to chew through it sluggishly. It's obnoxious and it just doesn't make sense. Even breaking normal blocks manages to be awkward and clunky, they break far too fast and the range for the laser is too far, making digging stairwells a chore when you accidentally dig at more or less than a 45* angle, meaning you have to dig out the ceiling or place blocks to make the stairs smooth again. With the way blocks break in Minecraft, you have far better control over what you're digging, to the point that I find mining to actually be one of the more enjoyable activities even after at least 5 years of playing the game, Fortresscraft's awkwardness just vomits all over that sense of zen that I get.  It's worth mentioning again that almost nothing is actually given context in the game. Despite dismantling a tree with my laser I can't make planks to make a crate to store all this garbage in my inventory. What do all these over-detailed glowing plants do? Slimes everywehere? Are they bad guys? Sometimes when I'm underground a block decides it hates me and kills me (dying has no consequences outside of respawning, yet another annoyance). Are THOSE bad guys? How do I fight them? I had to go down to -150 meters to find lithium ore, yet the device that beams power underground requires that I already have piles of lithium? Why do I have to nrun back and forth between my power station because there's little option for providing power to underground drills? How many times am I going to get HYPOTHERMIA? Also, no pickaxes in the game apart from the logo. That really miffs me for some reason, maybe because I can't mine myself and the machines are frustrating to deal with. Placing conveyor belts is an exasperating chore; they never go the way you want them to the first time, and you'll often need to dig a hole to stand in to get at the right angle to place them up a wall (that doesn't even make SENSE).The ugly, ugly, UGLY: Did I mention this game is ugly? Holy hell is it ugly. Again, I have to reitterate that the flat, blocky terrain clashes with the semi-detailed models; Minecraft might be ugly too but at least it's a consistent sort of ugly. Every texture is far more detailed than it needs to be, to the point that it looks less like a texture and more like a grey blob at every distance apart from directly in front of your eyes, in which case it's got so much detail it looks almost uncanny valley in a way. The lighting SUCKS, it hurts my eyes. I hate looking at this game. In conclusion, if you really, absolutely must play a voxel-based mining game with machines, buy Minecraft and install Technic launcher, there's dozens of well-made and POLISHED mods for you to play, with far more content and without the graphics drain and constant frustrations.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2016
												Don't let the high recommendation fool you. This game is awful. It's completely unfinished, it may as well not even have a tutorial for all the good the tutorial does you, and is barely functional in all other respects. Even if it were functional it is completely devoid of personality or spirit. What started as a clone of Minecraft hasn't evolved into anything worthwhile. Skip this one.Edit: The developer commented, so i figured I'd give a bit more detailed reasoning as to why I returned this game.a) the game runs like♥♥♥♥♥on a current gen ASUS,b) the first game I played I spent 20 minutes debugging why the power hub and conveyer setup wasn't working (the hub spawned a block too high), and had to restartc) you've published the game with the developer console actived) the robot tries to fly into the optimal place to display its message(which was clipped by the edge of the screen for me), and it took me several minutes of chasing him down before I realized that's what was going on,e) there's a general lack of visual communication when you look at objects to try to figure out what they do,f) things that, I assume, were working normally, looked buggy and unpolished, like the intro screen and the level generation screeng) the visuals and audio, while hardly placeholder, desperately need a polish pass (the lighting and shaders especially)h) you can die in the starting zone simply by not learning the game fast enough.All in all, a horrific first impression. All the in-game help menus in the world can't make up for a bad impression.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2016
												I did not find a lot to love in this game.  To start, it is ugly.  I was not expecting much from the screenshots, and I am hardly a graphics snob, but this is an unpleasant to look at game.  The textures and models are not cohesive, and the game is inexplicably dark.  And I mean dark.  There are highlights of variously colored lights, but it is more reminiscent of early games like Quake rather than anything attractive.  The tutorial is exceptionally short and completely useless.  I guess new players are expected to watch YouTube videos to figure things out.  The UI is also pretty terrible, starting with the main menu and getting worse from there.  There may be a good game buried in here, but I couldn't find it before I decided that there were better uses of my time and asked for a refund.

												I loved fortress craft at first up until the last changes.  Try and argue with the developer is like arguing with a brick wall.  Problem 1: Play style and lvl a simple difcuality level is needed.Peaceful - Those who just want to do the manufacturing part of the game and make stuff.Easy - Some monster shows up on rarity.  Start setting up defences etc form here.Medium - Diffcualtiy as normal Hard - Go for it and make it a little tougher enemy etc.Hard Core - If you die, you game is erase but your highest stats will be listed.Problem 2 - Generators does not work below 300.  I really don't care but like to generators to work at all levels.  Problem 3 - You spend more time mining and collecting resources then building an actual base.  Its already complicated as it is.  You don't need to add more problems on top of problems. Problem 4 - changes are soo annoying that when they do changes it makes the game worst then what it is.  - Examples  - Generators don't work below 300.  I have an entire system setup for that and now I have to go back and fix it.  I barely have enough materials to make a power laser to get that far down let alone finding a way back down.    - Monsters spawns soo much that all your ore is gone before you get it up.  Plus going back to make all those changes is a pain.  Even Minecraft changes is better then this.  - Force to use high speed tubes vs oonveyors,  It means hours of replacement again mining speed of the ore is slow going even after upgrades.    - 8-1 ore - yea millions of ore and on turns into 20 k or so.  With so much needed to build, who needs ore monsters.In addition, read the forms and you can see all the crappy changes they keep making.  Yea, its there game; but, who is paying for it???  Us of course.

number of helpful: 2 of 9 people (22%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 15
												The graphics are horrible. I never saw a game with worse graphics ever. It is like playing a game from 20 years ago. The lighting is ridiculous weird. In the most case, it is so dark that you cannot see anything. Once you initialized a scan or stand before a light/torch, it get so bright that you cannot see anything still. >.>The optimization for rendering is bad too. I have to set all the detail to lowest with 1/2 resolution (Yes, I have to play the game in a window which sucks) to make it run at around 30 fps. At the same time, I can play Minecraft very smoothly so I assume it is this game's problem.However, I really love factories-designing games. Although similar to factorio, this game is really creative in its own ways.   I really love how energy is transferred through lasers. I also love the concept of hoppers (which are similar to inserters in factorio though).Also, I really love that you can go (almost) infinitely deep in this game. It really gives me a sense of being in a 3D world. factorio is 2D obviously. Although Minecraft is 3D, the height limit thing is just annoying. When you are playing Minecraft you can get to the bottom very quickly. It feels like being in a paper world.Last but not least, I also love the "op-ness" of the main character. You basically get the ability to fly (even though really hard to control), infinite long reach, and very fast health regen from beginning. You also almost lose nothing when died. All these settings really let players get into the actual designing instead of worrying about getting to some where.Anyways, although the graphics is extremely bad, I will really recommend this game.

												I tried, I really did. I've seen the accusations that this is "another minecraft clone", but I went in with an open mind. I was disapointed and not really surprised that I was.Let's skip past the name, since we all know about that issue, and look at the gameplay.If you took a poor resolution minecraft texture pack, added rejected alien and weapon models from Garry's Mod, and threw the Tekkit mod in for some more "originality", you are left with Fortresscraft. - Gameplay is slow- Block textures are disappointing- Objects that are not a copy/paste from Minecraft texture packs do not fit the "feel" at all. number of helpful: 13 of 33 people (39%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2016
												First off, this is an early access game without the title, what a slimy way to get people to buy an incomplete game. There is already dlc for it, one of which is an expansion that costs more than the original game.I went into this game expecting to like it. For the first 30 seconds, the tutorial seemed very hand-holding which I liked for this game because after that, I didn't have a clue what to do next. After 22 minutes, I gave up and decided to try again later. Saving the game took about 2 full minutes; That's excessive. Came back the next day having no objectives. I didn't have any idea what I was supposed to do. Only after 20 minutes did it finally tell me what I was supposed to do. So I put ore in smelter thing and it just sat there. There was no on/off button to it so I thought, I know, I'll add power to it. There was no way to do that directly so I tried to add power to the central hub. My suit drained power but the machine didn't gain any. This had worked for me the first day though and continued to work for other machines. I decided to quit once more, saving seemed like it was going to take a while again(why is this even a thing? I'm not the only one with this problem), so I alt-tabbed, when I clicked on the icon to see the progress, it disappeared. I assume it crashed without errors.The whole suit having power thing is completely stupid, it drains so fast. Literally running back and forth to the energy block thing(that fills up very slowly) after trying to mine twice which collects like 10 ore total. I don't know if this energy dilemma is a problem late-game but it's realllllly annoying at the start. Unless you can upgrade your character, which I didn't see a way to, I imagine that will always be a problem throughout.Something I personally didn't like was the UI. The rainbow colors weren't pleasing to the eyes and the white font on top of it only made it worse. Very difficult to read.Spending the first two hours trying to figure out this unintuitive game will be too much trouble for me. Maybe the game is good for all I know but it certainly doesn't start out that way and I'm sure it's part of the reason people will be asking for refunds.

content:
Posted: April 23, 2016
												If this was an Early Access game, I would be gobsmacked. However as a full release, there are some glaring flaws I noticed in just the first hour. Foremost, the tutorial for a game this complicated should continue through the first five hours, lightly stepping in whenever the player encounters a new mechanic to explain it. I spent over an hour in this game trying to do one thing, and one thing only. I wanted to automate power transmission from the main generator to the coal mining drill, and subsequently automate coal transmission from the drill to the generator that burns it. In over an hour, I came no closer to figuring this out than I did watching the video at the top of the page.Secondly, the crafting system interface needs to be scrapped and redone. Impossible to find crafting requirements without more than a minute of searching through menus and lists, meanwhile 60 percent of the screen is taken up by ridiculous "sci-fi" window borders that do LITERALLY NOTHING AT ALL. If you are going to copy minecraft, at least copy the parts that were user friendly.Thirdly, do you know why blocks take a few seconds to break in minecraft, but appear instantaneously when building? ITS BECAUSE IT WARNS YOU WHEN YOU HAVE ACCIDENTALLY DONE THE WRONG ACTION. I spent more time than I can measure switching from the thing I actually WANTED to build back to BLOCKS OF DIRT just to fill in A HOLE I DIDNT MEAN TO DIG. This is utterly ridiculous.HOWEVERThe concept has incredible potential. Adding automation and base defense to a minecraft style operation creates both drama and empowerment, and it would be something I REALLY want to enjoy, but these initial issues with the OBSCENE learning curve, clunky interface, and other oversights overshadow a very good idea. Fix these issues and the game will improve.2/5

number of helpful: 8 of 24 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 28
												Start game, first thing to look for: Settings menu...  Ok; there is none.Guess I'll go create a world (no other available options).  Start typing in the world seed, go to click "ok", mouse cursor has vanished... Ok, so it's gonna be like that, eh?  Hit "enter", mouse is back... Strange way to start things off.  All menu's to this point are waaayy too big (playing on a 43" 4k monitor), but yeah, whatever, I'll probably find the settings in-game.Start the game, watch the initial cutscene which I guess trying to explain what's going on?  Get into the tutorial, but have absolutely no clue what to do, anywhere.  There's zero consistency in the presentation of information, no idea what the keys are (as I didn't find a settings menu before starting to check!), and the tutorial is pretty vague.  Information is arbitrarily displayed when your cursor is over random items, but there's nothing to really direct you.  I patch together some basic directions (pretty sure I missed half of course), one screen tells me to craft something, which I do from a menu (without the slightest clue as to its material requirements, purpose, or process), and bam, the tutorial ends... wait... what?Absolutely nothing learned in the first 15 minutes of the game.  I figure out how to "dig", make a hole (figure why not?), can't get out, tutorial didn't cover that (or anything else really).Whatever.  Enough for now, Exit game. Screen whines something about trying to compress something or other... Let it run for 30 seconds... Says you can exit, but nothing is clickable (even if it was, none of the buttons display when being pressed, etc.).  No progress, alt+tab / force-close.This game needs a serious tutorial/UI overhaul before it's worth wasting any time.  FWIW, I can manage to build asparagus staged rockets in KSP, I've finished Factorio (*with* bobs mods), etc.   The basics of a tutorial/etc. should be well within my capability to grasp, yet somehow, the first 20 minutes of this game were about as clear as mud.[update - 01-Mar-2017]:Well, I took the plunge and gave it another go.  I reset the world, played the tutorial up to the point it dropped the shield.  Honestly  -- it looks exactly the same as it did before.  The UI is absolutely terrible in every regard.  Maybe it's my 43" monitor/4k resolution -- but the text is enormous, the dialogue boxes are all at minimum opacity with crap going on directly behind them, the fact that all of the icons are fuzzy and look like excessively-inflated 16 bit art that doesn't match the rest of the landscape rendered in "fantastic" mode.  The tutorial gives you a set of directives that you follow because you're told to, not because they provide any compelling narrative, or stitch together actual game mechanics, etc.  And then at the end of this little mini tutorial, there's a robot floating off to your left, with the text "press h [blah blah blah]", but when you turn to look at him, he perpetually shifts away to sit in your peripheral (and the text rotates away, so if you missed it, you can't read it now).Bottom line, DjArcas: have an actual UI dev take a poke at your game, if you can't draw somebody in during the first 15 minutes of gameplay, then they're never going to discover what's beneath the hood, and that's your lost/flipped sales at the end of the day.

content:
Posted: January 16
												////// EDIT - Update for Patch 16 - see bottom //////It's a wildly popular game, and I'm sure this will be a wildly unpopular review, particularly with the short amount of time I've spent with it...but that is simply because the game is NOT friendly to new players, whatsoever.  There is a tutorial, but it is perhaps the single most confusing and least helpful tutorial of any video game in existence.  The player is thrown into the tutorial which does not explain anything whatsoever and instead, just tells you what buttons to press (without explaining what you are doing and why you must do it).There are in game pages you can read (like a reference), but that assumes the player as the patience to actually read through it all. It's 2017. Relatively complex games come with in-game tutorials,  This one doesn't and thus, only those who are extremely patient are likely to take an interest in it.For me, there is too much competition out there (other games) to be forced to learn the mechanics of this one. IMHO, lack of proper tutorial in a game like this is a sign of development laziness. There is no excuse for it.////// EDIT ////////Played the updated tutorial after Patch 16. It is better. However I didn't get far with it. It tells you to place the Holo-Laser Power Transmitter. Yet no such thing exists. I did find some sort of Power Transmitter in my inventory so I placed that, nothing happened...the quest didn't go away. So I placed another one, perhaps I just placed it wrong? When I did, the game crashed.It's a mess.

content:
Posted: October 1, 2016
												Who, even among scholars in the field, could keep up with the flood of attacks on Pius XII that began in the late 1990s? John Cornwell gave us Hitler’s Pope , and Michael Phayer followed with The Catholic Church and the Holocaust . David Kertzer brought charges against Pius XII in The Popes Against the Jews , and Susan Zuccotti reversed her previous scholarship to pen Under His Very Windows: The Vatican and the Holocaust in Italy . Garry Wills used Pius as the centerpiece for his reformist Papal Sin , as did James Carroll in Constantine’s Sword . So, for that matter, did Daniel Goldhagen when he wrote what proved to be the most extended and straightforward assault on Catholicism in decades: A Moral Reckoning: The Role of the Catholic Church in the Holocaust and Its Unfulfilled Duty of Repair . Meanwhile, the essays and occasional pieces were collected in such volumes as Holocaust Scholars Write to the Vatican , and The Holocaust and the Christian World , and The Vatican and the Holocaust , and Pope Pius XII and the Holocaust , and Christian Responses to the Holocaust ”and on, and on, until we seemed to be facing what the exasperated reviewer John Pawlikowski called “a virtual book-of-the-month club on institutional Catholicism, anti-Semitism, and the Holocaust.” The champions of Pius had their share of book-length innings as well”although, one might note, never from the same level of popular publisher as the attackers managed to find. In 1999 Pierre Blet produced Pius XII and the Second World War According to the Archives of the Vatican and got Paulist Press, a respectable but small Catholic house, to publish it in America. Ronald Rychlak finished his first-rate Hitler, the War, and the Pope , and the hardback was brought out by a press in Columbia, Missouri, known mostly for printing romance novels. For the paperback edition, Rychlak’s work was picked up by the book-publishing arm of the Catholic newspaper Our Sunday Visitor . Those are both fine presses in their way, and Rychlak has done well for them. But one can reasonably point out that Our Sunday Visitor is not quite at the level of distribution, advertising, and influence enjoyed by Doubleday, Houghton Mifflin, Knopf, and Viking”the large houses that issued the books against Pius. The commentator Philip Jenkins recently suggested that this disparity in publishers sends a message that the mainstream view is the guilt of Pius XII, while praise for the Pope belongs only to the cranks, nuts, and sectarians. Jenkins’ suggestion is worth considering. Still, no one can say Pius’ supporters were squashed or censored. In just six years, Margherita Marchione managed five books in praise of the Pope. The Thomistic philosopher and novelist Ralph McInerny, aggravated by the deluge of attacks, issued a splenetic volume called The Defamation of Pope Pius XII , while Justus George Lawler (a writer best known in Catholic circles for his liberalism) penned a witty evisceration of Pius’ critics called Popes and Politics: Reform, Resentment, and the Holocaust . José Sánchez added Pope Pius XII and the Holocaust , and a slew of German and Italian books might be mentioned as well, prompted, for the most part, by the popular visibility of the English-language criticisms even in Europe. But it was primarily in book reviews and responses that the defenders of Pius XII fought out the war”which is something of a problem. Every pope precipitates biographies, hagiographies, and maledictions, like the dropping of the rain; it is part of the job to be much written about, and the works on Eugenio Pacelli that began to appear when he became pope in 1939 seem innumerable. But no supporter has yet produced a book-length biography in the wake of the recent years of extended blame. Even Rychlak’s Hitler, the War, and the Pope was essentially reactive, devoting a thirty-page epilogue to a catalogue of the errors in Cornwell’s book. We have seen this pattern before. Rolf Hochhuth’s play The Deputy premiered in Berlin in 1963, and its picture of a greedy pope, concerned only about Vatican finances and silent about the Holocaust, immediately caused a firestorm of comment from the intellectual world. Everyone who was anyone felt compelled to weigh in. Hochhuth himself faded away when he tried to extend his censure to Winston Churchill, penning a play in 1967 that claimed Churchill had ordered the murder of the Polish General Wladyslaw Sikorski and, later, the murder of the pilot who had crashed Sikorski’s plane. Unbeknownst to Hochhuth, the pilot was, in fact, still alive, and he won a libel judgment that badly damaged the London theater which had staged the play. Thereafter, Hochhuth found it harder to get a hearing”although, interestingly, the current notoriety of Pius XII seems to have resurrected the playwright to some degree, and in 2002 the Greek filmmaker Constantin Costa-Gravas released a movie version of The Deputy with the English title Amen (or Eyewitness , in other copies). Even without Hochhuth, the wide discussion about Pius XII he initiated in 1963 went on for several years. It produced some overheated journalistic attempts to cash in on the public interest, such as Robert Katz’ Black Sabbath and Death in Rome (the latter being the target of a successful libel suit, this time brought by Pius XII’s niece, Countess Elena Pacelli Rossignani). But the era brought forth as well three more serious and scholarly”indeed, by today’s standards, quite moderate and thoughtful”attacks: Guenter Lewy’s The Catholic Church and Nazi Germany (1964), Carlo Falconi’s The Silence of Pius XII (1965), and Saul Friedlander’s Pius XII and the Third Reich: A Documentation (1966). The brouhaha also prompted the Vatican to begin releasing material from Pius’ pontificate, which appeared from 1965 to 1981 as the eleven-volume series Actes et Documents . In part by relying on these new documents, but even more by simply gathering their forces and investigating each of the incidents taken as the core of the indictment, the defenders gradually tamped down The Deputy ’s claims about Pius XII and the Holocaust. Pope John Paul II was a consistent advocate for his predecessor, and even once-popular notions about Pius”that he was, for instance, the great reactionary opponent against whom Vatican II turned”gradually seemed to lose steam by the late 1970s and early ’80s. It took more than a decade, but the reactive reviewers appeared to carry the day, and the popular magazine press and major book publishers lost interest. A few commentators noted that the whole thing hadn’t entirely died. The historian Michael Tagliacozzo said he kept an open file labeled “Calumnies Against Pius XII.” But most were unprepared when the criticism began again in the late 1990s. To journalists and cultural commentators, Hitler’s Pope seemed almost to come out of nowhere in 1999, and it received almost entirely ecstatic reviews when it first appeared. A few skeptical journalists who remembered the Hochhuth battles” Newsweek ’s Kenneth Woodward and the New York Times ’ Peter Steinfels, notably”doubted Cornwell’s conclusions, but it had been years since they had investigated the topic, and they were unprepared to provide details about the book’s errors. Time was needed for scholars to gin up the machine again, double-check the claims in Hitler’s Pope , and publish the reviews. Some of the results proved deeply embarrassing for Cornwell, particularly the falsity of his boast that he had spent “months on end” in the archives, when he visited the Vatican for only three weeks and didn’t go to the archives every day of that. The Italian letter from Pacelli that Cornwell placed at the center of his book as evidence of deep anti-Semitism had been, he claimed, waiting secretly “like a time bomb” until he did his research.

content:
Posted: January 8
												Perhaps there's a good game under the surface? I tried this on the recommendation of a colleague who described it as something of a mash-up of Factorio and Tower Defense games (which sounded awesome). However, it's inexcusible to have such terrible control options:Bad: The controls are only bindable from the launcher and can't  be displayed in game, let alone rebound. Worse: The prompts in the tutorial don't reflect any keybind changes and there's a good number of keys.Awful: because it's a Steam game, you can't launch multiple instances so the only way I could check my controls was to fully exit the game and then restart it - utterly ridiculous. Even if there is a good game under the covers the barrier to entry is such a pain I just can't be bothered. However, if you're happy with WASD and whatever default controls the game throws at you, you might have better luck.

Posted: March 29
												I tried Fortress Craft for the first time ... i use a non-standard keyboard layout.- All tutorials just show the standard keybindings- Changing keybindings is ONLY allowed before starting the game!!!- You can have multiple actions bound to a single key, only one will work, no warning ... nothing. - I use "u" to walk forward usually. The only binding for this key is "Walk forward", yet there seems to be still another action bound to "u" and i can´t change it at all. And the best comes now ... the keybindings are stored in the Registry as BINARY values.Reset your keybindings? Oh yes ... deinstall the game and delete the registry. Then re-install. Possible a nice game ... really. But i can´t recommend it, because i can´t play it. So if you are not using a standard keyboard layout and the default keys - you will run into trouble with this game.

												Terrible gameplay, constantly crashes fulscreen (only playable at 1080p windowed). Crashes on exiting the game also. These use highly saturated colors so if you have high contrast monitor it actually hurts your eyes to watch the game (you need to reduce the saturation to about 40%).Overall very badly designed game, a wannabe minecraft-like game with advanced tech but at the end is more annoying, with highly confusing gameplay and dont forget many hotkeys, you basicaly need to use whole keyboard to do one thing.

content:
Posted: February 2
												I got the game, as a lover of factory building games, and tower defense games, and the likeI pick up these types of games with relatively low expectations, if I can get a few days of enjoyment out of them hey, I'm relatively fine with that, but I have to say the developer of this game has made a completely unenjoyable game that many have picked up with hope for what it could be.the (lone) developer's attitude ammounting to this: I'm not doing it wrong, and my game is just as good as or better than x other game, people are just too stupid to realize itrather than accepting the fact that he has made an unenjoyable game that's idea of content is long ginds and waits, where you are forced to play longer than steam's main refund policy in before you can even begin to realize how little (and unenjoyable) content the game really has.whats more, rather than properly fixing their game, when an issue showed up relating to directX and unity, rather than fixing than putting out a patch to fix the problem, instead he left people to dig for the fix, even if he did post the fix, it is extremely poor customer servicerelating to the developers live streams, which I've frequently watched both him and streamers he was talking to while they played. the developer of this game uses being a 'lone developer' as an excuse constantly, despite constantly going on about how great his game is doing, if the game is doing as well as he says it is, he can afford to hire proper helpthe developer has reached to point of unsulting those people who have been unsatisfied with the game giving negative reveiws calling them 'abusive' and with ill intentthe maker of this game has no intention of delivering on this game, he slapped together a game, perhaps with good intentions at the start, but he slapped a 'finished' label on it as though that 'finished' label would magicly make people happy with the gamehis attitude towards the people who play his game, is that he shouldn't need to update it, and we should be happy he gives us anything since he decided the game was 'finished' 16 major patches ago, and describes those patches were 'free content' despite the fact that the game was marked as being 'completed' when it was no where near it, and his attitude suggests he could just abandon the game and run with the money if he chose to. now for the POSITIVE (yes there is a positive): the most recent patch, PATCH 16, seems to be a shift in the right direction, polishing the game in a way that fortresscraft has long needed that developer still has a bad attitude, but watching his interactions with steamers suggest that slap from reallity is coming, and he is at the beginning of seeing it coming he talks about how his game would be so much greater if people would just stream and post videos of it more, meanwhile he goes on to their streams and insults them when they do to the point that the big youtubers that took interest in the game in the early stages, now completely ignore his requests. ( in the recent stream by cpw, a well known developer of numerous very well known mods for other games, the djarcas (the developer of forgresscraft) spent a great deal of time saying it wasn't his fault that the person playing was stupid, when the game did a poor job of explaining what needed to be done )now to wrap things up, I've seen enough upstart developers in my own personal work who later got a nice slap in the face from reallity, I'll wait things out a bit and give them time, but the developer of this game needs a serious reallity check if this game is ever to be recomended by me, even as insiginficant as that will likely sound, telling your customers that they are wrong for disliking what you've done with the game is and extremely poor buisness practice.

content:
Posted: January 3
												While I'm not sure if this is abandonded, it is certainly unfinished garbage. The initial tutorial does very little hand holding, then just dumps you in the game. The client frequently crashes (to be fair, this may or may not be related to hardware issues when my graphics card gets hot), but half the time launching the game will cause it to freeze. I can't join multi-player as the network thread immediately crashes when I try to join. I feel like there's a lot of depth to the tech tree, but I'm still yet to get past tin and copper. *IF* I manage to find tin and copper near my starting location, I'm then stuck unable to find any higher level metals to progress with.EDIT: So after several restarts, and by switching from Mac to Windows, the game is getting better. I'm actually making progress now and starting to unlock the tech tree. I'm seeing more of the game now, but the initial learning curve is very steep, and the game doesn't hold your hand at all. Unless you're willing to be reading forums and searching wikis, you're going to find the start of the game hard.

content:
Posted: February 14
Product received for free
												Once upon a time there were 2 games, one was called Factorio and the other was called Minecraft. One night they both got really drunk and slept together, then out popped a baby game. This is that baby game. I only pratted about for alittle while to see what it's like so nowhere near enough to give it a definitive thumbs up or down, will update the review if i do bother to play again. First impressions are its not very user friendly, frustrating controls and lack of guidance. I like playing games to chill and have a bit of fun and could feel myself getting a bit annoyed with the lack of simple things. Another thing this game claims is that the map is huge and, yes it is but most of that size is of nothingness, just big empty caverns everywhere so goes to show size is not everything. I will keep an eye on development to see if things improve and i hope they do as it could have some potential but as it is, its just a big frustrating borefest.

content:
Posted: August 4, 2016
												Horrible. Although it may seem very interesting at first glance the game is littered with problems.The help guide is bugged, the blocks sometimes don't load in your hot-bar, there is no inventory, very limited amount of blocks.. The list goes on.But there's some interesting things to it as well. There is a creative mode, a weather staff that allows you to summon storms and meteorites, and a little drone that follows you around. Along with the option to color blocks, and a seemingly never ending ground limit ( you can tunnel for quite a while)The game is still drowned out by the fact that it needs more care and development to grow into its full potential.

content:
Posted: July 29, 2016
												Game starts: A cool intro, your mothership blows up and you crashland... not just waking up naked somewhere like most survival games.But then, you are trapped in a tutorial bubble, with the instructions to press E by some f#@$#$ing hub.Ok there is a center hub thing, that has allsorts of other things around it, you can build and process things, and make power...Neat! Well... WTF now?!?! Press E near the hub does not advance the tutorial..... Pressing E near the devices just activates them..... I have owned this game for over 2 years now, and have installed it 4 times. Each time I end up in the middle of WTF land.I have no idea why they can not have a normal tutorial.... you know, go here, click this, do that,......F#@#$#@$k no... You get to just walk around and be confused, constantly being nagged to press E to interact with a bunch of Sh!t that does nothing for you.I can understand why this game is totaly unpopular, unpopulated, and unknown... It is because NOBODY has a f-king clue on how to play the god dammed thing.It has nothing to do with fortress crafting or anything... it is all about being in a f-king bubble pressing E walking in circles , and playing like you are interacting with a bunch of cryptic crap.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 18
												I am frustrated. This is a review of the direction of the game and the developer. Make your decision on a purchase accordingly. I have a factory which I have just spent 100 hours building. With one fell swoop the dev has decided that I will practically need to rebuild my whole power production (by releasing a patch that drastically changes production of fuel). For a factory this size, it is no small chore.After having complained about the lack of warning for this change, I was given in-game suggestions to fix this - again, no small chore redesigning/rebuilding.And basically told to suck it up.To the dev: being "the only developer" for the game is NOT an excuse for shoddy, poorly-thought-out decisions and not looking after your gamers. This decision is clearly poorly-thought-out, as you didn't even realise the effect it would have on other systems downstream. And while you maintain your skepticism that I use 300fuel/min, I (and others) have already pointed out you need only 100/min to hit this bottleneck in my game. This furthur shows you have not thought out the effects on games running settings other than default (which are available within the base game).(I might add that 300items/min isn't even the default setting)All I have asked for is a way to roll back the changes via beta-opt-in, which you have previously provided for players for AESTHETIC changes.And as a developer, telling your players to "stick to facts and you might get a better response" is a very almighty way of saying "I don't give a damn" after all of the above.Like I said, I am frustrated.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 18
												Update 27FEB2017I switched from No to Yes after playing a bit more. I must admit its not a bad game and the pricepoint (12,99€) is fair. Too slow for me thought - building and automating is fun, manual labour and running errands is not. If you are more of a patient soul than me you will probably enjoy this  "Space engineer"/Minecraft/Factorio hybrid. (p.s. the huge monsters are awesome). OLD -------------------------------------------------Because of all the hating im going to post my reply to the dev (+ some clarification) here:I expect to be able to play without a major time investment. The game is not that complicated - but the user interface makes it feel that way. Its not that hard - except on your patience. I was impressed with a lot of things like: The early game on the surface with a great view, the awesome spiderbot and gigantic monsters. The scanner, the automation, the lift etc. all awesome. BUT: its feels like its going nowhere - like the game never starts. 20 hours is a LONG time to spend on something. And the 10 last was spent hoping the game would start to pick up. Its more like a template for a great game. Recap of 20 hours spent (as replied to dev):- Used default settings. No idear what they where. - Read the ingame guides. - Didn't get all 7 ressources. Started dying fast when digging deeper.- Research got slow and there where some unknown components missing.- Got really tired of collecting ressources manually - and since research got stalled i couldn't get tubes and thus the ressources up from below.Original review (unaltered):Has potential buy way too slow and grindy. It feels like the developer is trying to prevent me from having fun by dragging out everything into oblivion. Would be ok at 3-5€ or/and tagged as early access.
